Actinaria: {"seaAnemones": {"name": "Sea Anemones", "description": "Sea anemones are a group of predatory marine invertebrates belonging to the order Actiniaria. They are named after the Anemone, a terrestrial flowering plant, due to their colorful appearance. Sea anemones are classified in the phylum Cnidaria, class Anthozoa, subclass Hexacorallia. They are related to corals, jellyfish, tube-dwelling anemones, and Hydra.", "anatomy": {"description": "Sea anemones have a single polyp attached to a hard surface by its base, with a columnar trunk topped by an oral disc with a ring of tentacles and a central mouth. The tentacles are armed with stinging cells called cnidocytes and are used for catching prey. Some species have a symbiotic relationship with single-celled dinoflagellates or green algae. The digestive system is incomplete and functions as both mouth and anus, with waste being excreted through a single opening. They also have a primitive nervous system and musculature for contraction and movement.", "size": "Most sea anemones are 1 to 5 cm in diameter and 1.5 to 10 cm in length, but there are species that can be larger, such as Urticina columbiana and Stichodactyla mertensii, which can exceed 1 metre in diameter."}, "reproduction": {"breeding": "Sea anemones breed by liberating sperm and eggs into the sea. The fertilized eggs develop into planula larvae, which settle on the seabed and develop directly into juvenile polyps. They can also reproduce asexually by breaking in half or into smaller pieces which regenerate into polyps.", "lifeCycle": "Anemones entirely lack the free-swimming medusal stage of their life cycle. Both sexual and asexual reproduction can occur."}, "behavior": {"movement": "Sea anemones can change their shape dramatically and are capable of locomotion, including creeping, gliding, and swimming. They have the ability to cast themselves loose from the substrate and drift to a new location."}, "feeding": {"diet": "Sea anemones are predators, capturing prey of suitable size that comes within reach of their tentacles and immobilizing it with the aid of their stinging cells. They typically feed on small fish, crustaceans, and other marine organisms."}, "ecology": {"habitats": "Sea anemones are found in both deep oceans and shallow coastal waters worldwide. They are adapted to a variety of environments, including rocks, shells, submerged timber, sand, and mud."}, "relationshipWithHumans": {"aquariumTrade": "Sea anemones and their attendant anemone fish are often harvested from the wild for aquarium exhibits, impacting the populations of both. Fishing activities significantly impact the populations of anemones and anemone fish in exploited areas."}, "fossilRecord": "Fossils of sea anemones do exist, with Mackenzia being the oldest fossil identified as a sea anemone from the Middle Cambrian Burgess Shale of Canada."}}
Actiniaria: {"name": "Sea anemones", "taxonomy": {"phylum": "Cnidaria", "class": "Anthozoa", "subclass": "Hexacorallia", "order": "Actiniaria"}, "anatomy": {"description": "Sea anemones typically have a polyp with a columnar trunk topped by an oral disc with a ring of tentacles and a central mouth. The tentacles are armed with cnidocytes (stinging cells) and can be retracted or expanded. Some species have additional nourishment from symbiotic relationships with single-celled dinoflagellates or green algae."}, "reproduction": {"description": "Sea anemones breed by liberating sperm and eggs into the sea, with fertilized eggs developing into planula larvae. Some species live in symbiotic relationships with clownfish, hermit crabs, or small fish."}, "digestiveSystem": {"description": "Sea anemones have a gastrovascular cavity functioning as a stomach with a single opening serving as both mouth and anus. They excrete waste through this opening and have a flattened pharynx opening into the gastrovascular cavity divided into chambers by mesenteries."}, "lifeCycle": {"description": "Sea anemones lack a free-swimming medusal stage and reproduce both sexually and asexually. They have great powers of regeneration and can reproduce by budding, fragmentation, or longitudinal or transverse binary fission."}, "behavior": {"description": "Sea anemones are capable of changing shape dramatically and some species are capable of burrowing, walking, or swimming."}, "ecology": {"habitat": "Sea anemones are found in deep oceans and shallow coastal waters worldwide, clinging onto rocks, shells, or submerged timber. Some species burrow into sand and mud, while others are pelagic."}, "relationshipWithHumans": {"description": "Sea anemones and their attendant anemone fish are often harvested from the wild as adults or juveniles for aquarium exhibits, impacting the populations of both species in exploited areas."}, "fossilRecord": {"description": "Fossils of sea anemones are rare, but some species have been identified in the fossil record, such as Mackenzia from the Middle Cambrian Burgess Shale of Canada."}, "relatedTopics": ["Cnidaria", "Anthozoa", "Hexacorallia"]}
Actiniidae: {"Actiniidae": {"description": "Actiniidae is the largest family of sea anemones, to which most common, temperate, shore species belong. Most members of this family do not participate in symbioses with fishes. Three exceptions are the bubble-tip anemone (with anemonefish and certain cardinalfish), snakelocks anemone (with Incognito goby) and Urticina piscivora (with painted greenling).", "characteristics": {"Arrangement of tentacles": "Important in defining genera for Actiniidae families. There may be one tentacle per space between mesenteries or there may be more than one tentacle between each two mesenteries. Members of the family Actiniidae have one tentacle per space."}, "genera": ["Anthopleura sola"]}}

Aglantha digitale: {"Aglantha digitale": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Cnidaria", "class": "Hydrozoa", "order": "Trachymedusae", "family": "Rhopalonematidae", "genus": "Aglantha", "species": "digitale"}, "description": "Aglantha digitale is a small, transparent, hydrozoan with a maximum height of 4 cm (1.6 in). The bell is thimble-shaped, taller than it is wide, and has a small conical bulge at the apex. It has about eighty slender solid marginal tentacles on the edge of the bell. The gastric peduncle dangles inside the bell, and the mouth at the tip of the small manubrium has four simple lips. Mature individuals have eight white, sausage-shaped gonads which are visible through the bell. This hydrozoan is usually some shade of pink.", "distribution_and_habitat": {"distribution": "Aglantha digitale is found in surface waters in the Arctic and sub-Arctic, occurring above the continental slope but more common over the deep ocean. It seldom occurs at a depth greater than 200 m (660 ft).", "habitat": "It is the most common species of jellyfish found in the Arctic and sub-Arctic."}, "ecology": {"unique_feature": "Aglantha digitale is unique among known jellyfish in having giant axons in the subumbrella which are involved in a rapid escape response. When stimulated, it can produce up to three vigorous contractions that propel it a distance of about five body lengths. This rapid escape response may help it to avoid damage to its fragile tissues in its pelagic habitat."}}}
Agonidae: {"Agonidae": {"description": "Agonidae is a family of small, bottom-dwelling, cold-water marine fish known for their elongated bodies covered by scales modified into bony plates. They use their large pectoral fins to move in short bursts. The family includes about 59 species in some 25 genera, and is notable for species like poachers, Irish lords, sea ravens, alligatorfishes, starsnouts, hooknoses, and rockheads. They feed on small crustaceans and marine worms found on the bottom and are found in cold, deep waters of the Northern Hemisphere.", "common_names": ["Poachers", "Irish lords", "Sea ravens", "Alligatorfishes", "Starnouts", "Hooknoses", "Rockheads"], "physical_characteristics": {"size": {"largest_species": "Dragon poacher (Percis japonica) - 42 cm (17 in)", "smallest_species": "Bothragonus occidentalis - 7 cm (2.8 in)", "typical_range": "Most species are in the 20\u201330 cm range"}, "body_features": {"scales": "modified into bony plates", "pelvic_fins": "nearly vestigial, consisting of one small spine and a few rays", "swim_bladder": "not present"}}, "habitat_and_behavior": {"habitat_depth": "1,280 m (4,200 ft) deep, with some species in shallower coastal waters", "camouflage": "Some species camouflage themselves with hydras, sponges, or seaweed", "feeding_habits": "Feed on small crustaceans and marine worms found on the bottom"}, "taxonomy": {"proposed_by": "William John Swainson in 1839", "classification": "Superfamily Cottoidea, suborder Cottoidei, order Scorpaeniformes", "taxonomic_note": "Some authorities include it within the infraorder Cottales of the Perciformes"}, "subfamilies_and_genera": {"Hemilepidontinae": ["Hemilepidotus"], "Hemitripterinae": ["Blepsias", "Hemitripterus", "Nautichthys"], "Bothragoninae": ["Bothragonus"], "Hypsagoninae": ["Agonomalus", "Hypsagonus", "Percis"], "Anoplagoninae": ["Anoplagonus", "Aspidophoroides"], "Brachyopsinae": ["Brachyopsis", "Chesnonia", "Occella", "Pallasina", "Stellerina", "Tilesina"], "Agoninae": ["Agonopsis", "Agonus", "Freemanichthys", "Leptagonus", "Podothecus", "Sarritor"], "Bathyagoninae": ["Bathyagonus", "Odontopyxis", "Xeneretmus"]}}}

Alcyonacea: {"Alcyonacea": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Cnidaria", "class": "Anthozoa", "order": "Alcyonacea"}, "habitat": "Throughout the oceans of the world, especially in the deep sea, polar waters, tropics, and subtropics", "common_name": "Soft corals", "description": "Alcyonacea are sessile colonial cnidarians commonly known as soft corals. Alcyoniidae: {"Alcyoniidae": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Cnidaria", "class": "Anthozoa", "order": "Alcyonacea", "family": "Alcyoniidae"}, "description": "A family of leathery or soft corals characterized by colonies with stiff, hard, and inflexible structures composed of tiny polyps projecting from a shared leathery tissue. Members of the family may have two kinds of polyps: the autozooids with long trunks and eight tiny branched tentacles, and the siphonozooids which remain below the surface and pump water for the colony.", "distributionAndHabitat": "Leathery corals occur globally in temperate and tropical seas. They are often pioneer reef species and are found in wave-exposed areas of reef crests, less turbid waters in lagoons, on steep slopes, under overhangs, and at depths of thirty metres or even deeper.", "biology": {"symbioticRelationship": "Leathery coral polyps include endosymbiotic algae called zooxanthellae, which undergo photosynthesis and produce sugars from sunlight. This food is shared with the host, which itself provides the algae with minerals and shelter. Periodically, the surface layer of the leathery tissue is shed as a mechanism for ridding the colony of unwanted algal growth.", "populationStudy": "A study on the Great Barrier Reef found the population of these corals to be very stable, with little predation, low rates of growth, reproduction, and mortality, and few new colonies coming into existence or disappearing over a three-year period."}, "genera": ["Alcyonium", "Aldersladum", "Anthomastus", "Bathyalcyon", "Bellonella", "Cladiella", "Complexum", "Dampia", "Discophyton", "Elbeenus", "Eleutherobia", "Hedera", "Heteropolypus", "Inflatocalyx", "Klyxum", "Lanthanocephalus", "Lithophyton", "Lobophytum", "Lobularia", "Lohowia", "Malacacanthus", "Minabea", "Notodysiferus", "Paraminabea", "Parerythropodium", "Protodendron", "Pseudoanthomastus", "Rhytisma", "Sarcophyton", "Sinularia", "Skamnarium", "Sphaeralcyon", "Sphaerasclera", "Thrombophyton", "Verseveldtia"]}, "relatedTopics": ["Alcyonium digitatum", "Alcyonium glomeratum"]}

Amblyraja hyperborea: {"ArcticSkate": {"scientificName": "Amblyraja hyperborea", "family": "Rajidae", "habitat": "Arctic Ocean, waters around Canada and northern and north-western Europe, northern Pacific Ocean, waters surrounding Antarctica and New Zealand", "depth": "140 to 2,500 m", "description": "The Arctic skate is about 1 m long and is gray-brown with large dark spots. Amphipoda: {"Amphipoda": {"type": "order", "description": "Amphipoda is an order of malacostracan crustaceans with laterally compressed bodies, no carapace, and a range in size from 1 to 340 millimetres. They are mostly detritivores or scavengers and are found in marine, freshwater, and terrestrial environments. There are more than 9,900 known species of amphipods.", "etymologyAndNames": {"etymology": "The name Amphipoda comes from the Greek roots \u1f00\u03bc\u03c6\u03af 'on both/all sides' and \u03c0\u03bf\u03cd\u03c2 'foot'. They are also known as freshwater shrimp, scuds, or sideswimmers among anglers."}, "anatomy": {"segments": 13, "bodyParts": {"head": "fused to the thorax and bears two pairs of antennae and one pair of sessile compound eyes, and carries concealed mouthparts", "thorax": "distinct from abdomen, bears eight pairs of uniramous appendages, gills, and an open circulatory system with a heart", "abdomen": "divided into pleosome and urosome, comprising swimming legs and uropods"}, "size": "Amphipods range in size from less than 1 millimetre to as large as 340 millimetres, with the largest species recorded at 28-34 centimetres in length."}, "reproductionAndLifeCycle": {"reproduction": "Amphipods engage in amplexus for mating, and females bear a marsupium for carrying eggs until they hatch into juvenile forms.", "mortality": "Mortality is around 25\u201350% for the eggs, and there are no larval stages."}, "diversityAndClassification": {"diversity": "There are over 10,500 recognized species of amphipods, distributed among several suborders including Gammaridea, Caprellidea, Hyperiidea, and Ingolfiellidea.", "classification": "The recent works in classification have led to the establishment of new suborders and infraorders based on cladistic analysis and molecular data."}, "fossilRecord": {"origin": "Amphipods are thought to have originated in the Lower Carboniferous, and the fossil record is meagre, with the oldest specimens dating back to the Lower Cretaceous and Upper Eocene."}, "ecology": {"habitats": "Amphipods are found in almost all aquatic environments, from fresh water to the Challenger Deep, and are important components of aquatic ecosystems.", "feedingBehavior": "Most amphipods are detritivores or scavengers, but some are grazers of algae, omnivores, or predators of small insects and crustaceans."}, "relatedTopics": ["Pseudamphithoides incurvaria", "Orchestia grillus"], "externalResources": ["Media related to Amphipoda at Wikimedia Commons", "Data related to Amphipoda at Wikispecies"]}}
Anarrhichthys ocellatus: {"name": "Wolf eel", "scientificName": "Anarrhichthys ocellatus", "taxonomy": {"phylum": "Chordata", "class": "Actinopterygii", "order": "Perciformes", "family": "Anarhichadidae", "genus": "Anarrhichthys"}, "description": "The wolf eel is a species of marine ray-finned fish found in the North Pacific Ocean. Despite its name, it is not a true eel. It can grow up to 2.4 m in length and 18.4 kg in weight. Younger wolf eels are orange with dark spots, while older ones are grey, brown, or dark olive. They have powerful jaws with canine teeth in the front and molars in the posterior portion of the mouth.", "habitat": {"distribution": "Caves, crevices, and rocky reefs from shallow waters to a depth of 226 m, ranging from the Sea of Japan and the Bering Sea to Northern California"}, "behavior": {"socialStructure": "Monogamous, mate for life, and live in the same cave. Reproduce from October until the end of winter.", "predators": "Sharks, big fish, harbor seals"}, "diet": "Feeds on invertebrates with hard shells, such as crustaceans, sea urchins, mussels, clams, and some fishes, crushing them with its strong jaws.", "reproduction": {"matingBehavior": "Male places head against female's abdomen and wraps around her while she extrudes the eggs. Male fertilizes the eggs. Female coils around the eggs to protect them. Eggs hatch after 91 to 112 days."}, "conservationStatus": "Not evaluated", "interestingFacts": ["Only species in the monotypic genus Anarrhichthys", "Can live up to 20 years", "Considered a sacred 'doctorfish' by some Native American tribes", "Edible, with sweet and savory white flesh"]}

Anomura: {"Anomura": {"group": "decapod crustaceans", "includes": ["hermit crabs", "other varieties"], "sister_group": "Brachyura", "clade": "Meiura", "description": "Anomura is a group of decapod crustaceans that includes hermit crabs and other varieties. It is the sister group to Brachyura, and together they form the clade Meiura. The name derives from an old classification system and reflects the unusual variety of forms in this group. Anomurans show instances of carcinisation, resulting in the development of a crab-like body form. They have ten pereiopods, with the last pair often reduced in size and hidden inside the gill chamber. Anomurans diverged from Brachyura in the Late Triassic period, and the oldest known fossil attributed to Anomura is Platykotta from the Late Triassic Period in the United Arab Emirates.", "evolution": {"placement": "within the group Reptantia", "divergence": "Late Triassic period", "earliest_fossil": {"name": "Platykotta", "age": "Late Triassic", "location": "United Arab Emirates"}}, "classification": {"infraorder": "Anomura", "extant_superfamilies": ["Hippidae", "Paguroidea", "Parapaguridae"], "oldest_fossil": {"name": "Platykotta", "age": "Late Triassic", "location": "United Arab Emirates"}}, "external_links": [{"title": "Media related to Anomura at Wikimedia Commons", "url": "https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Anomura"}, {"title": "Data related to Anomura at Wikispecies", "url": "https://species.wikimedia.org/wiki/Anomura"}]}}
Anoplogaster cornuta: {"Anoplogaster cornuta": {"scientificName": "Anoplogaster cornuta", "commonName": "Common Fangtooth", "description": "Anoplogaster cornuta, also known as the common fangtooth, is a deep sea fish found in tropical and temperate oceans worldwide. It has a distinctive appearance with a large bony head, small eyes, and well-armed mouth with sharp fangs. The adults are dark brown to black in color and can grow to a total length of about 18 cm (7 in). Juveniles look different, with a much paler color and triangular cross-section.", "distribution": "The common fangtooth is found in tropical and temperate waters in both the eastern and western Atlantic Ocean, the Indian Ocean, and the Pacific Ocean. It inhabits depths ranging from 2 to 5,000 metres, with adults usually found between 500 and 5,000 metres and juveniles near the surface.", "habitat": "It is a pelagic fish occurring in deep waters, often forming small groups or being solitary. Juveniles are found at lesser depths.", "behavior": "The common fangtooth is a predator feeding on other fish, crustaceans, and cephalopods. It is preyed upon by tunas, marlins, and albacores. The fish breeds in the summer months and the developing larvae are planktonic. It is oviparous and lives for at least three years based on otolith examination.", "research": "Studies have shown that the common fangtooth is able to regulate its respiratory system according to its environment, and its respiration rate is directly proportional to its size. The fish has evolved features that make it nearly invisible in its deep-sea habitat, including efficient light absorption using melanin pigments in its dermis."}}

Anthozoa: {"Anthozoa": {"taxonomy": {"phylum": "Cnidaria", "subclass": [{"name": "Hexacorallia", "description": "Members have six-fold symmetry including stony corals, sea anemones, tube anemones, and zoanthids."}, {"name": "Octocorallia", "description": "Members have eight-fold symmetry including soft corals, gorgonians (sea pens, sea fans, and sea whips), and sea pansies."}, {"name": "Ceriantharia", "description": "Consists of tube-dwelling anemones."}], "incertae sedis": "Some additional species are also included in this category until their exact taxonomic position can be ascertained."}, "anatomy": {"bodyForm": "The basic body form of an anthozoan is the polyp, consisting of a tubular column topped by an oral disc with a central mouth surrounded by tentacles.", "skeleton": "Strengthened by calcium carbonate and other materials, taking various forms such as massive, plate-like, bushy, or leafy."}, "biology": {"feeding": "Carnivorous, catching prey with their tentacles, and some species supplement their energy needs by incorporating photosynthetic algae into their tissues.", "reproduction": "Releases sperm and eggs into the water, and larvae form part of the plankton before settling on the seabed and metamorphosing into polyps."}, "ecology": {"habitats": ["Coral reefs", "Shallow water environments", "Deep-water locations"], "importance": "Support a diverse array of marine life, provide food, hiding places, breeding grounds, and nurseries for many species, and influence the productivity of the ocean."}, "interactionsWithHumans": {"threats": ["Natural events", "Increased sea temperatures", "Pollution", "Sedimentation", "Destructive fishing practices"], "impact": "Coral reefs and shallow marine environments are threatened by various man-made problems and human activities."}}}

Antipathes: {"genus": "Antipathes", "order": "Antipatharia", "description": "Antipathes is a genus of coral in the order Antipatharia, composed of black coral with a black skeleton. It contains symmetrically aligned as well as irregularly shaped corals, a range of different colors, and colonies that can be either sparsely branched or closely packed. The polyps for these corals have six tentacles that are each lined with stinging cells. They lack photosynthesizing algae and prefer to live in deeper waters near currents to catch and eat passing zooplankton.", "species": ["Antipathes aculeata", "Antipathes arborea", "Antipathes assimilis", "Antipathes atlantica", "Antipathes brooki", "Antipathes caribbeana", "Antipathes catharinae", "Antipathes ceylonensis", "Antipathes chamaemorus", "Antipathes chota", "Antipathes contorta", "Antipathes craticulata", "Antipathes curvata", "Antipathes delicatula", "Antipathes dendrochristos", "Antipathes densa", "Antipathes dichotoma", "Antipathes dofleini", "Antipathes dubia", "Antipathes elegans", "Antipathes erinaceus", "Antipathes fragilis", "Antipathes fruticosa", "Antipathes furcata", "Antipathes galapagensis", "Antipathes gallensis", "Antipathes gracilis", "Antipathes grandiflora", "Antipathes grandis", "Antipathes grayi", "Antipathes griggi", "Antipathes herdmanni", "Antipathes hypnoides", "Antipathes indistincta", "Antipathes irregularis", "Antipathes lenta", "Antipathes lentipinna", "Antipathes longibrachiata", "Antipathes minor", "Antipathes nilanduensis", "Antipathes orichalcea", "Antipathes pauroclema", "Antipathes plana", "Antipathes plantagenista", "Antipathes pseudodichotoma", "Antipathes regularis", "Antipathes rhipidion", "Antipathes rubra", "Antipathes rubusiformis", "Antipathes salicoides", "Antipathes sarothrum", "Antipathes sealarki", "Antipathes sibogae", "Antipathes simplex", "Antipathes simpsoni", "Antipathes speciosa", "Antipathes spinulosa", "Antipathes taxiformis", "Antipathes tenuispina", "Antipathes ternatensis", "Antipathes thamnoides", "Antipathes tristis", "Antipathes umbratica", "Antipathes viminalis", "Antipathes virgata", "Antipathes zoothallus"]}

Aphanipathes: {"Aphanipathes": {"genus": "Aphanipathes", "taxonomy": {"family_gbif": "Aphanipathidae", "family_itis": "Antipathidae"}, "habitat": "Subtropic and tropic regions, continental slope of the ocean floor or coral reefs", "distribution": {"A. columbiana": "Western Atlantic, Colombia, Caribbean", "A. pedata": "West Indies, Atlantic coast of Florida", "A. salix": "West Indies", "A. verticillata": "Indian Ocean, Ryukyu Islands, Okinawa Island, Au\u2019au Channel, Hawaii", "A. sarothamnoides": "South Pacific, Palau, northwest Pacific"}, "morphology": {"species_groups": {"uniform_polypar_spines": [], "irregular_polypar_spines": {"A. sarothamnoides": "Bushy, irregular branching corallum with mostly straight, elongated, upward branches", "A. salix": "2-3 cm long branchlets, spaced 0.3-2 cm apart, with 0.22 mm tall polypar and 0.13 mm abpolypar spines"}, "irregular_polypar_spines_reduced_hypostomal_spines": {"A. columbiana": "Fan-shaped with 9th order and greater branching, long, smooth spines, \u22640.15mm in diameter", "A. verticillata": "Large colonies branched to the 12th or greater order, compressed conical spines covered in small conical tubercles"}}, "morphological_features": {"A. sarothamnoides": "5-10 cm long branchlets, spaced 1.5-2.5cm apart with 0.2mm long spines, with tubercles covering the top third or half of spines", "A. verticillata": "Spines in rows are spaced 0.28-0.36 mm apart usually, but not more than 0.5mm, polyps are typically 1.2-1.5 mm in transverse diameter"}}, "relationship_to_genus": {"Aphanipathes_pedata": "DNA sequencing shows a close relationship to Phanopathes rigida in the same family Aphanipathidae"}}}

Aphyonidae: {"Aphyonidae": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Chordata", "class": "Actinopterygii", "order": "Ophidiiformes", "family": "Aphyonidae"}, "habitat": "Tropical and subtropical deep-sea waters worldwide", "depth": {"range": "2,000 - 6,000 metres", "unit": "metres"}, "description": "Aphyonidae is a family of eel-like fishes. They are small, typically about 10 centimetres long when fully grown, and have transparent, gelatinous skin without scales. Their dorsal, caudal, and anal fins are united into a single ribbon. Most species exhibit neoteny, retaining larval features as adults. They have partially calcified skeleton, underdeveloped muscles and gills, reduced eyes, nasal organ and lateral line, and lack a swim bladder. Aphyonids are viviparous, with males producing sperm sacs for extended storage, enabling mating with immature females who can store the sperm until reaching sexual maturity."}}
Aplacophora: {"Aplacophora": {"description": "A class of small, deep-water, exclusively benthic, marine molluscs found in all oceans, consisting of the two clades Solenogastres and Caudofoveata, with about 320 species.", "characteristics": {"Form": "Cylindrical and worm-like, with some species reaching a length of 30 centimetres (12 in)", "Shell": "All known modern forms are shell-less, with only some extinct primitive forms possessing valves", "Habitat": "Caudofoveates generally burrow into the substrate while solenogasters are usually epibenthic", "Feeding": "Solenogasters are carnivores feeding on cnidarians or sometimes annelids, while caudofoveates are mostly detritovores or feed on foraminiferans"}, "anatomy": {"Mantle Cavity": "Reduced into a simple cloaca, located at the posterior of the animal", "Head": "Rudimentary, with no eyes or tentacles", "Cuticle": "Chitinous with an irregular texture, bearing organic matrix-coated spicules", "Digestive System": "Possesses both a radula and a style, indicating a relationship with other molluscs", "Reproduction": "Solenogasters are hermaphroditic with internal fertilization, while caudofoveates have two sexes and reproduce by external fertilization"}, "evolution": {"Classification": "Once classified as sea cucumbers in the echinoderms, officially recognized as molluscs in 1987", "Clades": "Two clades: Solenogastres and Caudofoveata", "Phylogeny": "Considered polyphyletic but recent molecular evidence supports it as a monophyletic clade, with fossil evidence supporting a link to Polyplacophora"}}}
Apolemia: {"Apolemia": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Cnidaria", "class": "Hydrozoa", "order": "Siphonophorae", "family": "Apolemiidae", "genus": "Apolemia"}, "discovery": {"discoveredBy": "Johann Friedrich von Eschscholtz", "discoveryYear": 1815, "firstSpeciesDocumented": "Apolemia uvaria"}, "feeding": {"diet": "Carnivorous", "prey": ["Small fish", "Crustaceans", "Copepods", "Other plankton", "Siphonophores"]}, "bodyPlan": {"classification": "Physonectae", "features": ["Pneumatophore", "Nectosome", "Polyp and medusae forms (zooids)"]}, "nematocysts": {"function": "Inject toxins and incapacitate prey", "behaviorChange": "Transition to more sessile, ambush lifestyle as colony grows"}, "pneumatophore": {"function": "Facilitate vertical displacement", "buoyancyRegulation": "Assist in traversing higher or lower in water column", "survivalImportance": "Evacuation from less optimal water conditions"}, "nectophore": {"function": "Facilitate horizontal displacement", "communicationLevel": "Exhibit high level of communication within colony"}, "species": ["Apolemia contorta", "Apolemia lanosa", "Apolemia rubriversa", "Apolemia uvaria", "Apolemia vitiazi"], "notable": {"2020Discovery": "Coiled into a spiral form off the coast of Western Australia", "sizeComparison": {"withLionManeJellyfish": "Longer than any other animal when including colonial animals"}, "additionalInfo": "The largest known specimen of the lion's mane jellyfish had tentacles as long as 37m and a tentacular spread of about 75m"}}}

Arachnactidae: {"Arachnactidae": {"scientificName": "Arachnactidae", "taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Cnidaria", "class": "Anthozoa", "order": "Ceriantharia", "family": "Arachnactidae"}, "description": "Arachnactidae is a family of tube-dwelling anemones in the order Ceriantharia. It is the only family in the monotypic order Penicillaria and comprises around 38 species. They differ from other ceriantharians in the makeup of their cnidome, the relative sizes of the oral discs, and the shape and structure of the mesenteries. Arthropoda: {"Arthropods": {"Definition": "Arthropods are invertebrates in the phylum Arthropoda. They possess an exoskeleton with a cuticle made of chitin, often mineralized with calcium carbonate, a body with differentiated (metameric) segments, and paired jointed appendages.", "Characteristics": {"Exoskeleton": "Arthropods have an exoskeleton with a cuticle made of chitin and often mineralized with calcium carbonate.", "Growth": "Arthropods must go through stages of moulting, a process by which they shed their exoskeleton to reveal a new one.", "Diversity": "Arthropods are an extremely diverse group, with up to 10 million species."}, "Physiology": {"RespiratorySystem": "Arthropods have a variety of respiratory systems depending on their environment and subphylum. They may use gills, tracheae, or other mechanisms for respiration.", "CirculatorySystem": "Arthropods have an open circulatory system with haemolymph functioning as the analogue of blood."}, "NervousSystem": {"Structure": "The nervous system is 'ladder-like', with paired ventral nerve cords running through all segments and forming paired ganglia in each segment.", "Specialization": "Arthropods have specialized sensory organs, including compound eyes, pigment-pit ocelli for vision, along with various chemical and mechanical sensors."}, "ReproductionAndDevelopment": {"Reproduction": "Most terrestrial species use internal fertilization, while aquatic species use either internal or external fertilization. Some arthropods are viviparous, and others lay eggs.", "Development": "Arthropod hatchlings vary in forms, from miniature adults to grubs and caterpillars, and undergo a total metamorphosis to produce the adult form."}, "EvolutionAndAncestry": {"Ancestry": "The evolutionary ancestry of arthropods dates back to the Cambrian period. The group is generally regarded as monophyletic, and many analyses support the placement of arthropods with cycloneuralians in a superphylum Ecdysozoa."}, "Etymology": {"Origin": "The word 'arthropod' comes from the Greek words '\u00e1rt[h]ron' (joint) and 'po\u00fas' (foot or leg), which together mean 'jointed leg'. The designation 'Arthropoda' appears to have been first used in 1843 by the German zoologist Johann Ludwig Christian Gravenhorst."}}}

The primary tubercles form an alternate series down the perradius. These traits distinguish this genus from Plesiodiadema and Gymnotiara. The primary tubercles are perforated and notched. bacterial mat: {"biofilm": {"definition": "A biofilm is a syntrophic community of microorganisms in which cells stick to each other and often also to a surface. These adherent cells become embedded within a slimy extracellular matrix that is composed of extracellular polymeric substances (EPSs). The cells within the biofilm produce the EPS components, which are typically a polymeric combination of extracellular polysaccharides, proteins, lipids, and DNA.", "formation": {"origin": {"primitive Earth": "Biofilms are thought to have arisen during primitive Earth as a defense mechanism for prokaryotes, as the conditions at that time were too harsh for their survival."}, "factors": "Biofilms may form on living (biotic) or non-living (abiotic) surfaces and can be common in natural, industrial, and hospital settings. The formation of a biofilm begins with the attachment of free-floating microorganisms to a surface."}, "development": {"stages": {"attachment": "The first colonist bacteria of a biofilm may adhere to the surface initially by weak van der Waals forces and hydrophobic effects. If the colonists are not immediately separated from the surface, they can anchor themselves more permanently using cell adhesion structures such as pili."}, "dispersal": "Dispersal of cells from the biofilm colony is an essential stage of the biofilm life cycle as it enables biofilms to spread and colonize new surfaces."}, "properties": {"habitats": "Biofilms are usually found on solid substrates submerged in or exposed to an aqueous solution, although they can form as floating mats on liquid surfaces and also on the surface of leaves, particularly in high humidity climates. Biofilms can attach to a surface such as a tooth or rock, and may include a single species or a diverse group of microorganisms."}, "uses_and_impact": {"medicine": "Around two-thirds of bacterial infections in humans involve biofilms. Infections associated with biofilm growth are usually challenging to eradicate. This is mostly due to the fact that mature biofilms display antimicrobial tolerance and immune response evasions.", "industry": "For example, many sewage treatment plants include a secondary treatment stage in which waste water passes over biofilms grown on filters, which extract and digest organic compounds.", "food_industry": "Biofilms have become problematic in several food industries due to the ability to form on plants and during industrial processes. Bacteria can survive long periods of time in water, animal manure, and soil, causing biofilm formation on plants or in the processing equipment."}, "eukaryotic": {"examples": ["fungi", "microalgae"], "horizontal_gene_transfer": "It happens frequently in prokaryotes, and less frequently in eukaryotes. Biofilms promote horizontal gene transfer in a variety of ways."}, "cultivation_devices": ["microtiter plate (MTP) systems", "BioFilm Ring Test", "Robbins Device", "Drip Flow Biofilm Reactor", "rotary devices", "flow chambers", "microfluidic approaches"]}}

Bathypterois grallator: {"tripodFish": {"scientificName": "Bathypterois grallator", "commonName": "Tripod Fish", "family": "Ipnopidae", "habitat": {"description": "Found relatively widely in the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian oceans from 40\u00b0N to 40\u00b0S. The fish's head-and-body is up to 43.4 cm (17.1 in) long, but its fins can be more than 1 m (3 ft 3 in).", "behavior": "Most of the time, the tripodfish stands on its three fins on the bottom of the ocean, hunting for food. Its fins are presumably quite stiff, but can be flexible when swimming. Scientists have suggested that fluids are pumped into these fins when the fish is 'standing' to make them more rigid."}, "feedingBehavior": {"description": "Uses tactile and mechanosensory cues to identify food and does not have special visual adaptations. The fish faces into the current, waiting for prey to drift by and senses objects in the water with its front fins, which act like hands. Once they feel prey and realize it is edible, the fins knock the food into the fish's mouth."}, "reproduction": {"description": "Each individual has male and female reproductive organs. If two tripodfish happen to meet, they mate. Beroe abyssicola: {"name": "Beroe abyssicola", "taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Ctenophora", "class": "Nuda", "order": "Beroida", "genus": "Beroe", "species": "B. abyssicola"}, "description": "Beroe abyssicola is a pelagic ctenophore species that inhabits the North Pacific. Beroe cucumis: {"species": "Beroe cucumis", "taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Ctenophora", "class": "Nuda", "order": "Beroida", "family": "Beroidae", "genus": "Beroe", "species_author": "Otto Fabricius", "year_described": 1780}, "description": {"body": "Transparent, sac-like, often somewhat compressed, with a maximum length of about 15 cm. Beroe gracilis: {"Beroe gracilis": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Ctenophora", "class": "Nuda", "order": "Beroida", "family": "Beroidae", "genus": "Beroe", "species": "gracilis"}, "description": "Beroe gracilis is a translucent, elongated, hollow, cylindrical comb jelly with a maximum length of about 4 cm (1.6 in). It lacks tentacles and has a gaping mouth at the broader anterior end. It possesses a statocyst at the posterior end and eight rows of combs with cilia which propel the animal forward, creating multicoloured sparkles. The body wall is slightly milky, sometimes bluish or pinkish in color, allowing the gut and diverticula to be visible.", "distributionAndHabitat": "It is found in the North Sea, the Atlantic Ocean, the Mediterranean Sea, and occasionally in the Baltic Sea, with its range extending from Norway to Morocco. It also occurs in the northeastern Pacific Ocean and cold deep waters off the Bahamas. In recent years, specimens were collected off the coast of Chile, marking the first records from the Southern Hemisphere. Beroe gracilis is part of the nekton, actively swimming in the top 100 m (330 ft) of the water column.", "ecology": "Beroe gracilis is a voracious predator, feeding almost exclusively on other comb jellies, such as Pleurobrachia pileus. It captures prey by swimming rapidly with its mouth open wide and processes it using specialized cilia. It primarily preys on the warty comb jelly Mnemiopsis leidyi, which has become invasive in European waters. While Beroe gracilis readily preys on M. leidyi, it is limited in controlling the alien species by its inability to ingest prey approaching its own size."}}

Bivalvia: {"Bivalvia": {"description": "Bivalvia is a class of marine and freshwater molluscs with laterally compressed bodies enclosed by a shell consisting of two hinged parts. The class includes clams, oysters, cockles, mussels, scallops, and numerous other families that live in saltwater, as well as a number of families that live in freshwater. Most bivalves are filter feeders that bury themselves in sediment for protection. The total number of known living species is about 9,200, placed within 1,260 genera and 106 families.", "characteristics": {"Body": "Laterally compressed with a shell consisting of two hinged parts", "Organs": "Lack some usual molluscan organs like the radula and the odontophore", "Gills": "Specialized organs for feeding and breathing, evolved into ctenidia", "Habitat": "Marine and freshwater environments", "Feeding": "Primarily filter feeders, some are carnivorous", "Reproduction": "Spawning, larvae development, and brooding"}, "etymology": {"Taxonomic term": "First used by Linnaeus in 1758 to refer to animals having shells composed of two valves", "Alternative names": "Lamellibranchiata and Pelecypoda"}, "anatomy": {"Shell": "Composed of calcium carbonate, consists of two usually similar parts called valves", "Muscles": "Include posterior and anterior adductor muscles, hinge ligament, and retractor muscles", "Nervous system": "Consists of a nerve network and paired ganglia", "Senses": "Mainly mechanoreceptors and chemoreceptors, with simple eyes in some species"}, "behavior": {"Feeding": "Primarily filter feeding, some are carnivorous, and some are endosymbiotic", "Movement": "Most are sedentary or sessile, some can swim or burrow quickly"}, "uses": {"Food": "Important source of human food and an industry product for global trade", "Other uses": "Used decoratively, in tools, in wampum, and in diverse craftwork"}, "ecosystem_services": {"Nutrient_extraction": "Bivalves filter particles like phytoplankton, transforming particulate organic matter", "Bioremediation": "Used for bioremediation including removal of pollutants from water", "Bioindicators": "Accumulate substances like heavy metals, used for monitoring environmental health"}, "taxonomy": {"Traditional taxonomies": "Based on hinge tooth morphology or gill morphology", "Modern taxonomy": "Reflects a comprehensive analysis of multiple organ systems, shell morphology, and molecular phylogenetics"}, "commercial_impact": {"Mariculture": "Cultivation of bivalves for food production is a highly important industry", "Pearl production": "Certain species used for pearl cultivation and mother-of-pearl"}}}

Bonellia viridis: {"Bonellia viridis": {"scientificName": "Bonellia viridis", "commonName": "Green spoonworm", "taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Annelida", "class": "Polychaeta", "order": "", "family": "", "genus": "Bonellia", "species": "viridis"}, "description": "Bonellia viridis, also known as the green spoonworm, is a marine worm noted for its exceptional sexual dimorphism and the biocidal properties of a pigment in its skin. Brachyura: {"entity": "Crab", "description": "Crabs are decapod crustaceans with a short projecting 'tail', typically hidden under the thorax. They are found in all of the world's oceans, freshwater, and on land, and have a thick exoskeleton and a single pair of pincers on each arm. They first appeared during the Jurassic Period.", "characteristics": {"exoskeleton": "Crabs are covered with a thick exoskeleton composed primarily of highly mineralized chitin.", "size": "Crabs vary in size from a few millimeters wide to a leg span of up to 4 m (13 ft).", "breathing": "Crabs breathe through gills on their underside.", "sexual dimorphism": "Crabs often show marked sexual dimorphism, with males having larger claws and different abdominal shapes.", "reproduction": "Most crabs have internal fertilization and mate belly-to-belly. Females often carry fertilized eggs on their abdomen and release the larvae into the water after development.", "behavior": "Crabs typically walk sideways, are aggressive toward one another, and are omnivores, feeding primarily on algae and other food sources.", "human consumption": "Crabs are consumed worldwide as a dish prepared in various ways. Some species are eaten whole, while others have specific components consumed in different cultures.", "evolution": "The earliest unambiguous crab fossils date from the Early Jurassic. Crabs radiated in the Late Jurassic, increased in diversity through the Cretaceous, and represented the dominant group of decapods by the end of the period."}, "environment": "Crabs are found in all of the world's oceans, freshwater, and on land, particularly in tropical regions. About 850 species are freshwater crabs.", "human_consumption": {"fisheries": "Crabs make up 20% of all marine crustaceans caught, farmed, and consumed worldwide, amounting to 1.5 million tonnes annually.", "cookery": "Crabs are prepared and eaten as a dish in many different ways all over the world, and some species are particularly valued for their meat."}, "evolution": {"fossils": "The earliest unambiguous crab fossils date from the Early Jurassic.", "radiation": "Crabs radiated in the Late Jurassic, increased in diversity through the Cretaceous, and represented the dominant group of decapods by the end of the period."}, "classification": {"taxonomy": "The infraorder Brachyura contains approximately 7,000 species in 98 families, and the evolution of crabs is characterized by an increasingly robust body and a reduction in the abdomen.", "superfamilies": {"count": "Approximately 7,000 species in 98 families."}}, "cultural_influences": {"mythology": "Crabs have influenced various mythologies and cultural beliefs, and are depicted in constellations, astrological signs, and ancient art."}}

Brisingida: {"entity": "Brisingids", "description": "Brisingids are deep-sea-dwelling starfish in the order Brisingida. Brotula multibarbata: {"Brotula barbata": {"commonName": "Goatsbeard brotula", "species": "Brotula barbata", "genus": "Brotula", "habitat": "Indo-Pacific", "depth": "Up to 300 meters", "coloration": {"male": "Dark brown with a submarginal black band and narrow white border on the dorsal and anal fins", "female": "Greenish to orange brown with orange-bordered dorsal and anal fins"}, "size": "Up to 100 centimeters", "diet": "Carnivorous", "reproduction": "Oviparous"}}
Bryozoa: {"name": "Bryozoa", "phylum": "Bryozoa (Ectoprocta)", "alternativeNames": ["Polyzoa", "Moss animals"], "description": "Bryozoa, also known as Polyzoa, Ectoprocta, or commonly as moss animals, are a phylum of simple, aquatic invertebrate animals, nearly all living in sedentary colonies. They have a special feeding structure called a lophophore, a 'crown' of tentacles used for filter feeding.", "characteristics": {"size": "Typically about 0.5 millimetres (1\u204464 in) long", "feedingStructure": "Lophophore, a 'crown' of tentacles used for filter feeding", "distribution": "Most marine bryozoans live in tropical waters, but a few are found in oceanic trenches and polar waters", "classification": ["Marine bryozoans (Stenolaemata)", "Freshwater bryozoans (Phylactolaemata)", "Mostly-marine bryozoans (Gymnolaemata)"]}, "taxonomy": {"introduction": "The terms Polyzoa and Bryozoa were introduced in 1830 and 1831, respectively. Soon after it was named, another group of animals was discovered whose filtering mechanism looked similar, so it was included in Bryozoa until 1869, when the two groups were noted to be very different internally.", "namingDispute": "Disagreements about terminology persisted well into the 20th century, but 'Bryozoa' is now the generally accepted term.", "diversity": "5,869 living species are known, with at least two genera being solitary (Aethozooides and Monobryozoon) and the rest being colonial."}, "colonyForms": {"description": "Colonies take a variety of forms, including fans, bushes, and sheets. Single animals, called zooids, live throughout the colony and are not fully independent.", "autozooids": "Responsible for feeding, excretion, and supplying nutrients to the colony through diverse channels", "specialistZooids": "Some classes have specialist zooids like hatcheries for fertilized eggs, colonial defense structures, and root-like attachment structures."}, "zooid": {"components": ["cystid, which provides the body wall and produces the exoskeleton", "polypide, which holds the organs"], "reproduction": {"hermaphrodites": "Zooids of all the freshwater species are simultaneous hermaphrodites. Although those of many marine species function first as males and then as females, their colonies always contain a combination of zooids that are in their male and female stages.", "larvae": "After settling, all larvae undergo a radical metamorphosis that destroys and rebuilds almost all the internal tissues."}, "defense": "Some species emit sperm into the water and also release ova into the water, while others capture sperm via their tentacles to fertilize their ova internally."}, "predators": {"marineBryozoans": ["sea slugs (nudibranchs)", "fish", "sea urchins", "pycnogonids", "crustaceans", "mites", "starfish"], "freshwaterBryozoans": ["snails", "insects", "fish"]}, "fossilRecord": {"appearance": "Mineralized skeletons of bryozoans first appear in rocks from the Early Ordovician period, making it the last major phylum to appear in the fossil record.", "evolution": "It is uncertain whether the phylum is monophyletic and their evolutionary relationships to other phyla are also unclear."}, "distinguishingFeatures": "Bryozoans, phoronids, and brachiopods strain food out of the water by means of a lophophore, a 'crown' of hollow tentacles. Bryozoans form colonies consisting of clones called zooids that are typically about 0.5 mm (1\u204464 in) long."}
Buccinidae: {"Buccinidae": {"common_name": "Whelks", "description": "Buccinidae is a large and diverse taxonomic family of sea snails, commonly known as whelks. The family includes more than 1500 species and is characterized by moderate to large-sized shells, conical to fusiform in shape, with deep sutures and a generally smooth surface. They are carnivorous and scavengers, feeding on clams, carrion, and detritus. The female whelk lays spongy egg capsules with hundreds of eggs. The flesh of the common northern whelk, Buccinum undatum, is highly valued as a food item. The empty shells of whelks are often used by hermit crabs as homes.", "habitat": "True whelks are found worldwide in all seas, from tropical oceans to the cold seas of the Arctic and Southern Oceans. They inhabit a wide range of depths, from the intertidal to the bathypelagic zones. While most prefer a solid bottom, some inhabit sandy substrates.", "genera": {"subfamily Buccininae": {"tribes": {"Ancistrolepidini": {"genus": "Ancistrolepis"}, "Buccinini": {"genus": ["Buccinum", "Suessionia"]}, "Buccinulini": {"genus": "Buccinulum"}, "Colini": {"genus": "Truncaria"}, "Liomesini": {"genus": "Liomesus"}, "Parancistrolepidini": {"genus": "Parancistrolepis"}, "Prosiphonini": {"genus": "Prosipho"}, "Volutopsiini": {"genus": "Volutopsius"}}}, "subfamily Beringiinae": {"genus": "Beringius"}, "subfamily Donovaniinae": {"genus": "Donovania"}, "subfamily Neptuneinae": {"genus": ["Aulacofusus", "Neptunea"]}, "subfamily Siphonaliinae": {"genus": "Siphonalia"}}}}
Buskiella: {"Buskiella": {"taxonomy": {"genus": "pelagic polychaete annelids", "family": ["Flotidae", "Flabelligeridae"]}, "appearance": {"description": "Bluish or yellowish, live exclusively in very deep water, move by swinging their bodies from side to side", "behavior": "Rowing with their bristles"}, "species": {"Buskiella abyssorum": {"description": "Covered by a transparent mucus sheath, have a cephalic cage, prominent parapodia, first described in 1885 from deep waters off Sierra Leone"}, "Buskiella flabelligera": {"description": "Covered by a thick mucus sheath, have less than ten segments, covered with papillae, bioluminescence reported, first described off southwestern Chile in 1967"}, "Buskiella vitjasi": {"description": "Grows to between 20 and 30 mm long, found at depths between 4000 and 6000 metres below sea level near Kuril-Kamchatka trench in the Pacific Ocean, thick and translucent gelatinous sheath, originally described in 1977"}}, "taxonomicHistory": {"1967": "Genus Flota described with one species (F. flabelligera) in the family Flabelligeridae by Olga Hartman", "1971": "Genus transferred by Hartman into the newly-erected Fauveliopsidae", "1977": "A second species, Flota vitjasi, is described by Galina N. Caecosagitta macrocephala: {"Chaetognath": {"name": "Caecosagitta macrocephala", "commonName": "deep sea marine chaetognath", "distribution": "meso- and bathypelagic layers, Subantarctic to Subarctic Ocean", "characteristics": {"headSize": "large", "bioluminescentOrgans": {"location": "ventral edge of anterior lateral fin", "composition": "hexagonal chambers with elongate ovoid particles"}, "eyes": {"photoreceptiveRegions": "allow them to catch weak light at bathypelagic depths"}, "gut": {"pigmentation": "orange", "luminousOrgan": "with bioluminescence"}}, "genus": "Caecosagitta", "relatedSpecies": ["Eukrohnia fowleri"], "bioluminescence": {"type": "coelenterazine based", "luciferase": "highly unstable and rapidly inactivated at ice-cold temperatures"}, "additionalInfo": "C. macrocephala has been found to consist of at least two cryptic species"}}
Caenogastropoda: {"Caenogastropoda": {"taxonomy": {"subclass": "Caenogastropoda", "class": "Gastropoda", "description": "Caenogastropoda is a taxonomic subclass of molluscs in the class Gastropoda. It is a large diverse group which are mostly sea snails and other marine gastropod mollusks, but also includes some freshwater snails and some land snails. The subclass is the most diverse and ecologically successful of the gastropods.", "diversity": "Caenogastropoda contains many families of shelled marine molluscs \u2013 including the periwinkles, cowries, wentletraps, moon snails, murexes, cone snails and turrids \u2013 and constitutes about 60% of all living gastropods.", "phylogeny": {"establishment": "The taxon Caenogastropoda was first established by Leslie Reginald Cox in 1960 as a superorder but now sometimes it is retained as a clade.", "monophyletic": true, "division": {"taenioglossa": "Equivalent to the older Mesogastropoda, with typically seven teeth in each radular row.", "stenoglossa": "The Neogastropoda, with only 1\u20133 teeth per row."}}, "latest_taxonomy": {"subterclass": "Sorbeoconcha", "superorder": "Hypsogastropoda", "orders": ["Architaenioglossa", "Littorinimorpha", "Neogastropoda"]}}, "biology": {"characteristics": "The Caenogastropoda exhibit torsion, and thus are included in what was previously called the Streptoneura (meaning twisted nerves), also known as Prosobranchia (meaning gills forward). Specifically, they are characterized by having only a single auricle in the heart and a single pair of gill leaflets.", "anatomy": "They are equivalent to the Monotocardia or Pectinibranchia of older authors.", "phylogeny_insight": "Colgan et al. (2006) provided further insight into the phylogeny of Caenogastropoda."}}}

Callionymidae: {"Dragonets": {"description": "Dragonets are small, colorful, marine fish belonging to the family Callionymidae. They are benthic organisms found mainly in the tropical waters of the western Indo-Pacific. There are 139 known species of dragonets, characterized by their elongated, scaleless bodies and showy fins.", "habitat": "Dragonets inhabit sandy bottoms at depths of around 200 meters in the tropical waters of the western Indo-Pacific.", "taxonomy": {"family": "Callionymidae", "genera": ["Anaora", "Bathycallionymus", "Callionymus", "Diplogrammus", "Draculo", "Eleutherochir", "Eocallionymus", "Foetorepus", "Neosynchiropus", "Paracallionymus", "Protogrammus", "Pseudocalliurichthys", "Repomucenus", "Spinicapitichthys", "Synchiropus", "Tonlesapia"]}, "reproduction": {"spawning": "Dragonet spawning occurs during late afternoons, involving distinct stages of courtship display, pairing, ascending, and the release of eggs and milt. Males are polygynous and will spawn with multiple females in a reproductive day. Females do not guard their offspring, and the released eggs float freely in the water column."}, "feeding": {"diet": "Dragonets feed on benthic sources including copepods, amphipods, and other small invertebrates living on sea grass. Their feeding behavior occurs throughout the day and is not territorial."}, "defense": {"defense_mechanisms": ["Rapidly bury themselves under the sand to hide from predators", "Capable of producing foul-tasting and -smelling substances as a defense mechanism"]}, "behavior": {"sexual_dimorphism": "Many species exhibit marked sexual dimorphism, with males and females colored and patterned differently. Male dragonets are larger and have longer fins than females."}, "locomotion": {"swimming_types": ["Burst swimming", "Continuous swimming", "Rapid swimming", "Vertical swimming"]}}}

Calliostomatidae: {"Calliostomatidae": {"definition": "Calliostomatidae is a family of sea snails within the superfamily Trochoidea and the clade Vetigastropoda.", "description": "The Calliostomatidae are unusually diverse. They are characterized by a stepped spire and a pointy aperture. They may possess or lack an umbilicus. The collumella is sometimes thicker, partially covering the aperture. The spiral whorls can differ between narrow and robust. They inhabit a wide range of ocean habitats, from the intertidal zone to mid-bathyal depths.", "taxonomy": {"2005": {"subfamilies": ["Calliostomatinae Thiele 1924 (1847)", "Thysanodontinae Marshall, 1988"], "tribes": ["Calliostomatini Thiele 1924 (1847)", "Fautricini Marshall, 1995"]}, "2008": {"note": "Calliostomatidae stays in Trochoidea. Callogorgia: {"Callogorgia": {"description": "Callogorgia is a genus of soft corals in the family Primnoidae, with a fan-shaped body structure that serves as a habitat for other organisms. Calyptogena magnifica: {"Calyptogena magnifica": {"type": "Species", "description": "Calyptogena magnifica is a species of giant white clam found clustered around hydrothermal vents at abyssal depths in the Pacific Ocean. Caprellidae: {"Caprellidae": {"scientificName": "Caprellidae", "commonName": "Skeleton shrimps", "description": "Caprellidae is a family of amphipods commonly known as skeleton shrimps. Their common name denotes the threadlike slender body which allows them to virtually disappear among the fine filaments of seaweed, hydroids and bryozoans. They are sometimes also known as ghost shrimps.", "characteristics": {"body": "Slender and elongated", "bodyParts": {"cephalon": "Head", "pereon": "Thorax", "abdomen": "Highly reduced and almost invisible, attached to the posterior of the seventh pereonite"}, "appendages": "Two pairs of antennae, with the first pair usually longer than the second pair. Each pereonite has a pair of appendages known as pereopods. The first two pairs are modified into raptorial appendages known as gnathopods. The third and fourth pair of pereopods are usually reduced or absent altogether. The fifth to seventh pair of pereopods are smaller than the gnathopods and are used for clasping objects.", "sexualDimorphism": "Males are usually far larger than the females."}, "ecology": {"habitat": "Low intertidal zones and subtidal waters among eelgrass, hydroids and bryozoans", "feedingHabits": "Omnivorous, feeding on diatoms, detritus, protozoans, smaller amphipods, and crustacean larvae. Some species are filter feeders, using their antennae to filter food from the water or scrape it off the substrate. Most species are predators that sit and wait like a praying mantis, with their gnathopods ready to snatch any smaller invertebrates which come along."}, "reproductionAndGrowth": {"mating": "Can only occur when the female is between the new and hardened exoskeletons", "brooding": "After mating the female will brood the fertilized eggs within her brood pouch. The young will hatch and emerge as juvenile adults.", "behaviorAfterMating": "In some species, the female has been known to kill the males by injecting venom from a claw within their gnathopod."}, "taxonomy": {"classification": "Superfamily Caprelloidea, infraorder Caprellida, suborder Corophiidea", "subfamilies": ["Caprellinae", "Paracercopinae", "Phtisicinae"], "genera": 1345}, "additionalResources": {"media": "Media related to Caprellidae at Wikimedia Commons", "data": "Data related to Caprellidae at Wikispecies", "photos": "Photos of skeleton shrimp"}}}
Carcharhinus albimarginatus: {"silvertip_shark": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Chordata", "class": "Chondrichthyes", "order": "Carcharhiniformes", "family": "Carcharhinidae", "genus": "Carcharhinus", "species": "Carcharhinus albimarginatus", "description": "The silvertip shark (Carcharhinus albimarginatus) is a large species of requiem shark in the family Carcharhinidae."}, "distribution": {"habitat": "The silvertip shark is widely but not continuously distributed in the tropical Indian and Pacific Oceans. It is found over continental and insular shelves at a depth of 30\u2013800 m (98\u20132,625 ft), occupying all levels of the water column."}, "description": {"physical_description": "The silvertip shark is a robust and streamlined species with a blue-gray coloration above with a bronze sheen, and white below. It can grow up to 3 m (9.8 ft) long and has a maximum reported weight of 162.2 kg (358 lb).", "diet": "The diet of the silvertip shark consists primarily of bony fishes, eagle rays, smaller sharks, and cephalopods."}, "biology": {"reproduction": "Like other requiem sharks, the silvertip shark is viviparous, with females giving birth to one to 11 pups in the summer.", "behavior": "Silvertip sharks are aggressive apex predators and exhibit territorial behavior. They are often encountered alone or in pairs."}, "human_interactions": {"danger_to_humans": "The silvertip shark is regarded as potentially dangerous to humans and has been known to approach divers closely."}, "conservation_status": "The International Union for Conservation of Nature has assessed the silvertip shark as vulnerable due to overfishing and population declines."}}
Careproctus: {"Careproctus": {"description": "Careproctus is a genus of snailfishes found in benthic and benthopelagic habitats in the Atlantic, Pacific, Arctic, and Southern Oceans. They range from shallow coastal seas in the far north of their range to the abyssal zone, at depths of 6 to 5,459 meters.", "habitats": ["Benthic", "Benthopelagic"], "distribution": {"oceans": ["Atlantic", "Pacific", "Arctic", "Southern"]}, "speciality": "Some species of Careproctus are known to have unusual breeding behaviors and some are parasitic on king crabs.", "anatomy": {"features": ["One pair of nostrils", "Ventral suction disc", "Lack pseudobranch", "Tadpole-like shape", "Loose gelatinous skin", "Some species covered in prickly spines"], "size": "Up to 54 cm in standard length"}, "feeding_habits": "Most species of Careproctus feed on small animals.", "behavior": {"breeding": ["Some species exhibit mouth brooding", "C. fulvus has a commensal relationship with glass sponges", "Several species are parasitic on king crabs"]}, "species": ["Careproctus abbreviatus", "Careproctus acaecus", "Careproctus acanthodes", "Careproctus aciculipunctatus", "Careproctus acifer", "Careproctus aculeolatus", "And many more..."]}}
Careproctus ovigerus: {"Careproctus ovigerus": {"commonName": "Abyssal snailfish", "taxonomy": {"phylum": "Chordata", "class": "Actinopterygii", "order": "Scorpaeniformes", "family": "Liparidae", "genus": "Careproctus", "species": "ovigerus", "author": "Charles Henry Gilbert", "year": 1896}, "description": {"habitat": "Northeastern Pacific Ocean at depths of 1,920\u20132,910 m", "physicalCharacteristics": "Elongated fish with gelatinous skin, no scales, large pectoral fins, pelvic fins modified into adhesive disc, maximum length of 43 cm", "finFeatures": {"dorsalFin": {"spines": "none", "softRays": "40-45"}, "analFin": {"spines": "none", "softRays": "35-36"}}, "pelvicDiscSize": "26-38% of total length", "distinguishingFeature": "Cephalic pore pattern: 2\u20136\u20137\u20131", "teeth": "Simple, sharp recurved teeth in a single narrow band"}, "behavior": {"reproduction": "Thought to be a mouth brooder", "reproductiveFeatures": {"male": "Carrying developing eggs in his mouth", "immature females": "Had undeveloped ovaries with small eggs", "mature females": "Had fewer large-yolked eggs in their ovaries"}}, "distribution": "Found off northern British Columbia and off Washington state"}}
Caridea: {"Caridea": {"scientificName": "Caridea", "commonName": "caridean shrimp", "description": "Caridea is an infraorder of shrimp within the order Decapoda, commonly known as caridean shrimp or true shrimp. They are found widely around the world in both fresh and salt water.", "habitat": "Carideans are found in every kind of aquatic habitat, with the majority of species being marine. Around a quarter of the described species are found in fresh water.", "biology": {"size": "They vary greatly in form, from species a few millimetres long when fully grown, to those that grow to over a foot long.", "feedingHabit": "Most carideans are omnivorous, but some are specialised for particular modes of feeding. Some are filter feeders, using their setose (bristly) legs as a sieve; some scrape algae from rocks."}, "lifecycle": {"reproduction": "Carideans brood their eggs rather than releasing them into the water. Caridean larvae undergo all naupliar development within the egg, and eclose as a zoea.", "metamorphosis": "The decapodid larva will metamorphose a final time into a post-larval juvenile, resembling a miniature adult but retaining some larval characteristics."}, "commercialImportance": {"significantSpecies": ["Pandalus borealis", "Crangon crangon"], "fishing": "The most significant commercial species among the carideans is Pandalus borealis, followed by Crangon crangon. The global aquaculture of all shrimp and prawn species slightly exceeded the global wild capture. No carideans were significantly involved in aquaculture, but about 13% of the global wild capture, or about 6% of the total production of all shrimp and prawns, were carideans."}, "relatedTaxa": {"closelyRelated": ["lobsters", "crabs"], "differences": {"gillStructure": "The gill structure is lamellar in carideans but branching in dendrobranchiates.", "abdominalSegment": "The easiest practical way to separate true shrimp from dendrobranchiates is to examine the second abdominal segment.", "chelae": "Carideans typically have two pairs of chelae (claws), while dendrobranchiates have three.", "thirdLegs": "Stenopodidea differs from carideans and dendrobranchiates in that the third pairs of legs is greatly enlarged."}}, "taxonomy": {"superfamilies": 15}, "fossilRecord": {"fossilSpeciesCount": 57, "earliestFossil": "Lower Jurassic and Cretaceous"}}}

Cephalopholis igarashiensis: {"Cephalopholis igarashiensis": {"commonNames": ["Garish hind", "Neptune grouper", "Goldbar grouper", "Japanese cod"], "description": {"bodyFeatures": "Deep body with reddish-orange color, 7 wide lemon-yellow bars on flanks, 3 wide yellow irregular oblique stripes on the head, juveniles are yellower with several white bars on the body and a large black eyespot on the dorsal fin.", "size": "Maximum standard length of 43 centimeters (17 in)", "dorsalFin": "9 spines and 14 soft rays", "analFin": "3 spines and 9 soft rays", "caudalFin": "Rounded"}, "distribution": "Western Pacific Ocean, including Japan, Fiji, French Polynesia, and Australia, also found around Christmas Island in the Indian Ocean.", "habitat": "Steep reef drop-offs, seamounts, and offshore banks in deep waters at depths of 64 to 250 meters (210 to 820 ft)", "diet": "Feeds on fishes and crustaceans", "taxonomy": {"speciesAuthor": "Masao Katayama", "yearOfDescription": 1957, "typeLocality": "Sumisu-tu in the Izu Islands of Japan"}, "utilisation": {"aquariumTrade": "Extremely rare and expensive due to difficulty in adapting to changing water pressure, sold for $8000 SGD ($6300 USD) for a juvenile in Singapore", "fisheries": "Targeted in subsistence fisheries and as a gamefish", "aquariumDisplay": "First displayed in Okinawa Churaumi Aquarium in Japan in January 2009"}}}
Cephalopoda: {"concept": {"name": "Cephalopods", "description": "Cephalopods are a class of marine animals characterized by bilateral body symmetry, a prominent head, and a set of arms or tentacles.", "members": [{"name": "Squid", "description": "Squid are cephalopods of the order Teuthida. They are marine animals known for their elongated bodies, large eyes, and two long tentacles.", "habitat": "Squid are found in all the world's oceans, predominantly in the euphotic zone."}, {"name": "Octopus", "description": "Octopuses are soft-bodied mollusks of the order Octopoda. They belong to the class Cephalopoda and are known for their eight arms and bulbous heads.", "habitat": "Octopuses inhabit many diverse regions of the ocean, including coral reefs, pelagic waters, and the seafloor."}, {"name": "Cuttlefish", "description": "Cuttlefish are marine mollusks of the order Sepiida. They have a unique internal structure called the cuttlebone and are known for their ability to change color and texture.", "habitat": "Cuttlefish are found in shallow coastal waters, but some species are also found at considerable depths."}, {"name": "Nautilus", "description": "Nautiluses are primitive cephalopods that belong to the subclass Nautiloidea. They are characterized by their spiral-shaped shells and many tentacles.", "habitat": "Nautiluses inhabit deep waters near the ocean floor, typically in the Indo-Pacific region."}], "taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Mollusca", "class": "Cephalopoda"}}, "characteristics": {"physical_description": "Cephalopods are characterized by their bilateral body symmetry, prominent heads, and a set of arms or tentacles. They are exclusively marine animals and exhibit a wide range of sizes, from very small species to the massive colossal squid.", "behavior": "Cephalopods are widely regarded as intelligent invertebrates with well-developed senses and large brains. They exhibit complex behaviors, including problem-solving, hunting, and social interactions. Some cephalopods are known to change their color and patterns rapidly for signaling and camouflage purposes.", "senses": "Cephalopods have advanced vision, gravity detection using statocysts, and a variety of chemical sense organs. They rely on vision to detect predators and prey and use their arms and tentacles for exploration.", "reproduction": "Cephalopods reproduce sexually, with males and females exhibiting sexual dimorphism. They employ various mating strategies, including male-male competition, mate choice, and complex courtship behaviors. Some species store sperm and exhibit polyandrous behavior.", "ecological_role": "Cephalopods play essential roles in marine ecosystems as predators and prey. They contribute to nutrient cycling and food webs, influencing the abundance and distribution of various marine organisms."}, "habitat_and_distribution": {"habitat": "Cephalopods are found in all the world's oceans, from the surface to the deep-sea, and can inhabit a wide range of marine environments, including coral reefs, coastal waters, and open ocean.", "distribution": "Their diversity is greatest near the equator, with a decrease in species richness towards the poles. They are also found in the hadal zone, the deepest part of the ocean."}, "importance": {"scientific_research": "The study of cephalopods is important in various scientific fields, including neuroscience, marine biology, and evolutionary biology. They are used as model organisms for studying learning, memory, and behavior.", "ecological_significance": "Cephalopods play a significant role in marine food webs, serving as both predators and prey. Their ecological importance influences the structure and dynamics of marine ecosystems."}}
Cephalurus cephalus: {"lollipopCatshark": {"name": "Lollipop Catshark", "scientificName": "Cephalurus cephalus", "family": "Scyliorhinidae", "genus": "Cephalurus", "description": "The lollipop catshark is a little-known species of deep sea catshark, which can be readily identified by its tadpole-like shape with a greatly expanded, rounded head and narrow body. It is a bottom-dwelling shark found on the outer continental shelf and upper continental slope, and it preys on crustaceans and fishes. The species exhibits aplacental viviparity, with females retaining egg cases internally until they hatch.", "taxonomy": {"originalDescription": "The lollipop catshark was originally described as Catulus cephalus by Charles Henry Gilbert in 1892, and later placed in the genus Cephalurus by Henry F. Bigelow and William C. Schroeder in 1941. There are potentially other undescribed species of Cephalurus in different locations.", "phylogeny": "Cephalurus is thought to form a clade with the genera Asymbolus, Parmaturus, Galeus, and Apristurus, with some disagreement on the interrelationships within this group."}, "distributionAndHabitat": {"range": "The lollipop catshark's range extends from the Gulf of California to off the southern Baja peninsula, and it is abundant in benthic areas around the outer continental shelf and upper continental slope at depths of 155\u2013937 m.", "habitat": "It is found in deep-sea basins with low levels of dissolved oxygen, and may possibly also tolerate high temperatures and salinity."}, "physicalDescription": {"shape": "Tadpole-like with an enormously expanded head and branchial region coupled with a slender, cylindrical body tapering towards the tail.", "distinctiveFeatures": ["Wide, flattened, and rounded head", "Short and blunt snout with widely spaced nostrils", "Large eyes followed by prominent spiracles", "Five pairs of distinctive forward-arching gill slits", "Soft, almost gelatinous body", "Delicate skin sparsely covered by thorn-like dermal denticles", "Plain brownish gray coloration with iridescent green eyes"], "size": "Adults typically attain a length of 24 cm, but may grow up to 28 cm long."}, "biologyAndEcology": {"feedingHabits": "Feeds mainly on crustaceans, followed by fishes.", "reproduction": "Aplacental viviparous with birthing apparently taking place in early summer. Females retain pairs of thin-shelled egg cases within their bodies until they hatch, and newborns measure about 10 cm long."}, "humanInteractions": {"fisheryInterest": "There is no fishery interest in this species, and it may be taken as bycatch. It is presently assessed as least concern by the IUCN."}}}

Beroida: {"Beroidae": {"scientificName": "Beroidae", "commonName": "Beroids", "description": "Beroidae is a family of ctenophores or comb jellies. Chondrocladia: {"Chondrocladia": {"genus": "carnivorous demosponges", "family": "Cladorhizidae", "description": "Chondrocladia is a genus of carnivorous demosponges of the family Cladorhizidae. Neocladia was long considered a junior synonym, but has recently become accepted as a distinct genus. They are stipitate, with a stalk frequently anchored in the substrate by rhizoids and an egg-shaped body, sometimes with branches that end in inflatable spheres. Fossils assignable to this genus are known since the Pleistocene, less than 2 million years ago. Given its deep-sea habitat, Chondrocladia may well have been around for much longer, perhaps since the Mesozoic, as characteristic spicules almost identical to those of some living Chondrocladia are known from Early Jurassic rocks almost 200 million years old.", "carnivory": "These sponges are carnivorous, using hooked spicules to capture small crustaceans and possess a water flow system and choanocytes, albeit highly modified to inflate balloon-like structures that are used for capturing prey.", "species": {"known": ["C. alaskensis", "C. pulchra"], "incorrectly placed": ["C. alaskensis", "C. pulchra"], "junior synonyms": ["C. dura", "C. ramosa", "C. sessilis"], "another genus": ["C. flabelliformis"]}}, "Neocladia": {"description": "Neocladia was long considered a junior synonym of Chondrocladia, but has recently become accepted as a distinct genus."}, "ANDEEP": {"description": "The Antarctic Benthic Deep-Sea Biodiversity Project (ANDEEP) identified a new species of Chondrocladia, a gourd-shaped carnivorous sponge, in the seas off Antarctica."}, "Asbestopluma hypogea": {"description": "Another genus of the family Cladorhizidae, identified in Mediterranean sea caves, known for its carnivorous nature."}}

Cidaris cidaris: {"Cidaris cidaris": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Echinodermata", "class": "Echinoidea", "order": "Cidaroida", "family": "Cidaridae", "genus": "Cidaris", "species": "Cidaris cidaris"}, "common_name": "long-spine slate pen sea urchin", "description": "Cidaris cidaris is a species of sea urchin with a small central test, long, blunt, widely separated primary spines, and a dense covering of short secondary spines. The primaries are pale grey, tipped with green, and the secondaries are pale green. The sea urchin often has bits of algae, sponge, or other organisms adhering to the spines.", "distribution": "Cidaris cidaris is found in the eastern Atlantic Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea in deep water on coral, rock, and gravel bottoms. Its range extends from Cape Verde, the Azores, and the Canary Islands northwards to the Faroe Islands and Norway. It is also found on knolls and seamounts at depths down to about 1,800 meters (5,900 feet).", "biology": {"diet": "Cidaris cidaris feeds on sponges, sea fans, and algae.", "disease": "Cidaris cidaris is one of a number of species of sea urchin that can suffer from bald sea urchin disease."}}}

Cirripedia: {"name": "Barnacles", "scientificName": "Crustacea Cirripedia", "kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Arthropoda", "subphylum": "Crustacea", "habitat": "Exclusively marine, many species in shallow and tidal waters", "description": "Barnacles are arthropods with hard calcareous shells. Cirroteuthis: {"Cirroteuthis muelleri": {"scientificName": "Cirroteuthis muelleri", "commonName": "Big-finned jellyhead", "description": "Cirroteuthis muelleri is a cirrate octopus species closely related to the genus Cirrothauma within the family Cirroteuthidae. It was the first cirrate octopus species and genus to be scientifically described in 1836. It can reach a maximum length of 400 mm (mantle length 170 mm) and is off white or pale purple in color with brownish-purple inner side of the arms and webs. The head features well-developed eyes with lenses, thin and relatively weak upper and lower beaks, and a gelatinous and fragile body. The arms are nearly equal in length with translucent webs joining the dorsal and ventral sides of the arms together. The suckers and cirri are also notable features of its anatomy.", "distribution": "Cirroteuthis muelleri is found in the Arctic Ocean, northern basins of the Atlantic and Pacific, and may also have unidentified species in the southern hemisphere, such as New Zealand and Australia.", "habitat": "It is a deep-sea benthopelagic species, swimming or drifting in the immediate above sea bed in cold seas at depths of over 2,000 m. It is particularly found in the seas around Greenland.", "biology": "Female specimens of Cirroteuthis muelleri were found near the ocean floor at depths between 3,000\u20133,300 m. Their diet includes small crustaceans and polychaetes, all small benthic or epibenthic prey items. They are known to lay large eggs on the ocean floor."}}
Cirrothauma: {"Cirrothauma": {"genus": "deep water octopuses", "family": "Cirroteuthidae", "description": "Cirrothauma is a genus of deep water octopuses from the cirrate family Cirroteuthidae. The species Cirrothauma are fragile, gelatinous deep-sea octopods with a shell, a moderate saddle, and triangular wings. Their eyes either have lenses, as seen in the species Cirrothauma murrayi or they have reduced eyes without lenses, shown in the other extant species Cirrothauma magna. Both species were placed in Cirrothauma due to the fact that they possess similar shells. These octopuses have been reported to live in all the world's oceans, except for the Southern Ocean.", "species": [{"name": "Cirrothauma magna", "author": "Hoyle", "year": 1885}, {"name": "Cirrothauma murrayi", "author": "Chun", "year": 1911}], "distribution": "reported to live in all the world's oceans, except for the Southern Ocean"}}
