Cnemidocarpa finmarkiensis: {"name": "Cnemidocarpa finmarkiensis", "taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Chordata", "class": "Ascidiacea", "order": "Stolidobranchia", "family": "Styelidae", "genus": "Cnemidocarpa", "species": "Cnemidocarpa finmarkiensis"}, "commonNames": ["broad base sea squirt", "orange sea squirt", "red sea squirt", "shiny orange sea squirt", "shiny red tunicate", "Finmark's tunicate"], "description": {"morphology": "Solitary tunicate with a broad base and often appears hemispherical. Cnidaria: {"phylum": "Cnidaria", "description": "Cnidaria is a phylum of aquatic animals found in both freshwater and marine environments. It includes over 11,000 species, such as jellyfish, hydroids, sea anemones, and corals. Cnidarians have a decentralized nervous system, cnidocytes for envenomation and capturing prey, and bodies consisting of mesoglea sandwiched between two layers of epithelium. They exhibit polymorphism, with both swimming medusae and sessile polyps forms. Cnidarians reproduce sexually and asexually, and their early fossils date back to 580 million years ago.", "characteristics": {"nervous_system": "Decentralized nervous system", "cnidocytes": "Specialized cells for envenomation and capturing prey", "body_structure": "Consists of mesoglea sandwiched between two layers of epithelium", "reproduction": "Both sexual and asexual reproduction", "life_cycle": "Polyp and medusa stages"}, "groups": [{"name": "Anthozoa", "examples": ["sea anemones", "corals", "sea pens"]}, {"name": "Scyphozoa", "examples": ["jellyfish"]}, {"name": "Cubozoa", "examples": ["box jellies"]}, {"name": "Hydrozoa", "examples": ["fire corals", "hydroids", "hydroid jellyfishes", "siphonophores", "Hydra"]}, {"name": "Staurozoa", "examples": ["stalked jellyfishes"]}], "ecology": {"habitat": "found in shallow waters, polar regions, and even in freshwater", "ecosystem_role": "Important role in coral reefs and in providing fishing grounds"}, "evolution": {"fossil_record": "Fossils dating back to 580 million years ago, with corals diversified in the Early Ordovician period", "family_tree": "Molecular phylogenetics show that Cnidaria and Bilateria are more closely related to each other than to Ctenophora"}, "interaction_with_humans": {"implications": "Can cause jellyfish stings, are used as a food source in some cultures, and have economic importance in tourism and aquaculture"}}

Comatulida: {"entity": "Comatulida", "description": "Comatulida is an order of crinoids, also known as feather stars, that mostly do not have a stalk as adults. Members of this order are characterized by having the oral surface with the mouth facing upwards and surrounded by five often divided rays with feathery pinnules. They are found in tropical and temperate waters, living on the seabed and on reefs.", "taxonomy": {"suborder": "Bourgueticrinina", "sister_taxon": "Bourgueticrinida (Sea lilies)", "characteristics": "Pentamerous symmetry as adults, bilateral symmetry in larvae. Endoskeleton made of articulated calcareous plates. Body shape is a cup (calyx) with a lid (tegmen) containing the mouth and an anus. They have five long, often branched, rays attached round the edge of the tegmen, each further subdivided into branchlets (pinnules). Comatulids are suspension feeders with dioecious reproduction.", "families": ["Atelecrinidae", "Bathycrinidae", "Phrynocrinidae", "Rhizocrinidae", "Antedonidae", "Pentametrocrinidae", "Zenometridae", "Colobometridae", "Himerometridae", "Mariametridae", "Zygometridae", "Aporometridae", "Notocrinidae", "Asterometridae", "Calometridae", "Charitometridae", "Ptilometridae", "Thalassometridae", "Tropiometridae", "Atopocrinidae", "Bourgueticrinidae", "Eudiocrinidae", "Guillecrinidae", "Septocrinidae"]}, "behavior": "Comatulids are mostly sedentary, but some can move across the seabed or swim with their arms. They are suspension feeders, extending their arms to gather plankton. Reproduction is dioecious, with specialized pinnules producing gametes. After several larval stages, they settle on the seabed and anchor themselves with a stalk, which breaks at metamorphosis.", "ecology": {"composition": "80% calcium carbonate", "predation": "Unappetising to most predators, but preyed on by some fish, with the ability to regenerate lost arms or visceral mass. Many other invertebrates live as commensals among the rays of crinoids."}}

Copepoda: {"Copepods": {"description": "Copepods are a group of small crustaceans found in almost every freshwater and saltwater habitat. Corallimorpharia: {"Corallimorpharia": {"description": "Corallimorpharia is an order of marine cnidarians closely related to stony or reef building corals (Scleractinia). Corallium: {"preciousCoral": {"commonName": "Precious coral", "scientificName": "Corallium", "habitat": {"description": "Red corals grow on rocky seabottom with low sedimentation, typically in dark environments\u2014either in the depths or in dark caverns or crevices. The original species, C. rubrum (formerly Gorgonia nobilis), is found mainly in the Mediterranean Sea. It grows at depths from 10 to 300 meters below sea level, although the shallower of these habitats have been largely depleted by harvesting."}, "anatomy": {"description": "Red corals have the shape of small leafless bushes and can grow up to a meter in height. Their valuable skeleton is composed of intermeshed spicules of hard calcium carbonate, colored in shades of red by carotenoid pigments. In living specimens, the skeletal branches are overlaid with soft bright red integument, from which numerous retractable white polyps protrude."}, "gemstone": {"description": "The hard skeleton of red coral branches is naturally matte, but can be polished to a glassy shine. It exhibits a range of warm reddish pink colors from pale pink to deep red. Owing to its intense and permanent coloration and glossiness, precious coral skeletons have been harvested since antiquity for decorative use. Coral jewellery has been found in ancient Egyptian and prehistoric European burials, and continues to be made to the present day."}, "historyOfTrade": {"description": "At the beginning of the 1st millennium, there was significant trade in coral between the Mediterranean and India, where it was highly prized as a substance believed to be endowed with mysterious sacred properties."}, "culture": {"description": "In Hindu astrology red coral is associated with the planet Mars and used for pleasing Mars. It should be worn on the ring finger. Amongst the Yoruba and Bini peoples of West Africa, red precious coral jewellery are signifiers of high social rank, and are worn as a result by titled kings and chieftains."}, "conservation": {"description": "Intensive fishing, particularly in shallow waters, has damaged this species along the Mediterranean coastline, where colonies at depths of less than 50 meters are much diminished. Fishing and now climate change threaten their persistence."}}}

Cranchia: {"Cranchia scabra": {"scientificName": "Cranchia scabra", "commonName": "Glass squid", "genus": "Cranchia", "family": "Cranchiidae", "size": "Approximately 150 millimeters (5.9 in)", "characteristics": {"mantle": "Covered by large, multi-pointed cartilaginous tubercles", "behavior": "When disturbed, the squid often pulls its head and arms into the mantle cavity and folds its fins tightly against the mantle to form a turgid ball. It may also ink into the mantle cavity, making the ball opaque."}, "bioluminescence": true, "namedAfter": "John Cranch", "sources": [{"title": "CephBase: Cranchia scabra", "url": "https://web.archive.org/web/20050817063551/http://www.cephbase.utmb.edu/refdb/html/cranchiascabraspp.html"}, {"title": "Tree of Life web project: Cranchia scabra", "url": "http://tolweb.org/Cranchia_scabra/19771/2008.05.23"}]}}
Cranchia scabra: {"Cranchia scabra": {"scientificName": "Cranchia scabra", "taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Mollusca", "class": "Cephalopoda", "order": "Oegopsida", "family": "Cranchiidae", "genus": "Cranchia", "species": "Cranchia scabra"}, "description": "Cranchia scabra is a species of glass squid. It is the only species in the genus, and is fairly small (about 150 millimeters (5.9 in)). The mantle is covered by large, multi-pointed cartilagenous tubercles. When disturbed, the squid often pulls its head and arms into the mantle cavity and folds its fins tightly against the mantle to form a turgid ball. The tubercules, presumably, provide some type of protection, but it is unclear what predators are affected and how. In addition, the squid may ink into the mantle cavity, making the ball opaque. This was thought to be an aberrant behavior due to the stress and confinement of shipboard aquaria, until the same inking behavior was seen in cranchiids from submersibles. The function of this behavior is unknown. The genus contains bioluminescent species.", "habitat": "Oceanic waters", "bioluminescence": true, "namedAfter": "John Cranch", "sources": ["CephBase: Cranchia scabra", "Tree of Life web project: Cranchia scabra"]}}
Cranchiidae: {"Cranchiidae": {"description": "The family Cranchiidae comprises approximately 60 species of glass squid, also known as cockatoo squid, cranchiid, cranch squid, or bathyscaphoid squid. Crinoidea: {"topic": "Crinoids", "description": "Crinoids are marine invertebrates in the class Crinoidea, characterized by a mouth located on the upper surface, feeding arms, and a U-shaped gut. They are echinoderms and live in both shallow waters and depths up to 9,000 meters. The class includes approximately 700 living species, but was much more abundant and diverse in the past.", "characteristics": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Echinodermata", "class": "Crinoidea"}, "habitats": "Shallow waters and depths up to 9,000 meters", "feeding": "Passive suspension feeders, filtering plankton and small particles of detritus from the sea water with their feather-like arms", "reproduction": "Dioecious with free-swimming vitellaria larvae", "movement": "Most modern crinoids are free-moving and lack a stem as adults", "fossils": "Abundant in sedimentary rocks and can serve as the primary supporting clasts", "species": "Approximately 700 living species"}, "etymology": {"origin": "From the Ancient Greek word \u03ba\u03c1\u03af\u03bd\u03bf\u03bd (kr\u00ednon), meaning 'a lily', with the suffix \u2013oid meaning 'like'", "common names": {"sea lilies": "Attached to the sea bottom by a stalk in their juvenile form", "feather stars": "Unstalked forms of crinoids"}}, "morphology": {"body form": "Consists of a stem and a crown with a cup-like central body known as the theca and a set of five rays or arms", "arms": "Feathery and branched, often subdivided into multiple branches with pinnules"}, "evolution": {"origins": "Earliest known crinoid groups date back to the Ordovician period", "diversity": "Underwent periods of abrupt adaptive radiation with a significant diversity during the Ordovician and early Triassic"}}

It is observed sitting on the seafloor in the Arctic Ocean.", "abundance": "Highest abundance at 2500 m off California and 1250 m off Hawaii."}, "behavior": {"bioluminescence": "Serves as a defense or warning to other creatures.", "reproduction": "Sexual reproduction, viviparous with females brooding baby medusae."}, "etymology": {"nameOrigin": "Named after Dr. Claudia Mills, a marine scientist at the Friday Harbor Laboratories."}}}
Crustacea: {"subject": "Crustaceans", "type": "Animal", "description": "Crustaceans are a diverse group of mainly aquatic arthropods that include decapods, shrimps, prawns, crabs, lobsters, crayfish, seed shrimp, branchiopods, fish lice, krill, remipedes, isopods, barnacles, copepods, opossum shrimps, amphipods, and mantis shrimp. They are known for their exoskeleton, biramous (two-parted) limbs, and larval forms such as the nauplius stage of branchiopods and copepods.", "characteristics": {"size": "Ranges from 0.1 mm to 3.8 m in leg span and can weigh up to 20 kg", "habitat": "Most are free-living aquatic animals, but some are terrestrial, parasitic, or sessile.", "diet": "Consists of small organisms and detritus; some species are filter feeders."}, "ecology": {"habitats": "Marine or freshwater environments, with some species adapted to life on land", "behavior": "Most are motile, but some are parasitic or live a sessile life; some species can withstand rapid changes in salinity", "impact": "Some species are significant invasive species and can have a significant impact on local ecosystems"}, "reproduction": {"mating system": "Most crustaceans reproduce sexually, while some are hermaphrodites and a few undergo parthenogenesis", "eggs": "Fertilized eggs are released into the water column in many species, while others hold onto the eggs until they are ready to hatch"}, "fossil record": "The fossil record of crustaceans dates back to the Middle Cambrian age, with most major groups appearing before the end of the Cambrian period", "consumption by humans": {"harvesting": "Over 10,700,000 tons were harvested in 2007, with a predominant consumption of decapod crustaceans such as crabs, lobsters, shrimp, crawfish, and prawns", "impact": "60% of all crustaceans caught for consumption are shrimp and prawns, and nearly 80% is produced in Asia"}, "classification": {"subphylum": "Crustacea", "classes": ["Cephalocarida", "Branchiopoda", "Remipedia", "Maxillopoda", "Ostracoda", "Malacostraca"], "orders": "Organized into multiple orders, including Branchiopoda, Remipedia, Cephalocarida, and others", "relationships": "Recent studies based on DNA sequences suggest that Crustacea is paraphyletic, with the hexapods nested within a larger Pancrustacea clade"}, "study": {"scientific study of crustaceans": "Carcinology (also known as malacostracology, crustaceology, or crustalogy)", "scientist who works in carcinology": "Carcinologist"}}
Ctenophora: {"ctenophora": {"scientificName": "Ctenophora", "commonName": "Comb Jellies", "description": "Ctenophora comprise a phylum of marine invertebrates known as comb jellies, notable for the groups of cilia they use for swimming. They are the largest animals to swim with the help of cilia and range in size from a few millimeters to 1.5 m. They have a wide range of body forms and are primarily predators, preying on microscopic larvae, rotifers, and small crustaceans. Fossils of ctenophores have been found in lagerst\u00e4tten dating back to the early Cambrian, about 525 million years ago.", "distinguishingFeatures": {"cells bound by inter-cell connections": true, "carpet-like basement membranes": true, "muscles": true, "nervous systems": true, "sensory organs": true, "colloblasts": true}, "ecology": {"distribution": "Found in most marine environments, from polar waters to the tropics and from the surface to ocean depths of more than 7000 meters. Found near coasts and in mid-ocean. No ctenophores have been found in freshwater.", "preyAndPredators": "Ctenophores are primarily predators, feeding on zooplankton and other small marine organisms. Some are preyed upon by jellyfish, turtles, and other organisms."}, "evolutionaryHistory": {"fossilRecord": "Fossils of ctenophores have been found in lagerst\u00e4tten, dating back to the early Cambrian period, about 525 million years ago. Early fossils resembled modern species but had more comb rows. There are also fossils suggesting a sessile form similar to Vendobionta with cilia on branches, thought to be related to the origin of ctenophores.", "relationshipToOtherAnimalGroups": "The phylogenetic relationship of ctenophores to other animals has been debated, with some studies suggesting they are the sister lineage to all other animals and others suggesting they are sister to Cnidaria, Placozoa, and Bilateria."}, "taxonomy": {"classification": "Traditionally divided into two classes, Tentaculata and Nuda, and further divided into several orders and families."}}}
Ctenophore: {"ctenophora": {"scientificName": "Ctenophora", "commonName": "Comb jellies", "phylum": "Ctenophora", "description": "Ctenophora, commonly known as comb jellies, are marine invertebrates notable for the groups of cilia they use for swimming. Cunina: {"Ancient Roman Birth and Childhood Deities": {"Introduction": "In ancient Roman religion, birth and childhood deities were thought to care for every aspect of conception, pregnancy, childbirth, and child development. The belief in these deities reflects the high value Romans placed on family, tradition, and the compatibility of the sexes.", "Importance": {"Childbirth": "In antiquity, childbirth was a life-threatening experience for both the woman and her newborn, with infant mortality as high as 30 or 40 percent. Rites of passage pertaining to birth and death had several parallel aspects, and maternal death was common.", "Ritual Practices": "Several ritual practices surrounding childbirth may be characterized as anxious superstitions, but the religious aura surrounding childbirth reflects the high value Romans placed on family, tradition, and compatibility of the sexes."}, "Deities and Their Functions": {"Conception and Pregnancy": {"Jugatinus": "A conjugal god associated with marriage and conception.", "Cinxia": "Functioned within the bride's belt, symbolizing marriage and facilitating labor.", "Subigus": "The god who causes the bride to submit sexually to her husband.", "Prema": "An insistent sex act, sometimes referred to as the mother goddess.", "Inuus": "Embodied the mammalian impulse toward mating, associated with sexual penetration.", "Pertunda": "The female personification of the act of penetration.", "Janus": "The god of doorways and passages, associated with providing generative seed for conception.", "Consevius": "The god of propagation and insemination.", "Liber Pater": "Empowered the man to release his semen.", "Libera": "Empowered the woman to release her seed.", "Mena": "Assured menstrual flow.", "Fluonia": "A form of Juno who retained nourishing blood within the womb.", "Alemona": "Fed the embryo and nourished its growth in utero.", "Vitumnus": "Endowed the fetus with life or the vital principle.", "Sentinus": "Gave the newborn sentience or the powers of sense perception."}, "The Parcae": {"Nona, Decima, and Parca": "The three goddesses of fate who determined the right time for birth and overseen the initial separation from the mother's body."}, "Birthing": {"Juno Lucina": "The primary deity presiding over the delivery and introducing the baby to the light.", "Egeria": "Received sacrifices from pregnant women in order to bring out the baby.", "Postverta and Prosa": "Averted breech birth.", "Diespiter": "Brought the baby toward the daylight.", "Lucina": "Introduced the baby to the light.", "Vagitanus": "Opened the newborn's mouth for its first cry.", "Levana": "Lifted the baby and was responsible for the child's fitness or 'straightness'."}, "Neonatal Care": {"Rumina": "Promoted suckling and received libations of milk."}, "Child Development": {"Edusa": "Enabled the taking of nourishment. Also known as Edulia and Educa.", "Fabulinus": "Prompted the child's first words.", "Mens": "Provided the child with intelligence."}}, "Later Literature": "Some of these deities are mentioned in works of literature by authors like James Joyce, showcasing their lasting influence on cultural and literary traditions.", "Sources": "The most extensive lists of deities pertaining to the conception-birth-development cycle come from the Church Fathers, surviving theological works of Roman scholars, and scattered mentions in Latin literature."}}
Cyathidium: {"Saussurea": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Plantae", "division": "Magnoliophyta", "class": "Magnoliopsida", "order": "Asterales", "family": "Asteraceae", "genus": "Saussurea", "tribe": "Cardueae"}, "description": "Saussurea is a genus of about 300 species of flowering plants native to cool temperate and arctic regions of East Asia, Europe, and North America. Cydippida: {"Cydippida": {"taxonomy": {"order": "Cydippida", "phylum": "Ctenophora", "description": "An order of comb jellies characterized by their spherical or oval bodies, branched tentacles, and non-monophyletic classification."}, "anatomy": {"body": "Rounded or cylindrical, with long, slender tentacles that can be retracted into sheaths. Demospongiae: {"Demosponges": {"phylum": "Porifera", "class": "Demospongiae", "description": "Demosponges are the most diverse class in the phylum Porifera, with nearly 8,800 species worldwide. They have a soft body that covers a hard, often massive skeleton made of calcium carbonate, predominantly leuconoid in structure. Their skeletons are made of spicules consisting of fibers of the protein spongin, the mineral silica, or both. They reproduce sexually and asexually, and some species have a long lifespan of 500\u20131,000 years. Demosponges are the only extant organisms that methylate sterols at the 26-position, and their dense skeletons can provide data about ocean temperature and salinity.", "orders": {"Spongillida": {"description": "The only order of freshwater sponges, split from the marine sponges about 311 million years ago in the Late Carboniferous."}}}, "classification": {"ancientHistory": "The first demosponges may have appeared during the Precambrian deposits at the end of the Cryogenian 'Snowball Earth' period. Fossilized steroids called steranes provide indirect evidence of their presence. The earliest Demospongiae fossil was discovered in the lower Cambrian.", "systematics": {"firstClassification": "The Systema Porifera (2002) book organized extant Demospongiae into 14 orders. However, molecular and morphological evidence led to a revision of the classification to include three subclasses: Verongimorpha, Keratosa, and Heteroscleromorpha."}}, "reproduction": {"sexualReproduction": "Spermatocytes and oocytes develop from choanocytes and archeocytes, respectively. The resulting swimming larvae enter a canal of the central cavity and are expelled with the exhalant current.", "asexualReproduction": "Includes budding and the formation of gemmules. Gemmules are found in the freshwater family Spongillidae and are capable of surviving harsh conditions."}, "economicImportance": "The most economically important group of demosponges to humans are the bath sponges, which are harvested by divers and grown commercially. They are bleached and marketed; the spongin gives the sponge its softness."}
Dendronotus patricki: {"Dendronotus patricki": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Mollusca", "class": "Gastropoda", "order": "Nudibranchia", "family": "Dendronotidae", "genus": "Dendronotus", "species": "patricki"}, "common_name": "Patrick's Dendronotid Nudibranch", "description": "Dendronotus patricki is a species of sea slug, a dendronotid nudibranch, a shell-less marine gastropod mollusc in the family Dendronotidae. It is a translucent species with no surface markings and a reddish-brown hue to the body. It can grow to at least 25 mm in length. There is a small amount of opaque white pigment at the tips of the dorsal appendages, velar appendages, and rhinophore sheath papillae.", "distribution": "Dendronotus patricki was described from a whalefall in Monterey Canyon, California at a depth of 1820 m. It was also observed on video from another whalefall in Santa Cruz Basin at a depth of 1676 m.", "habitat": "Dendronotus patricki was found crawling on a muddy seabed at depths of around 1800 m. Its stomach contents included structures thought to be nematocysts, and it is possible that it feeds on burrowing cerianthid anemones as does Dendronotus iris."}}

diatom: {"topic": "Diatoms", "description": "Diatoms are a group of algae found in oceans, waterways, and soils. They play a significant role in producing oxygen, taking in silicon, and contributing to the Earth's biomass. They are unicellular organisms and are known for their silica cell walls. Diatoms are classified as a type of plankton called phytoplankton and are used to monitor past and present environmental conditions. They are also widely used in various industrial applications and have potential uses in nanotechnology.", "importance": {"oxygenProduction": "Diatoms generate about 20 to 50 percent of the oxygen produced on the planet each year.", "biomassContribution": "Diatoms constitute nearly half of the organic material found in the oceans.", "siliconAbsorption": "They take in over 6.7 billion tonnes of silicon each year from the waters they inhabit."}, "characteristics": {"sizeRange": "Diatoms are generally 2 to 200 micrometers in size, with a few larger species.", "shapes": "They occur either as solitary cells or in colonies, which can take the shape of ribbons, fans, zigzags, or stars.", "uniqueFeature": "They are surrounded by a cell wall made of silica, called a frustule. These frustules produce structural coloration, prompting them to be described as 'jewels of the sea' and 'living opals.'"}, "movement": {"passiveMovement": "Movement in diatoms primarily occurs passively as a result of both ocean currents and wind-induced water turbulence."}, "ecologicalRole": {"contributionToPhotosynthesis": "They are estimated to be responsible for about half of photosynthesis in the global oceans.", "roleInCarbonCycle": "They play a crucial role in the biological carbon pump, transferring surface carbon to the deep ocean and sequestering atmospheric CO2 for extended periods."}, "taxonomy": {"phylum": "Bacillariophyta", "class": "Bacillariophyceae", "subphyla": ["Leptocylindrophytina", "Ellerbeckiophytina", "Probosciophytina", "Melosirophytina", "Coscinodiscophytina", "Rhizosoleniophytina", "Arachnoidiscophytina", "Bacillariophytina"]}, "industrialUses": {"diatomite": "Diatoms and their shells, known as diatomite or diatomaceous earth, are used for fine polishing and liquid filtration. Diatomite is considered to be a natural nanomaterial and has numerous industrial applications."}, "history": {"discovery": "The first illustrations of diatoms are found in an article from 1703 in Transactions of the Royal Society showing unmistakable drawings of Tabellaria. The first formally identified diatom, the colonial Bacillaria paxillifera, was described in 1783 by Danish naturalist Otto Friedrich M\u00fcller."}}

Dofleinia: {"Dofleinia armata": {"commonName": "Striped Anemone", "scientificName": "Dofleinia armata", "family": "Actiniidae", "genus": "Dofleinia", "description": "Dofleinia armata is one of Australia's largest species of anemone. It can grow to 20 cm in diameter, with tentacles up to 50 cm long. The base of this species is broad, the column smooth, with a broad, flat oral disc. It has long inner tentacles which are a minimum of double the size of the outer tentacles. The surface of the tentacles end in a tip that is somewhat swollen. The tentacles are either cream, brown, or plain, and are striped. They have a surface that is scale-like and are often observed curling into ball shapes that hide the mouth. It is able to expand its body and tentacles due to a well-developed hydrostatic system.", "distribution": "This species is known to live in the tropical waters of Australia as far south as Perth, Western Australia. It is also known to occur in the Philippines and Indonesia.", "habitat": "The species lives at depths of up to 20 metres in the intertidal zone on sloping, sheltered reefs, as well as in mangroves. It may be found in fine silt or mud.", "dangerToHumans": "The sting of Dofleinia armata presents a danger to humans. Injuries resulting from contact with this species are considered very painful, and can take several months to heal.", "furtherReading": ["Coleman, N. (1977) A Field Guide to Australian Marine Life. Rigby Limited, Adelaide, 223 pp.", "Fautin, D.G. (2003) Hexacorallians of the World. https://archive.today/20120604092440/http://hercules.kgs.ku.edu/hexacoral/anemone2/index.cfm", "Edgar, G.J. (1997) Australian Marine Life: the plants and animals of temperate waters. Reed Books, Kew, 544 pp.", "Honma, Tomohiro; Iso, Takeshi; Ishida, Masami; Nagashima, Yuji & Shiomi, Kazuo (2003). 'Occurrence of type 3 sodium channel peptide toxins in two species of sea anemones (Dofleinia armata and Entacmaea ramsayi)'. Toxicon. 41 (5): 637\u2013639. doi:10.1016/s0041-0101(02)00368-9. PMID 12676443."]}}
Dolioletta: {"Dolioletta": {"scientificName": "Dolioletta", "genus": "Tunicate", "family": "Doliolidae", "characteristics": {"description": "Transparent, gelatinous barrel-shaped animals, usually less than one centimetre long. They move in jerks by contracting the circular bands of muscle in their body wall sharply."}, "biology": {"lifeCycle": "Complex life cycle with alternating sexual and asexual phases. They use a net of mucus strands to efficiently trap phytoplankton floating past. They grow fast and multiply rapidly, with a single animal capable of forming thousands of new individuals in a few days. They sometimes form dense swarms with up to 500 individuals per square metre."}, "species": ["Dolioletta chuni (Neumann, 1906)", "Dolioletta gegenbauri (Uljanin, 1884)", "Dolioletta mirabilis Korotneff, 1891", "Dolioletta tritonis Herdman, 1888", "Dolioletta valdiviae (Neumann, 1906)"]}}
Doliolida: {"Doliolida": {"order": "Tunicata", "subphylum": "Tunicata", "class": "Thaliacea", "description": "Doliolida are small marine animals with barrel-shaped bodies, featuring two wide siphons and circular muscle strands. They are filter feeders and free-swimming plankton, primarily found in tropical oceans. Their complicated life cycle includes sexual and asexual generations, and they can produce an astonishing number of progeny. Doliolids have natural enemies, such as the copepod Sapphirina nigromaculata.", "life_cycle": {"description": "Doliolids alternate through sexual and asexual generations. The sexual generation consists of individuals featuring eight muscle bands, each having male or female gonads. Fertilized eggs produce asexual individuals with nine muscle bands and two stalks, which produce mature progeny asexually."}, "natural_enemies": ["Sapphirina nigromaculata"]}}
Doliolidae: {"Doliolidae": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Chordata", "class": "Ascidiacea", "order": "Doliolida", "family": "Doliolidae"}, "characteristics": {"habitat": "Pelagic, far away from coastlines", "physical_description": "Transparent, gelatinous, barrel-shaped or cylindrical", "size": "Mostly small and inconspicuous", "feeding_behavior": "Use cilia to move water through mucus nets to trap phytoplankton", "movement": "Rapid jerky movement due to sudden contraction of circular muscles"}, "life_cycle": "Complex, with forms that alternate between generations undergoing sexual and asexual reproduction"}, "genera": {"Dolioletta": {"species": ["Dolioletta chuni", "Dolioletta gegenbauri", "Dolioletta mirabilis", "Dolioletta tritonis", "Dolioletta valdiviae"]}, "Doliolina": {}, "Dolioloides": {}, "Doliolum": {"species": ["Doliolum denticulatum", "Doliolum intermedium", "Doliolum nationalis"]}}}

Doryteuthis opalescens: {"Doryteuthis opalescens": {"scientificName": "Doryteuthis opalescens", "commonName": "Opalescent inshore squid", "otherNames": ["Market squid"], "description": "The opalescent inshore squid, or market squid, is a small squid in the family Loliginidae. Echinorhinus cookei: {"name": "Prickly Shark", "scientificName": "Echinorhinus cookei", "family": "Echinorhinidae", "habitat": "Pacific Ocean over continental and insular shelves and slopes, submarine canyons", "depth": "100\u2013650 m (330\u20132,130 ft) deep, occasionally in shallower waters", "description": "Stocky, dark-colored shark with a dense covering of thorn-like dermal denticles, up to 4.0 m (13.1 ft) long, two small dorsal fins, no anal fin", "behavior": "Nocturnally active, with a small home range and diel migration to shallower waters at dusk", "diet": "Bony and cartilaginous fishes, cephalopods, may use suction to capture prey", "reproduction": "Aplacental viviparous, females produce sizable litters, gestating 114 embryos", "humanInteractions": "Not known to be dangerous to humans, minimal economic value, caught incidentally by commercial deepwater fisheries", "conservationStatus": "Data Deficient by the IUCN, classified as 'At Risk \u2013 Naturally Uncommon' with qualifiers 'Data Poor' and 'Secure Overseas' in New Zealand"}
Echinothuriidae: {"Echinothuriidae": {"taxonomy": {"order": "Echinothurioida", "subfamilies": ["Echinothuriinae", "Hygrosomatinae", "Sperosomatinae"], "genera": {"Echinothuriinae": ["Araeosoma", "Asthenosoma", "Calveriosoma", "Hapalosoma"], "Hygrosomatinae": ["Hygrosoma"], "Sperosomatinae": ["Sperosoma", "Tromikosoma", "Retzneiosoma"]}}, "description": "Sea urchins with a disc-like body, flexible test, and thin, weakly calcified plates. Echinothurioida: {"entity": {"name": "Echinothurioida", "description": "The Echinothurioida are an order of sea urchins in the class Echinoidea. They are distinguished by their flexible test and hollow spines, and are nearly all deep-sea dwellers.", "characteristics": {"test": "Echinothurioids have regular tests (shells) with 10 columns of plates. These plates are fused in groups of three with a central primary plate and a half plate on either side, making the test flexible.", "spines": "The primary tubercles which articulate with the spines are each perforated by a hole and the spines are hollow. The primary spines are usually long and are used to support the test and in locomotion. In many species, the secondary spines are tipped with poison glands.", "mouthparts": "The membrane around the mouth contains only simple plates, and the mouthparts, known as the Aristotle's lantern, have simple plates and grooved teeth.", "gills": "The gills are relatively small, and in many species, entirely absent."}, "biology": {"habitat": "Echinothurioids are nearly all found on the seabed at abyssal depths, but some species may be found in shallow water.", "feeding habits": "Little is known of their feeding habits, but examination of their stomach contents suggests they eat detritus, mostly in the form of algal fragments.", "reproduction": "Their reproduction is relatively unstudied, but some members of the group produce eggs with large yolks which at first rise towards the surface and later sink again. The bilaterally symmetrical larva, called an echinopluteus, is planktonic and may not feed, relying on its yolk for nourishment before descending to the seabed and undergoing metamorphosis."}, "evolutionary history": {"fossils": "For many years, echinothurioids were believed to be extinct, being only known from fossils. The earliest known echinothurioid was Pelanechinus, dating back to the Middle to Late Jurassic. The earliest crown group example was Echinothuria, which came from the Upper Cretaceous of southern England."}, "taxonomy": {"families": [{"name": "Echinothuriidae", "genera": ["Araeosoma", "Asthenosoma", "Calveriosoma", "Echinothuria", "Hapalosoma", "Hygrosoma", "Retzneiosoma", "Sperosoma", "Tromikosoma"]}, {"name": "Kamptosomatidae", "genera": ["Kamptosoma"]}, {"name": "Phormosomatidae", "genera": ["Hemiphormosoma", "Paraphormosoma", "Phormosoma"]}, {"name": "Pelanechinidae", "genera": ["Pelanechinus"]}]}, "related_topics": ["Calveriosoma gracile"]}}
Echiura: {"Echiura": {"scientificName": "Echiura", "commonName": "Spoon worms", "description": "A small marine animal group now considered to belong to Annelida, characterized by cylindrical, soft-bodied structure and non-retractable proboscis for feeding.", "taxonomy": {"phylum": "Annelida", "class": "Echiurans", "families": ["Bonelliidae", "Ikedidae", "Echiuridae", "Thalassematidae", "Urechidae"]}, "habitat": "Exclusively marine, inhabiting burrows in soft sediment, rock crevices, under boulders, and deep sea environments.", "anatomy": {"bodyCharacteristics": {"shape": "Cylindrical", "proboscis": {"structure": "Non-retractable, scoop-shaped for feeding", "sizeRange": "Less than a centimetre to more than a metre length"}, "color": "Varies from dull grey or brown to brightly colored species"}}, "behavior": {"feedingHabits": "Primarily detritivores, with various feeding methods including extending proboscis to gather organic particles and deposit feeding", "movement": "Ability to move about on the surface by extending the proboscis and some species can swim", "burrowing": "Utilizes proboscis and body wall for digging and creating burrows in the sediment", "reproduction": "Dioecious with external fertilization, releasing gametes into the water column"}, "distribution": "Majority of species found in the Atlantic Ocean, infaunal in lower intertidal zone or shallow subtidal, some found in deep waters including abyssal depths", "notableSpecies": [{"scientificName": "Bonellia viridis", "description": "Characterized by extreme sexual dimorphism, with females being much larger than males"}, {"scientificName": "Urechis unicinctus", "commonName": "Fat innkeeper worm", "description": "Prized as a food source in East and Southeast Asia, also known as gaebul in South Korea"}], "relevance": {"diet": "Eaten as a delicacy in East and Southeast Asia, including raw and fermented preparations"}}}

Engraulis mordax: {"name": "Californian Anchovy", "scientificName": "Engraulis mordax", "habitat": "Pacific Ocean, ranging from Mexico to British Columbia", "relationships": {"commercialFishing": {"history": "As sardine populations declined in the Pacific during the 1940s and 50's, fish packers in America started canning the more abundant local anchovies. Total hauls increased over this time from 960 tons in 1946 to 9,464 tons in 1947 and peaking at almost 43,000 tons in 1953. Most Californian anchovies today are fished for use in animal feed and as bait fish."}, "recreationalFishing": "They are taken by anglers for use as bait or for personal consumption"}, "uses": ["animal feed", "bait fish"], "conservationStatus": "Not listed as endangered or threatened", "photos": [{"source": "Sealife Collection", "description": "Photos of Californian anchovy"}]}
Enteroctopus: {"Enteroctopus": {"etymology": {"creation": "Alphonse Tremeau de Rochebrune and Jules Fran\u00e7ois Mabille in 1887", "meaning": "joining Ancient Greek \u1f14\u03bd\u03c4\u03b5\u03c1\u03bf\u03bd 'gut' and \u1f40\u03ba\u03c4\u03ce\u03c0\u03bf\u03c5\u03c2, thus 'octopus [with arms similar to] guts.'"}, "description": "Enteroctopus is a genus of generally temperate octopuses characterized by their large size and distinct longitudinal wrinkles or folds dorsally and laterally on their bodies. Their heads are distinctly narrower than the mantle width. The hectocotylus of the males in this genus, found on the third right arm, is long and narrow in comparison with other genera in the family Octopodidae. They have large, paddle-like papillae instead of the more conical papillae in other octopus genera.", "species": {"count": 4, "list": ["E. membranaceus", "E. megalocyathus", "E. magnificus", "E. zealandicus"]}, "distribution": "Species in the genus Enteroctopus are restricted to the temperate areas of the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. E. dofleini is found in the Northern Hemisphere, and the other three species are found in the Southern Hemisphere.", "size": {"E. dofleini": {"record": "The world's largest octopus based on direct measurements of a 71 kilograms (157 pounds) individual, weighed live. This octopus had a total length near to 3.5 metres (11 feet)."}, "other species": "substantially smaller, with E. megalocyathus having an average mass of 4 kilograms (8.8 pounds) and reaching a total length of 1.0 metre (3.3 feet). E. magnificus reaches a total length of around 1.5 metres (5 feet)."}}}
Enteroctopus dofleini: {"name": "Giant Pacific octopus", "scientificName": "Enteroctopus dofleini", "otherNames": ["North Pacific giant octopus"], "description": "The giant Pacific octopus is a large marine cephalopod with a spatial distribution encompassing much of the coastal North Pacific. It is known for its large size, with adults weighing around 15 kg and having an arm span of up to 4.3 m, potentially making it the largest octopus species on earth.", "etymology": {"specificName": "dofleini", "chosenBy": "Gerhard W\u00fclker in honor of German scientist Franz Theodor Doflein", "genusChange": "Moved to genus Enteroctopus by Eric Hochberg in 1998"}, "ecology": {"habitat": "Can be found from the intertidal zone down to 2,000 m, adapted to colder, oxygen- and nutrient-rich waters", "diet": "Preys on various marine organisms including shrimp, crabs, fish, and even seagulls", "predators": "Preyed upon by marine mammals, and also fished for human consumption", "lifespan": "Lives for three to five years, lays between 120,000 and 400,000 eggs, and dies after the young hatch"}, "reproduction": {"reproductiveProcess": "Lays eggs coated in chorion, intensively cared for by the female, and dies soon after the young hatch", "matingProcess": "Female is semelparous and breeds only once in her life"}, "intelligence": {"capabilities": "Considered the most intelligent invertebrates, capable of recognition, problem-solving, tool use, and having personalities"}, "conservation": {"status": "Not currently under international protection, abundance estimates are difficult due to tracking challenges, and future climate change scenarios may impact the species", "challenges": ["Oxygen limitation", "Reproduction changes due to increased seawater temperatures", "Ocean acidification affecting prey base and blood pH", "Toxins in tissues from preferred prey", "Effects on other trophic levels"]}, "references": ["CephBase: Giant Pacific octopus", "The Cephalopod Page"]}

Entosphenus tridentatus: {"name": "Pacific Lamprey", "scientificName": "Entosphenus tridentatus", "family": "Petromyzontidae", "habitat": "Pacific Coast of North America and Asia", "description": {"size": "Up to about 80 cm (31 in) as adults", "characteristics": "Slender, elongated bodies with two dorsal fins arising far back on the body. After spawning, the adults usually die within four days.", "reproduction": "Constructs nest (redd) in small gravel and females can lay over 100,000 eggs, fertilized externally by the male.", "feedingHabits": "Parasitic on other fish and sperm whales, attaching themselves with their suckers and feeding on blood and body fluids. Eumunididae: {"Chirostyloidea": {"description": "Chirostyloidea is an anomuran superfamily with squat lobster-like representatives. It comprises the three families Chirostylidae, Eumunididae, and Kiwaidae. Although representatives of Chirostyloidea are superficially similar to galatheoid squat lobsters, they are more closely related to Lomisoidea and Aegloidea, together forming the clade Australopoda. No fossils can be confidently assigned to the Chirostyloidea, although Pristinaspina may belong either in the family Kiwaidae or Chirostylidae.", "families": [{"name": "Chirostylidae", "year": 1892, "genera": ["Chirostylus", "Gastroptychus", "Hapaloptyx", "Uroptychodes", "Uroptychus"]}, {"name": "Eumunididae", "year": 1900, "genera": ["Eumunida", "Pseudomunida"]}, {"name": "Kiwaidae", "year": 2005, "genera": ["Kiwa"]}]}}

Euphausiacea: {"krill": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Arthropoda", "subphylum": "Crustacea", "order": "Euphausiacea", "families": ["Euphausiidae", "Bentheuphausiidae"]}, "description": "Krill are small and exclusively marine crustaceans of the order Euphausiacea, found in all the world's oceans.", "importance": "Krill are considered an important trophic level connection at the bottom of the food chain, serving as the main food source for many larger animals including whales, seals, penguins, seabirds, squid, and fish.", "distribution": "Krill occur worldwide in all oceans, with many individual species having endemic or neritic distributions.", "feeding": "Krill are filter feeders, feeding primarily on phytoplankton, particularly diatoms. They are mostly omnivorous, but some species are carnivorous, preying on small zooplankton and fish larvae.", "predation": "Krill are preyed upon by various animals including fish, penguins, seals, and baleen whales.", "human_uses": {"commercial_harvesting": "Krill are fished in the Southern Ocean and in the waters around Japan, with the majority of the catch used for aquaculture and aquarium feeds, bait in sport fishing, or in the pharmaceutical industry. They are also used for human consumption in Japan, the Philippines, and Russia, as well as in traditional dishes such as camarones in Spain and Philippines."}, "anatomy": {"physical_characteristics": "Krill are decapod crustaceans with a chitinous external skeleton, compound eyes, two antennae, and several pairs of thoracic legs. They also possess bioluminescent organs called photophores.", "size": "Most krill are about 1\u20132 centimetres (0.4\u20130.8 in) long as adults, with some species growing to sizes of 6\u201315 centimetres (2.4\u20135.9 in)."}, "life_history": {"lifecycle": "Krill hatch and go through several larval stages before reaching maturity, and they reproduce by spawning fertilized eggs into the water or carrying the eggs attached to the female.", "reproduction": "During the mating season, the male deposits a sperm sack at the female's genital opening, and females can carry several thousand eggs in their ovary."}, "behavior": {"swarming": "Most krill are swarming animals, with swarms varying in size and density by species and region, serving as a defensive mechanism against predators.", "migrations": "Krill typically follow a diurnal vertical migration, spending the day at greater depths and rising during the night toward the surface."}, "ecology": {"predation_impact": "Disturbances in the krill population can have far-reaching effects on the ecosystem, as demonstrated by a decline in krill population leading to cascading impacts on other species."}, "biogeochemical_cycles": "Antarctic krill play a prominent role in the Southern Ocean by cycling nutrients and serving as a key element in the Antarctic food web.", "human_impact": {"harvesting": "Krill have been harvested for human and domesticated animal consumption since the 19th century, with large-scale fishing operations developing in the late 1960s. The total fishing yield has increased, with major countries involved in harvesting including Norway, the Republic of Korea, and China."}, "bio_inspired_robotics": "Krill have inspired robotic platforms to study their locomotion and find design solutions for underwater robots."}}

Fritillaria: {"name": "Fritillaria", "scientificName": "Fritillaria", "family": "Liliaceae", "genusDescription": "Fritillaria is a genus of perennial herbaceous bulbiferous geophytes in the lily family (Liliaceae), characterized by nodding flowers, perianths campanulate with nectarial pits at the base of the tepal, large genome size, and close genetic relation to lilies. The flowers are usually pollinated by wasps or bumblebees.", "toxicity": "Most fritillaries contain poisonous steroidal alkaloids, and some species may even be deadly if ingested in quantity."}, "distribution": {"habitat": "Found in most temperate zones of the Northern Hemisphere, with centres of diversity in Turkey and the Zagros Mountains of Iran. They are usually grown from dormant bulbs planted in Autumn.", "traditionalMedicine": "Many species of Fritillaria have been used in traditional Chinese medicine for over 2,000 years and are of significant commercial value, although over-harvesting has led to endangerment."}, "conservation": "A number of Fritillaria species are endangered due to over-harvesting, habitat fragmentation, over-grazing, and international demand for herbals."}

Gobiidae: {"Gobiidae": {"taxonomy": {"phylum": "Chordata", "class": "Actinopterygii", "order": "Gobiiformes", "family": "Gobiidae"}, "description": "Gobiidae is a family of bony fish with more than 2,000 species in over 200 genera. Most gobiid fish are small, with some of the smallest vertebrates in the world. They are important as prey species for commercially important fish and are also popular as aquarium fish. Their distinctive feature is the fused pelvic fins that form a disc-shaped sucker, allowing them to adhere to rocks, corals, and aquarium surfaces.", "distributionAndHabitat": {"distribution": "Gobiidae are found in tropical and temperate near shore-marine, brackish, and freshwater environments worldwide.", "habitat": "Gobies are primarily bottom-dwellers, living in burrows, caves, coral reefs, and seagrass meadows."}, "subfamilies": {"Benthophilinae": {"description": "Endemic to the Ponto-Caspian region, these gobies have fused pelvic fins and elongated dorsal and anal fins. Examples include tadpole gobies, monkey gobies, and bighead gobies."}, "Gobiinae": {"description": "Known as true gobies, this subfamily is the most widespread and diverse among gobiids, containing around 2000 species and 150 genera."}}, "ecologyAndBiology": {"feedingHabits": "Most gobies feed on small invertebrates, while larger species may eat other fish or planktonic algae.", "reproduction": "Gobiids attach their eggs to a substrate, with the male guarding and fanning the eggs until they hatch. Some species are adapted to freshwater environments, and larvae may be carried downstream to brackish waters or the sea."}, "behavior": {"burrowConstruction": "Many gobiids live in male-female pairs and construct burrows for shelter and spawning. Burrow maintenance is a cooperative behavior, with males primarily caring for the eggs.", "kleptogamy": "Some male gobies exhibit sneaking behavior during reproduction, fertilizing eggs of paired females while the paired male cares for the eggs.", "sexChange": "Certain gobiid species can change their sexes, often from female to male, depending on the group dynamics and mating opportunities.", "navigation": "Some gobiids can remember landmarks within short distances and use them for navigation in their habitats."}, "symbiosis": {"withBurrowingShrimps": "Gobiids have symbiotic relationships with burrowing shrimps, where both parties benefit from the association.", "withLargerFish": "Some gobiids act as cleaner fish, removing parasites from the skin, fins, mouth, and gills of larger fish, benefiting from a continuous food supply."}, "commercialImportance": {"fishing": "Gobiids have commercial importance in Russia, Ukraine, and Italy, especially species like round goby, monkey goby, toad goby, and grass goby.", "aquariumTrade": "Several gobiid species are kept in aquariums, with popular marine species including Randall's shrimp goby and the neon goby."}}}
Gonatidae: {"Gonatidae": {"common_name": "Armhook squid", "description": "The Gonatidae, also known as armhook squid, are a family of moderately sized squid. The family contains about 19 species in three genera, widely distributed and plentiful in cold boreal waters of the Pacific Ocean. They are pelagic and associated with the continental shelf, and may roam as deep as 4,500 m or more, depending on the species.", "morphology": {"characteristics": "Armhook squid are characterized by the suckers of their arms, which are arranged in four rows (series) rather than the typical count of two. In most species, the arm's two mesial rows of suckers have been modified into hooks, and the tentacular clubs possess an enlarged central hook, with or without several smaller hooks. Species of the genus Gonatus lack tentacles as adults. The fiery armhook squid (Gonatus pyros) is the only species that possesses photophores located on the ventral periphery of the eyes. They have muscular, cylindrical bodies with very soft, reddish to purplish-brown skin. The arms are thick and capable, and the fins vary in shape and size.", "size": "These squid range in size from 11 to 40 cm, with most species being 25 cm or less. Females are somewhat larger than males."}, "lifecycle": {"habitat": "These squid are thought to undertake diel migration, staying in the depths by day and ascending to the upper layers of the water column by night to feed.", "reproduction": "Little is known about the reproductive cycle of armhook squid. Most species deposit eggs on the sea floor, then leave the eggs to hatch on their own. Some species, like Gonatus onyx, have been observed dragging a membrane sack containing developing eggs."}, "predators": "Cetaceans, large seabirds, seals, and large fish are known predators of armhook squid. Cannibalism also occurs within the family."}, "species": {"Berryteuthis": {"species": ["Berryteuthis anonychus", "Berryteuthis magister"]}, "Gonatopsis": {"subgenus": {"Boreoteuthis": "Gonatopsis borealis", "Gonatopsis": ["Gonatopsis japonicus", "Gonatopsis makko", "Gonatopsis octopedatus", "Gonatopsis okutanii"]}}, "Gonatus": {"species": ["Gonatus antarcticus", "Gonatus berryi", "Gonatus californiensis", "Gonatus fabricii", "Gonatus kamtschaticus", "Gonatus madokai", "Gonatus onyx", "Gonatus oregonensis", "Gonatus pyros", "Gonatus steenstrupi", "Gonatus ursabrunae"]}}}

Gonatus onyx: {"GonatusOnyx": {"scientificName": "Gonatus onyx", "commonNames": ["Clawed arm hook squid", "Black-eyed squid"], "taxonomy": {"class": "Cephalopoda", "phylum": "Mollusca", "family": "Gonatidae"}, "description": "The Gonatus Onyx, also known as the Clawed arm hook squid or the Black-eyed squid, is a smaller-sized squid with a characteristic black eye and two arms with clawed hooks. Goniasteridae: {"Goniasteridae": {"scientificName": "Goniasteridae", "commonName": "Biscuit stars", "order": "Valvatida", "description": "Goniasteridae are middle-sized sea stars with a characteristic double range of marginal plates bordering the disk and arms. Gorgonocephalus eucnemis: {"Gorgonocephalus eucnemis": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Echinodermata", "class": "Ophiuroidea", "order": "Phrynophiurida", "family": "Gorgonocephalidae", "genus": "Gorgonocephalus", "species": "Gorgonocephalus eucnemis"}, "description": {"size": "Central disc up to 14 cm (5.5 in) across, with five pairs of arms branching into smaller subdivisions", "color": "Varies in shades of white and beige, often with a darker disc", "characteristics": "Endoskeleton of calcified ossicles, covered in a fleshy layer of skin giving it a rubbery appearance, arms are covered in tiny hooks and spines"}, "distributionAndHabitat": {"habitat": "Rocky areas with strong currents, mud and sandy seabeds among boulders, sea pens, and sea fans", "depth": "Ranges from 15 to 150 m (49 to 492 ft), with a maximum depth of 2,000 m (6,600 ft)", "locations": "Arctic Ocean, northern parts of the Atlantic Ocean, Bering Sea, Japan, Laguna Beach, California"}, "biology": {"feeding": "Perches in an elevated position and extends its arms in a net-like fashion perpendicular to the current to trap small crustaceans, copepods, chaetognaths, jellyfish, and detritus", "reproduction": "Individuals are either male or female, larvae become part of plankton and disperse with the currents after spawning"}, "ecology": {"behavior": "Cryptic and well hidden during the day, returns to specific location regularly, often found living in association with sponges and soft corals", "predators": "Eaten by fish and crabs"}}}

Grimalditeuthis: {"Grimalditeuthis bonplandi": {"scientificName": "Grimalditeuthis bonplandi", "commonName": "None", "namedAfter": "Grimaldi family, Monaco", "discoveredBy": "Prince Albert I of Monaco", "discoveryYear": "First observed alive in 2005", "bioluminescent": true, "distribution": "Mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones worldwide, depths of 200\u20131500 m", "morphology": {"maxMantleLength": "25 cm", "distinctFeatures": ["Longer neck and different body and fin shape compared to Chiroteuthidae", "Fused mantle locking apparatus", "Bioluminescent with photophores only in the tips of female squid's tentacles"]}, "behavior": {"aggressiveMimicry": {"description": "Lures prey by mimicking a harmless squid with the tips of its tentacles, then quickly snatching fooled prey into its death", "example": "Intact tentacles suspected to be from this species found inside the longnose lancetfish"}}, "references": [{"title": "CephBase: Grimalditeuthis", "url": "https://web.archive.org/web/20050817090732/http://www.cephbase.utmb.edu/spdb/animal_detail.cfm?scientific=Grimalditeuthis%20bonplandi"}, {"title": "Tree of Life web project: Grimalditeuthis bonplandi", "url": "http://tolweb.org/Grimalditeuthis_bonplandi"}]}}

Grimpoteuthis: {"Grimpoteuthis": {"type": "Genus", "commonName": "Dumbo octopuses", "description": "Grimpoteuthis is a genus of pelagic cirrate (finned) octopods known as dumbo octopuses. They are named after the title character of Disney's 1941 film Dumbo due to their resemblance to it, with prominent ear-like fins above each eye. The genus encompasses 17 recognized species.", "speciesAndTaxonomy": {"speciesCount": 17, "taxonomicHistory": "Several species formerly classified as Grimpoteuthis were moved to genera Cirroctopus and Opisthoteuthis. A new family, Grimpoteuthididae, has been proposed to accommodate Grimpoteuthis and those of genera Enigmatiteuthis, Cryptoteuthis, and Luteuthis due to persistent confusion and disparity about the taxonomy of these species."}, "rangeAndHabitat": {"distribution": "Worldwide, living in the cold, abyssal depths ranging from 1,000 to 7,000 meters. Specimens have been found off the coasts of Oregon, the Philippines, Martha's Vineyard, the Azores, New Zealand, Australia, California, Gulf of Mexico, Papua, and New Guinea.", "recentObservations": [{"date": "21 June 2022", "depth": "1250 meters", "location": "Normand Ocean, Tr\u00f8ndelag, Norway"}, {"date": "24 May 2023", "depth": "2108 meters", "location": "Far Samson, Guyana"}], "depthRecord": "Spotted 6,957 meters deep in the Java Trench, confirming the hadal distribution of this genus."}, "threats": {"humanThreats": "Few direct threats from humans due to their habitat below 1,000 meters. Natural predators include large teleost fish, sharks, marine mammals such as sperm whales and seals."}, "movementAndBehaviour": {"movementPatterns": "Rest on the seafloor with arms and web spread out, crawl along the seafloor, use mantle fins for rapid locomotion. Capable of jet-propulsion.", "feedingBehavior": "Trap small prey items in the webbing and use cirri to move food to the mouth. Known prey items include benthic polychaetes, benthopelagic copepods, amphipods, and isopods."}, "reproduction": {"spawning": "Continuous spawners with no seasonality in spawning, multiple eggs carried by females, no observed mating behavior, tough casing surrounding the chorion of eggs, eggs attached to deep sea corals, hatchlings emerge as fully competent juveniles."}}}
Gymnosarda unicolor: {"name": "Dogtooth Tuna", "scientificName": "Gymnosarda unicolor", "commonNames": ["White Tuna"], "family": "Scombridae", "description": {"size": {"male": {"length": "190-248 cm", "weight": "130 kg"}, "average": {"length": "40-120 cm"}}, "physicalCharacteristics": {"dorsalSoftRays": "12-14", "analSoftRays": "12-13", "coloration": "brilliant blue green on the back, silvery on the side, and whitish on the belly with two white tips on the back fins"}}, "distribution": "Tropical waters of the Indo-Pacific area from the eastern coast of Africa to French Polynesia and oceanic islands of the Pacific Ocean, excluding Hawaii, and extending north to Japan and south to Australia.", "ecology": {"habitat": "Reef environments, seamounts, and steep underwater walls at depths of 10-300 meters", "diet": "Small schooling fishes, squids, pelagic schooling fish found near reef habitat"}, "predators": ["Giant Trevally", "Napoleon Wrasse", "Large Groupers", "Reef Sharks", "Bull Sharks", "Tiger Sharks"], "longevity": "Preliminary estimates suggest a maximum observed age of at least 20 years", "fishing": {"market": "Canned and frozen", "foodUse": "Appreciated as a fine food fish", "sportFishing": "Highly sought after by rod and reel anglers and spearfishermen, particularly in European and Asian regions", "fishingTechniques": ["Trolling with dead and live baits or with lures", "High speed jigging", "Teasing with live bait"]}, "references": ["Integrated Taxonomic Information System", "Photos of Dogtooth tuna on Sealife Collection"]}
Gymnosomata: {"seaAngels": {"description": "Sea angels are small free-swimming sea slugs classified into six different families within the clade Gymnosomata. They are pelagic opisthobranchs in the mollusc clade Heterobranchia, with a geographic range from polar regions to equatorial seas.", "anatomy": {"adaptations": "The foot has developed into wing-like flapping appendages, and they discard their embryonic shells a few days after hatching. Their lack of a heavy shell allows them to hover and maneuver more efficiently."}, "behavior": {"diet": "Sea angels are carnivorous, feeding on their fellow pteropods, the Thecosomata, and their hunting strategies vary from ambush predation to active pursuit. They use their wing-like parapodia to propel through the water column."}, "reproduction": {"reproductiveSystem": "They are simultaneous hermaphrodites with internal fertilization. After fertilization, they release gelatinous egg masses, and their embryonic shells are lost within a few days after hatching."}, "taxonomy": {"classification": "Sea angels are a clade within the order Pteropoda, arranged under the superfamily Clionoidea and superfamily Hydromyloidea."}}}

Haliphron atlanticus: {"sevenArmOctopus": {"scientificName": "Haliphron atlanticus", "commonNames": ["seven-arm octopus", "blob octopus", "septopus"], "description": "The seven-arm octopus, Haliphron atlanticus, is one of the largest known species of octopus. Haliscera bigelowi: {"Haliscera bigelowi": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Cnidaria", "class": "Hydrozoa", "order": "Anthoathecata", "family": "Halicreatidae", "genus": "Haliscera", "species": "bigelowi"}, "description": "Haliscera bigelowi is a species of deep sea hydrozoan of the family Halicreatidae. The umbrella is 15\u201317 mm wide, 9\u201310 mm high, almost hemispherical, with very thick, hemispherical apex. Adults have about 96 marginal tentacles, about 12 marginal tentacles and 3 statocysts in each octant, and thickening of marginal cnidocyst tissue less pronounced than in H. conica. The gonads are broadly oval, about 2/5 as long as radial canals, and located slightly nearer manubrium than bell margin."}}
Haliscera conica: {"Haliscera conica": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Cnidaria", "class": "Hydrozoa", "order": "Leptomedusae", "family": "Halicreatidae", "genus": "Haliscera", "species": "Haliscera conica"}, "description": "Umbrella up to 18 mm, with very thick, bluntly conical projection; 64-72 marginal tentacles in adults; 8-9 tentacles and 2 statocysts in each octant; the base of tentacles surrounded by broad thickening of marginal cnidocyst tissue; gonads oval, well separated from manubrium in the middle portion of 8 broad radial canals."}}

Halosauridae: {"Halosaurs": {"description": "Halosaurs are eel-shaped fishes found only at great ocean depths. Hexactinellida: {"hexactinellidSponges": {"scientificName": "Hexactinellida", "phylum": "Porifera", "class": "Hexactinellida", "subclasses": {"Amphidiscophora": {"orders": ["Amphidiscosida", "Hemidiscosa", "Reticulosa"]}, "Hexasterophora": {"incertaeSedis": "Dactylocalycidae", "orders": ["Lychniscosida", "Lyssacinosida", "Sceptrulophora"]}}}, "biology": {"habitat": "Found at depths from 450 to 900 metres (1,480 to 2,950 ft) below sea level, particularly common in Antarctic and Northern Pacific waters", "size": "Ranges from 10 to 30 centimetres (3.9 to 11.8 in) in height, with some species growing up to 1 meter long", "color": "Generally pale, ranging from white to orange", "uniqueFeatures": ["Relatively symmetrical, cup-shaped animals with sturdy skeletons made of glass-like silica spicules fused to form a lattice", "Body comprises three parts: inner and outer peripheral trabecular networks and the choanosome, used for feeding purposes", "Possess a unique system for rapidly conducting electrical impulses across their bodies, enabling quick response to external stimuli"]}, "reefs": {"formation": "Capable of fusing together to create reefs or bioherms", "locations": ["Off the coast of British Columbia, southeast Alaska, Washington state, Antarctic, Northern Pacific waters"], "discoveries": {"HecateStrait": {"size": "Up to 7 kilometres long and 20 metres high", "previousBelief": "Thought to have died out in the Jurassic period"}}}, "conservation": {"threats": ["Climate change, increased temperature, acidification"], "conservationEfforts": {"CanadianGovernment": "Designated 2140 km\u00b2 of the Hecate strait and Queen Charlotte sound as a marine protected area", "regulations": "Prohibit bottom contact fishing within 200 meters of the sponge reefs"}}, "age": {"longevity": "Tentatively estimated to live up to 15,000 years, possibly the longest-lived animals on earth", "oldestSpecimen": "Estimated age of a specimen of Scolymastra joubini as 23,000 years"}}

Hexatrygon bickelli: {"sixgillStingray": {"scientificName": "Hexatrygon bickelli", "family": "Hexatrygonidae", "description": "The sixgill stingray is a flabby, heavy-bodied fish with a unique trait of having six pairs of gill slits rather than the typical five. It has a rounded pectoral fin disc, a long, triangular, and flexible snout filled with gelatinous substance, and lacks dermal denticles. It grows up to 1.7 m (5.6 ft) long, with a brownish upper body and white underside.", "habitat": "Benthic in nature, the sixgill stingray is found over upper continental slopes and seamounts at depths of 500\u20131,120 m (1,640\u20133,670 ft) in scattered locations across the Indo-Pacific from South Africa to Hawaii.", "taxonomy": {"discovery": "Discovered and described as a new species in 1980 by Phillip Heemstra and Margaret Smith, who placed it in its own family (Hexatrygonidae).", "speciesVariation": "Although several species of sixgill stingrays have been historically described, current evidence suggests they may represent variations in a single, widespread species.", "phylogeny": "Phylogenetic studies using morphological and genetic data have shown that the sixgill stingray is the most basal member of the stingray lineage."}, "physicalCharacteristics": {"body": "Bulky, flabby body with a rounded pectoral fin disc that is longer than wide.", "snout": "Triangular snout filled with a clear gelatinous material, with tiny eyes placed far apart and well ahead of the spiracles.", "gillSlits": "Six pairs of gill slits on the underside of the disc, while most other rays have five pairs.", "coloration": "Purplish to pinkish brown above, darkening slightly at the fin margins with white underside and delicate, lacking dermal denticles."}, "distribution": {"range": "Recorded at scattered locations in the Indo-Pacific from South Africa to Hawaii, including the Indian Ocean and the Pacific Ocean.", "habitat": "Inhabits upper continental slopes and seamounts at depths of 500\u20131,120 m (1,640\u20133,670 ft), occasionally venturing into shallower water."}, "biology": {"feedingBehavior": "Uses its flexible snout to probe for food in the bottom sediment, with jaws capable of capturing buried prey. Poorly mineralized jaws suggest it does not feed on hard-shelled animals.", "reproduction": "Viviparous with litter sizes ranging from two to five pups, with both males and females maturing sexually at around 1.1 m (3.6 ft) long."}, "conservation": {"status": "Listed as Least Concern by the IUCN due to minimal fishing pressure across most of its range.", "threats": "Caught in small numbers as bycatch in bottom trawls in some areas, with concerns about potential local overfishing."}}}
Hippasteria: {"Hippasteria": {"genus": "Sea star", "family": "Goniasteridae", "description": "Hippasteria is one of 70 genera of sea stars in the diverse family Goniasteridae. These sea stars are regular, five-armed starfishes, with a large and flattened central disc. Hippasteria muscipula: {"hippasteriaMuscipula": {"name": "Hippasteria muscipula", "description": "Hippasteria muscipula is a deep-sea sea star in the genus Hippasteria, family Goniasteridae. It is a regular, five-armed sea star with a large and flattened central disc. The body is covered by short and stout spines, and it is characterized by big, fly-trap like pedicellariae. It is a rather big species, growing up to 30 cm across. It is a predator of deep sea coral and other cnidarians, observed climbing on corals in order to feed. The species was unknown to science until 2014 and has been observed in the depths of the Pacific Ocean, in locations such as Hawaii, New Caledonia, and New Zealand, between 425 and 1500 meters deep.", "habitat": "This species lives in the depths of Pacific Ocean, and has been recorded in Hawaii, New Caledonia, and New Zealand, between 425 and 1500 meters deep.", "bibliography": "Mah, Christopher L.; Neill, K.; El\u00e9aume, Marc; Foltz, D. (2014). 'New Species and global revision of Hippasteria (Hippasterinae: Goniasteridae; Asteroidea; Echinodermata)'. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society. 171 (2): 422\u2013456. doi:10.1111/zoj.12131."}}
Hirudinea: {"name": "Leeches", "taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Annelida", "subphylum": "Clitellata", "class": "Hirudinea"}, "description": "Leeches are segmented parasitic or predatory worms that comprise the subclass Hirudinea within the phylum Annelida. They are closely related to the oligochaetes, which include the earthworm, and like them, have soft, muscular segmented bodies that can lengthen and contract.", "habitats": {"freshwater": "The majority of leeches live in freshwater habitats.", "terrestrial": "Some species can be found in terrestrial environments.", "marine": "Around 100 leech species are marine."}, "feeding_behavior": {"hematophagous": "Best-known species feed on blood, such as the medicinal leech Hirudo medicinalis, which secretes the peptide hirudin to prevent blood clotting.", "predatory": "A minority of leech species are predatory, mostly preying on small invertebrates."}, "reproduction": {"cocoon_enclosure": "Eggs are enclosed in cocoons, usually attached to an underwater surface for aquatic species, or concealed under logs or buried in damp soil for terrestrial species. Some species exhibit parental care by brooding the eggs or carrying the young."}, "diversity": {"total_species": 680, "marine": 100, "freshwater": 480, "terrestrial": 100}, "medical_use": {"historical": "Leeches have been used in medicine from ancient times until the 19th century for bloodletting and are still used in modern medicine for treating joint diseases, extremity vein diseases, and in microsurgery. Hirudin, a component of leech saliva, is used as an anticoagulant drug to treat blood-clotting disorders."}, "evolution": {"oldest_fossils": "The oldest leech fossils are from the middle Permian period around 266 million years ago."}, "anatomy": {"morphology": "Leeches have segmented bodies with suckers at both ends, muscular body walls, and reduced coelomic cavities.", "reproductive_organs": "Leeches are hermaphrodites, with female gonopores, nine pairs of testes, and other reproductive organs."}, "nervous_system": {"sensory_organs": "Leeches have pigment spot ocelli, sensory papillae, and can detect touch, vibration, movement, and chemicals secreted by their hosts."}, "interaction_with_humans": {"bites": "Leech bites are generally alarming rather than dangerous, though a small percentage of people have severe allergic or anaphylactic reactions. Leeches have been historically used for bloodletting and are still used in modern medicine.", "water_pollution": "Exposure to synthetic estrogen from contraceptive medicines in freshwater ecosystems can affect leeches' reproductive systems."}}

Histioteuthis: {"Histioteuthis": {"scientificName": "Histioteuthis", "commonName": "Cock-eyed squid", "description": "Histioteuthis is a genus of squid in the family Histioteuthidae known for its unique eye structure, with one eye being normal-sized, round, blue and sunken, and the other being at least twice the diameter, tubular, yellow-green, upward facing, and bulging out of the head. The genus contains bioluminescent species and has several species groups and subspecies.", "characteristics": {"eyeStructure": {"normalEye": "Round, blue, sunken", "abnormalEye": "At least twice the diameter, tubular, yellow-green, upward facing, bulging out of the head"}}, "behavior": "Histioteuthis uses its larger eye to see ambient sunlight and its smaller eye to detect bioluminescence from prey animals.", "etymology": {"nameOrigin": "The name is composed of the Greek histion (\u1f31\u03c3\u03c4\u03af\u03bf\u03bd, 'sail', a large webbed membrane between six of the arms, in some species) and teuthis ('squid')."}, "species": [{"groupName": "H. bonnellii species-group", "speciesList": ["Histioteuthis bonnellii (Umbrella squid)", "Histioteuthis machrohista"]}, {"groupName": "H. reversa species-group", "speciesList": ["Histioteuthis eltaninae", "Histioteuthis atlantica", "Histioteuthis reversa (Reverse jewel squid)"]}, {"groupName": "H. celetaria subspecies-group", "speciesList": ["Histioteuthis celetaria celetaria", "Histioteuthis celetaria pacifica"]}, {"groupName": "H. corona subspecies-group", "speciesList": ["Histioteuthis corona berryi", "Histioteuthis corona cerasina", "Histioteuthis corona corona", "Histioteuthis corona inermis"]}, {"groupName": "H. miranda species-group", "speciesList": ["Histioteuthis miranda", "Histioteuthis oceani"]}, {"groupName": "H. meleagroteuthis species-group", "speciesList": ["Histioteuthis heteropsis (Strawberry squid)", "Histioteuthis meleagroteuthis"]}], "sources": [{"title": "CephBase: Histioteuthis", "url": "http://www.cephbase.utmb.edu/refdb/refdb_search.php/1239"}, {"title": "Histioteuthidae discussion forum at TONMO.com", "url": "https://www.tonmo.com/forums/histioteuthidae.14/"}]}}
Histioteuthis heteropsis: {"Histioteuthis heteropsis": {"commonName": "strawberry squid", "scientificName": "Histioteuthis heteropsis", "description": "Histioteuthis heteropsis, also known as the strawberry squid, is a species of small cock-eyed squid. The scientific nomenclature of these squid stems from their set of differently sized eyes, one being small and blue and the other being large and yellow. It is thought that the large eye is used to see objects against dim light, while the smaller eye is more able to view bioluminescent light sources. The squid's vernacular name arose due to its rich red skin pigmentation and the presence of photophores along its body, making it appear like a strawberry with seeds.", "habitat": {"depth": "200-1000 meters", "location": "California Current, Humboldt Current, Pacific Ocean", "migration": "diurnal vertical migration"}, "behavior": {"feeding": "visual clues and tentacle strikes", "mating": "poorly understood, likely in deeper waters", "inking": "only when provoked"}, "taxonomy": {"discoveredBy": "Berry", "relatedSpecies": ["Histioteuthis meleagroteuthis", "Histioteuthis bonnellii"]}, "conservationStatus": "least concern", "furtherReading": ["Belman, Bruce W (1978). Respiration and the effects of pressure on the mesopelagic vertically migrating squid Histioteuthis heteropsis. Limnology and Oceanography. 23 (4): 735-9.", "CephBase: Histioteuthis heteropsis"]}}

Gastropoda: {"name": "Gastropods", "taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Mollusca", "class": "Gastropoda"}, "description": "Gastropods, commonly known as slugs and snails, belong to a large taxonomic class of invertebrates within the phylum Mollusca called Gastropoda. This class comprises snails and slugs from saltwater, freshwater, and from the land. The class Gastropoda is highly diverse and successful, containing a vast total of named species, second only to the insects in overall number. The anatomy, behavior, feeding, and reproductive adaptations of gastropods vary significantly from one clade or group to another, so stating many generalities for all gastropods is difficult.", "habitats": ["Gardens", "Woodlands", "Deserts", "Mountains", "Small ditches", "Great rivers", "Lakes", "Estuaries", "Mudflats", "Rocky intertidal zones", "Sandy subtidal zones", "Abyssal depths of the oceans", "Hydrothermal vents", "Parasitic habitats"], "anatomy": {"distinctive_feature": "Torsion, where the visceral mass of the animal rotates 180\u00b0 to one side during development, leading to asymmetrical growth", "shell": {"description": "Most shelled gastropods have a one piece shell, typically coiled or spiraled, with some species having operculum acting as a trapdoor", "exceptions": ["Land slugs have reduced or absent shells", "Some species have adult shells that are bottom heavy"]}, "sensory_organs": {"types": ["Olfactory organs", "Eyes", "Statocysts", "Mechanoreceptors"]}, "reproductive_system": {"types": ["Separate sexes (dioecious/gonochoric)", "Hermaphrodites"], "notable_feature": "Land snails have the presence and utilization of love darts"}}, "feeding_behavior": {"types": ["Herbivores", "Detritus feeders", "Predatory carnivores", "Scavengers", "Parasites", "Ciliary feeders"]}, "conservation": {"threats": ["Habitat destruction", "Pollution", "Climate change"], "efforts": "Conservation efforts often focus on protecting their habitats, especially in freshwater and terrestrial ecosystems"}}

Homolidae: {"Homolidae": {"common_name": "Carrier crabs or porter crabs", "description": "The family Homolidae contains 14 genera of marine crabs. They mostly live on the continental slope and continental shelf and are rarely encountered. Members of the Homolidae have their fifth pereiopods (last pair of walking legs) in a sub-dorsal position, which allows them to hold objects in place over the rear half of the carapace. The objects carried include sponges, black corals, and gorgonians, and this behavior may be a defense mechanism against predators. Some species have been observed carrying living sea urchins in a symbiotic relationship which allows them to benefit from the protection of the urchin's dangerous spikes.", "habitats": "Continental slope and continental shelf", "genera": ["Dagnaudus", "Gordonopsis", "Homola", "Homolax", "Homolochunia", "Homologenus", "Homolomannia", "Ihlopsis", "Lamoha", "Latreillopsis", "Moloha", "Paromola", "Paromolopsis", "Yaldwynopsis"]}, "Homolidae_genera": [{"name": "Dagnaudus", "authors": "Guinot & Richer de Forges", "year": 1995}, {"name": "Gordonopsis", "authors": "Guinot & Richer de Forges", "year": 1995}, {"name": "Homola", "authors": "Leach", "year": 1816}, {"name": "Homolax", "authors": "Alcock", "year": 1899}, {"name": "Homolochunia", "authors": "Doflein", "year": 1904}, {"name": "Homologenus", "authors": "A.
