Hydrolagus colliei: {"name": "Spotted Ratfish", "scientificName": "Hydrolagus colliei", "description": "The spotted ratfish is a chimaera found in the northeastern Pacific Ocean, known for its distinct appearance, pointed rat-like tail, and large emerald green eyes. It is a cartilaginous fish with a smooth and scaleless silvery-bronze skin, speckled with white spots, and large, triangular pectoral fins. It has a venomous spine and is supported by cartilage rather than bone.", "distributionAndHabitat": {"habitat": "The spotted ratfish can be found in the northeastern Pacific Ocean, ranging from Alaska to Baja California, with an isolated population in the Gulf of California. It is most commonly found off the Pacific Northwest and lives near the sea floor in sandy, muddy, or rocky reef environments. It can be found at depths ranging from 0 to 913 m (0 to 2,995 ft) below sea level.", "depth": "It is most common between 50 and 400 m (160 and 1,310 ft) and tends to move closer to shallow water during the spring and autumn, then to deeper water in summer and winter. It prefers temperatures between 7.2 and 8.9 \u00b0C (45 and 48 \u00b0F), but can move into slightly warmer water seasonally."}, "diet": "The spotted ratfish feeds on crunchy foods such as crabs and clams, as well as shrimp, worms, small fish, small crustaceans, and sea stars. It swims slowly above the sea floor in search of food and typically hunts at night.", "reproduction": {"reproductiveMethod": "Oviparous", "spawningSeason": "The spawning season peaks during the spring to autumn, and the female releases up to two fertilized eggs into sand or mud areas of the seabed every 10\u201314 days. The egg sack is leather-like, 12.7 cm (5.0 in) long, connected to a filament, and development can take up to a year."}, "behavior": "The ratfish prefers to maintain a safe distance from divers and is usually not aggressive. It can inflict a mildly toxic wound with its dorsal fin spines when it feels threatened. The fish is known for performing barrel rolls and corkscrew turns as it swims, using its large pectoral fins.", "specialCharacteristic": "A rare albino Puget Sound ratfish was discovered near Whidbey Island, Washington. It is the only pure albino among the 7.2 million specimens in the University of Washington's fish collection."}
Hydrolagus melanophasma: {"Hydrolagus melanophasma": {"scientificName": "Hydrolagus melanophasma", "commonName": "Eastern Pacific black ghostshark", "family": "Chimaeridae", "classification": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Chordata", "class": "Chondrichthyes", "order": "Chimaeriformes", "family": "Chimaeridae", "genus": "Hydrolagus"}, "description": "The Eastern Pacific black ghostshark, or Hydrolagus melanophasma, is a species of fish in the family Chimaeridae. Despite its name, it does not belong to the clade Selachii used for the modern classification of sharks. It is, however, distantly related to the sharks in the sense that both are Chondrichthyes (cartilaginous fishes).", "sources": [{"title": "The Eastern Pacific Black Ghost Shark", "author": "Greg Laden", "publication": "smithsonian.com", "date": "2009-9-28", "url": "https://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/the-eastern-pacific-black-ghost-shark-57280652/"}, {"title": "Weird New Ghostshark Found; Male Has Sex Organ on Head", "author": "Christine Dell'Amore", "publication": "National Geographic News", "date": "2009-9-22", "url": "https://www.nationalgeographic.com/news/2009/9/290922-new-ghostshark-species-male-organ-head/"}, {"title": "Hydrolagus melanophasma", "url": "http://www.fishbase.se/summary/Hydrolagus-melanophasma.html"}]}}

Liparidae: {"snailfish": {"scientificName": "Liparidae", "commonName": "Snailfish", "description": "The snailfish family, Liparidae, is a diverse group of marine ray-finned fishes with elongated, tadpole-like shape, large heads, small eyes, slender bodies, and small tails.", "habitat": {"range": "Arctic to Antarctic Oceans, including the oceans in between", "depth": "Shallow coastal waters to more than 8,300 m (27,200 ft)"}, "taxonomy": {"order": "Scorpaeniformes", "superfamily": "Cyclopteroidea", "classifications": {"American biologist Theodore Gill": "First proposed the family Liparidae in 1861", "Fishes of the World (5th edition)": "Classifies Liparidae within superfamily Cyclopteroidea", "Osteological analysis": "Found Bathylutichthys to be intermediate between the Psychrolutidae and the Cyclopteroidea families"}}, "molecularBiology": {"adaptations": {"Yap hadal snailfish": "Loss of olfactory receptors, gain of taste receptors, and fewer copies of crystallin genes", "Mariana hadal snailfish": "Loss of several photoreceptor genes, decreased vision capabilities, and adjusted to pressure"}}, "reproduction": {"strategies": "Varies among species, with some species depositing eggs among cold-water corals, practicing mouth brooding, or parasitic egg laying"}, "depthRecord": {"deepestLivingSpecies": "Pseudoliparis swirei recorded at 8,076 m (26,496 ft)", "deepestRecordedDepth": "Unknown species filmed at a depth of 8,336 m (27,349 ft) in the Izu\u2013Ogasawara Trench", "commonality": "Snailfish are the most common and dominant fish family in the hadal zone"}, "diet": {"larvalStage": "Feed on plankton, copepods, and amphipods", "adults": "Prey on gammarid, krill, natantian decapods, other crustaceans, fish, and others"}, "imageURL": "https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Liparidae"}}

Lophiiformes: {"Anglerfish": {"order": "Lophiiformes", "characteristic_predation": "Anglerfish are named for their characteristic mode of predation, in which a modified luminescent fin ray (the esca or illicium) acts as a lure for other fish. The luminescence comes from symbiotic bacteria, which are thought to be acquired from seawater. Some anglerfish are notable for extreme sexual dimorphism and sexual symbiosis of the small male with the much larger female.", "habitat": "Anglerfish occur worldwide and can be pelagic (dwelling away from the sea floor) or benthic (dwelling close to the sea floor). Some live in the deep sea, while others live on the continental shelf.", "evolution": "The earliest fossils of anglerfish are from the Eocene Monte Bolca formation of Italy. They likely originated during the Cretaceous and diversified in a short period of the early to mid-Cretaceous, between 130 and 100 million years ago.", "classification": {"families": 18, "suborders": ["Lophiidae", "Antennariidae", "Tetrabrachiidae", "Brachionichthyidae", "Lophichthyidae", "Chaunacidae", "Ogcocephalidae", "Centrophrynidae", "Ceratiidae", "Himantolophidae", "Diceratiidae", "Melanocetidae", "Thaumatichthyidae", "Oneirodidae", "Caulophrynidae", "Neoceratiidae", "Gigantactinidae", "Linophrynidae"]}, "anatomy": {"carnivorous_adaptation": "Anglerfish are carnivorous and have large, crescent-shaped mouths full of long, fang-like teeth angled inward for efficient prey grabbing. They also have a unique flap (illicium) at the distal end of their body on their first dorsal fin, which acts as a luring mechanism where prey approach in a face-to-face manner.", "bioluminescence": "Most adult female ceratioid anglerfish have a luminescent organ called the esca at the tip of a modified dorsal ray, derived from Latin \u0113sca, meaning 'bait'. The luminescence comes from symbiotic bacteria dwelling in and around the esca."}, "behavior": {"swimming_and_energy_conservation": "Anglerfish exhibit lethargic behavior suited to the energy-poor environment of the deep sea. They also show burst swimming when approached by predators.", "predation": "Anglerfish use their bioluminescent esca to attract prey, and are opportunistic foragers with a range of preferred prey. They can also emit light from their esca to attract prey.", "reproduction": "Some anglerfish employ an unusual mating method involving sexual symbiosis and extreme sexual dimorphism. Males become dependent on the female host for survival by receiving nutrients via their shared circulatory system, and provide sperm to the female in return."}, "threats": "Northwest European Lophius species are heavily fished, and anglerfish are known to occasionally rise to the surface during El Ni\u00f1o, leaving large groups of dead anglerfish floating on the surface. They are also listed by Greenpeace International as being sourced from unsustainable fisheries.", "human_consumption": "Monkfish or goosefish is a commercially important anglerfish in western Europe, eastern North America, Africa, and East Asia. Anglerfish is heavily consumed in South Korea, where it is featured in dishes such as Agujjim.", "further_reading": ["Review of the deep-sea anglerfishes of Southern Africa", "Tree of Life web project: Lophiiformes", "Video - Anglerfish mating on YouTube", "New Scientist article: Anglerfish immune system"]}}

Macrouridae: {"Macrouridae": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Chordata", "class": "Actinopterygii", "order": "Gadiformes", "family": "Macrouridae"}, "description": "Macrouridae is a family of deep sea fish within the order Gadiformes. They are characterized by their large heads, slender bodies, and whip-like tails. They have two dorsal fins, a long anal fin, and small scales covering their bodies. Some species exhibit bioluminescence due to symbiotic bioluminescent bacteria. They are mainly benthopelagic and are found at depths of 200\u20132000 m, with a wide distribution from the Arctic to the Antarctic. They are weak swimmers and some species are of commercial importance to fisheries.", "habitat": "The species in the Macrouridae normally live near the sea bed on the continental slope. Some species are bathypelagic or mesopelagic, and others occur on the outer continental shelf.", "commercial_importance": true, "subfamilies": [{"name": "Bathygadinae", "genera_count": 2, "species_count": 26}, {"name": "Macrourinae", "genera_count": 28, "species_count": 370}, {"name": "Macrouroidinae", "genera_count": 2, "species_count": 1}, {"name": "Trachyrincinae", "genera_count": 2, "species_count": 7}]}}

second dorsal fin runs along the back and connects to the tail", "lateral line system": "Well-developed", "unique features": "Chemoreceptors on the head and lips, chemosensory barbels underneath the chin, swim bladders with unique muscles, and light-producing organs (photophores) present in some species"}, "behavior": {"depthRange": "From about 200 to 7,000 m", "socialBehavior": "May be solitary or form large schools", "feedingHabits": "Generalists, feeding on smaller fish, pelagic crustaceans, and occasionally cephalopods and lanternfish", "reproduction": "Eggs are made buoyant by lipid droplets and presumed to float up to the thermocline for development; Medusae: {"Jellyfish": {"Definition": "Jellyfish are medusa-phase members of the subphylum Medusozoa, which is a major part of the phylum Cnidaria. They are mainly free-swimming marine animals with umbrella-shaped bells and trailing tentacles.", "Characteristics": {"Anatomy": {"Description": "The main feature of a true jellyfish is the umbrella-shaped bell, which consists of a mass of transparent jelly-like matter known as mesoglea.", "Locomotion": "Jellyfish move through the water by radially expanding and contracting their bell-shaped bodies to push water behind them and create vortex rings for propulsion. They are considered the most energy-efficient swimmers of all animals."}, "Life Cycle": {"Description": "Jellyfish have a complex life cycle that includes sexual and asexual phases. They typically spawn, producing larvae that develop into polyps, which then reproduce asexually by budding and form ephyrae that detach and grow into adult medusae."}, "Largest and Smallest": {"Description": "Jellyfish range in size from about one millimeter to nearly 2 meters in bell height and diameter. The smallest jellyfish are the creeping jellyfish with bell disks from 0.5 millimeters to a few millimeters, while the lion's mane jellyfish is known as one of the largest."}}, "Habitats": {"Ecology": {"Diet": "Jellyfish are generally carnivorous, feeding on a variety of organisms including planktonic organisms, small fish, fish eggs, other jellyfish, and more. Some species have a symbiotic relationship with microalgae or host parasitic organisms.", "Predation": "Jellyfish are predated upon by a variety of marine animals including sea anemones, tunas, sharks, sea turtles, and penguins. However, they are also considered top predators in the food chain."}}, "Interaction with Humans": {"Stings": "Jellyfish are equipped with stinging cells and their stings can range from mild discomfort to extreme pain and even death. Contact with a jellyfish tentacle can trigger nematocysts to pierce the skin and inject venom. Vinegar and hydrocortisone cream are often used to alleviate the effects of stings.", "Products": "In some cultures, jellyfish are harvested for food and other purposes. They are used in traditional dishes, and their collagen has potential biotechnological applications.", "Fishing and Biotechnology": "Jellyfish are harvested in fisheries for export, and they have been studied for their applications in biotechnology, specifically the discovery of green fluorescent protein (GFP)."}, "Impacts": {"Blooms": "Jellyfish can form large masses or blooms under certain environmental conditions, often leading to ecological impacts such as competition with fish for food, impacting fish stocks, and causing harmful effects in industries and tourism."}, "Uses": {"Aquarium Display": "Jellyfish are displayed in public aquariums, and there is an emerging interest in keeping them in home aquariums.", "Biotechnology": "Jellyfish have been studied for their biotechnological applications, particularly in the discovery and use of green fluorescent protein (GFP) as a genetic marker."}}}

metal: {"metal": {"description": "A material that, when freshly prepared, polished, or fractured, shows a lustrous appearance, and conducts electricity and heat relatively well. Metals are typically ductile and malleable, and these properties are the result of the metallic bond between the atoms or molecules of the metal.", "properties": {"form_and_structure": "Metals are shiny and lustrous, with varying densities. They are typically malleable and ductile, deforming under stress without cleaving. The atoms of metallic substances are typically arranged in one of three common crystal structures: body-centered cubic (bcc), face-centered cubic (fcc), and hexagonal close-packed (hcp).", "electrical_and_thermal": "Metals are relatively good conductors of electricity and heat. The electronic structure of metals means they have fixed energy levels and correspond to the energy levels at which electrical conduction can occur. The contribution of a metal's electrons to its heat capacity and thermal conductivity, and the electrical conductivity of the metal itself can be calculated from the free electron model.", "chemical": "Metals are usually inclined to form cations through electron loss. Most will react with oxygen in the air to form oxides over various timescales. Painting, anodizing, or plating metals are good ways to prevent their corrosion.", "periodic_table_distribution": "Metals are found in yellow on the periodic table, while light blue represents giant covalent structures, dark blue molecular covalent structures, and violet single atoms. There is some doubt for uninvestigated elements such as oganesson (Og)."}, "abundance_and_occurrence": "Metals make up approximately 25% of the Earth's crust by weight, with nonmetals making up the rest. They are primarily found as lithophiles, or chalcophiles. Gold is a siderophile and is relatively rare.", "extraction": "Metals are often extracted from the Earth by means of mining ores. Once the ore is mined, the metals must be extracted, usually by chemical or electrolytic reduction."}, "alloys": {"description": "An alloy is a substance having metallic properties and which is composed of two or more elements, at least one of which is a metal. Most pure metals are either too soft, brittle, or chemically reactive for practical use, so combining different ratios of metals as alloys modifies the properties of pure metals to produce desirable characteristics."}, "categories": {"ferrous_and_non-ferrous_metals": "Ferrous metals contain iron, while non-ferrous metals and alloys lack appreciable amounts of iron.", "brittle_metals": "While nearly all metals are malleable or ductile, a few are brittle.", "refractory_metals": "Refractory metals are extraordinarily resistant to heat and wear, such as niobium, molybdenum, tantalum, tungsten, and rhenium.", "white_metals": "White metals have relatively low melting points, and they include zinc, cadmium, tin, antimony, lead, and bismuth.", "heavy_and_light_metals": "Heavy metals are relatively dense, while light metals have lower densities."}}

Mysida: {"name": "Mysida", "taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Arthropoda", "subphylum": "Crustacea", "class": "Malacostraca", "superorder": "Peracarida", "order": "Mysida"}, "description": "Mysida is an order of small, shrimp-like crustaceans in the malacostracan superorder Peracarida. They are characterized by the presence of a brood pouch in females where the larvae are reared. Their head bears a pair of stalked eyes and two pairs of antennae. The thorax consists of eight segments with branching limbs, all concealed beneath a protective carapace, and the abdomen has six segments with small limbs.", "habitat": "Mysids are found throughout the world in both shallow and deep marine waters, as well as in some freshwater and brackish ecosystems. They can be benthic or pelagic, and some benthic species make daily vertical migrations into higher parts of the water column.", "feeding_habits": "Mysids are filter feeders and omnivores, feeding on algae, detritus, and zooplankton. They are also used as a food source for other cultured marine organisms and are sensitive to water pollution, making them useful as bioindicators to monitor water quality.", "distribution": "Mysids have a cosmopolitan distribution and are found in both marine and freshwater environments, including estuaries, shallow coastal waters, lakes, rivers, and underground waters.", "behavior": "Some mysids are benthic or pelagic, while most are found close to or burrowing into the mud or sand. They are important in the diet of fish and exhibit varied feeding behaviors, reproductive patterns, and mutualistic relationships with other marine organisms.", "uses": "Some species of mysids are cultured in laboratories for experimental purposes and used as a food source for other cultured marine organisms. Narcomedusae: {"Narcomedusae": {"taxonomy": {"order": "Hydrozoans", "subclass": "Trachylinae"}, "description": "Narcomedusae is an order of hydrozoans in the subclass Trachylinae. Members of this order do not normally have a polyp stage. The medusa has a dome-shaped bell with thin sides. The tentacles are attached above the lobed margin of the bell with usually a gastric pouch above each. There are no bulbs on the tentacles and no radial canals. Narcomedusans are mostly inhabitants of the open sea and deep waters. They can be found in the Mediterranean in large numbers.", "feedingBehavior": "Narcomedusae use their tentacles to catch large, fast-moving prey. They do this by holding their tentacles perpendicular to the direction they are swimming to cover a larger area. If something is caught they bend the tentacle inwards and coil them at the tips to their mouths.", "reproductiveFeatures": {"reproductiveSystem": "Hermaphroditic", "reproductionProcess": "Narcomedusae release their eggs and sperm into the water where fertilization happens. Once the eggs are fertilized, they develop into a larval stage called planula and live in the seafloor. They are capable of reproducing all year round, with fluctuations depending on environmental conditions and food availability."}, "habitat": "Open sea and deep waters", "habitatSpecifics": "Found in large numbers in the Mediterranean", "gallery": "Gallery images of Narcomedusae"}}
Narella: {"genus": "Narella", "scientificName": "Narella", "discoveryYear": 1870, "family": "Primnoidae", "description": "Narella is a genus of deep-sea soft corals in the family Primnoidae. They are sessile, bottom-dwelling organisms with a branching appearance.", "etymology": {"nameOrigin": "The name Narella is believed to be derived from the Latin nares, meaning nostril, due to the resemblance of the rows of polyps to small noses."}, "distribution": {"description": "Narella is the most species-rich genus in Primnoidae and has a cosmopolitan distribution. They can be found in all ocean basins, including the Atlantic, the Pacific, the Hawaiian Islands, the Indian Ocean, the Gal\u00e1pagos, and off the coast of Antarctica.", "distinctGroup": "Each region has a distinct group of sympatric species, indicating Narella's high rate of adaptive radiation and potential for many undiscovered species."}, "morphology": {"speciesCount": "Over 50 recognized species, with Narella regularis as the type taxon", "distinguishingFeatures": "Conspicuous polyps with distinct large scales (sclerites). Most species have 16-18 sclerites arranged in pairs. Polyps are covered with opercular scales, each paired together, giving them a symmetrical appearance. Physical differences among species primarily involve the shape and texture of the scales. Corals have aragonite axes and spicules made of high Mg calcite. They anchor themselves using calcareous discoid holdfasts.", "fieldIdentification": "Branching appearance is the primary identification guide due to difficulty in identifying scale characteristics in the field."}, "species": [{"speciesName": "Narella regularis"}, {"speciesName": "Narella discoveryName"}]}
narella: {"genus": {"name": "Narella", "scientific_name": "Narella", "discovered_by": "John Edward Gray", "discovery_year": 1870, "family": "Primnoidae", "etymology": {"meaning": "The name Narella is believed to be derived from the latin nares, meaning nostril, due to the resemblance of the rows of polyps to small noses."}, "distribution": {"description": "Narella can be found in all ocean basins and has a cosmopolitan distribution, with species occurring in the Atlantic, the Pacific, the Hawaiian Islands, the Indian Ocean, the Gal\u00e1pagos, and off the coast of Antarctica."}, "morphology": {"description": "Narella is distinguished from other members of Primnoidae by their conspicuous polyps which have very distinct large scales, also called sclerites. Most species of Narella have 16 - 18 sclerites that are always arranged in pairs. The axis of corals in this genus are made of aragonite, while their spicules are made of high Mg calcite. They anchor themselves to hard substrates using calcareous discoid holdfasts."}, "species": {"type_taxon": "Narella regularis", "total_species": 50}}, "history": {"discovery": "The understanding of Narella and its members was established in the late 20th century. The genus was described in 1870 by John Edward Gray, and the first species in the genus was described in 1860. Several new species of Narella were discovered in 1887 but were initially described as members of new genera. It was only in 1951 that these genera were synonymized with Narella by Frederick Bayer."}}
Nemertea: {"name": "Nemertea", "scientificName": "Nemertea", "phylum": "Nemertea", "commonNames": ["Ribbon worms", "Proboscis worms"], "description": "Nemertea is a phylum of animals consisting of about 1300 known species, also known as ribbon worms or proboscis worms. They are characterized by their slim, elongated bodies and possess an eversible proboscis used for capturing prey, a rhynchocoel, a nervous system characterized by a ring of ganglia and ventral nerve cords, and a primitive circulatory system for transport of nutrients and waste products. Most nemerteans are marine, but some are found in freshwater and terrestrial environments.", "characteristics": {"bodyStructure": {"sizeRange": "From a few millimeters to over 1 meter in length", "coloration": "Patterns of yellow, orange, red, and green coloration", "thinness": "Very slim, elongated bodies"}, "feeding": {"proboscis": "Eversible proboscis used to capture prey", "feedingStyle": "Carnivorous, feeding on annelids, clams, crustaceans, and some are scavengers or commensals"}, "reproduction": {"reproductiveStrategy": "Most nemerteans are gonochoric, some are hermaphroditic, and reproduction can involve external fertilization or internal fertilization with viviparous species"}, "movement": {"locomotion": "Slow movement using external cilia, muscular waves, burrowing, and dorso-ventral undulations for swimming"}, "ecology": {"habitat": "Marine, freshwater, and cool, damp terrestrial environments", "ecologicalRole": "Carnivorous, scavengers, commensals, and have been known to devastate clam beds"}}, "taxonomy": {"traditionalClassification": {"classes": [{"name": "Anopla", "description": "Includes animals with proboscis without stylet"}, {"name": "Enopla", "description": "Includes animals with stylets"}], "orders": [{"name": "Palaeonemertea", "description": "Comprises predominantly marine species"}, {"name": "Heteronemertea", "description": "Includes both marine and freshwater species"}, {"name": "Bdellonemertea", "description": "Comprises species living as commensals"}, {"name": "Hoplonemertea", "description": "Includes species with armed stylets"}]}, "modernClassification": {"superclasses": [{"name": "Pronemertea", "classes": ["Palaeonemertea"]}, {"name": "Neonemertea", "classes": ["Pilidiophora", "Hoplonemertea"]}]}}, "evolutionaryHistory": {"fossilRecord": "Nemerteans are mostly soft-bodied, and their fossils are rare. Molecular phylogenetic analyses suggest nemerteans are part of the Lophotrochozoa, sharing relationships with annelids and mollusks."}}
Nemichthyidae: {"snipeEels": {"taxonomy": {"family": "Nemichthyidae", "genera": [{"name": "Avocettina", "species": ["A. gilli", "A. infans"]}, {"name": "Nemichthys", "species": ["N. scolopaceus"]}, {"name": "Protopterus", "species": ["P. annectens"]}]}, "characteristics": {"body": "Long and slender, similar to typical eels", "jaws": "Very slender with separation toward the tips and a resemblance to the beak of a snipe bird", "size": "Adults may reach 1\u20132 m in length and weigh only 80\u2013400 g", "dorsalFins": "Show wide variation in number of rays"}, "distribution": {"habitats": "Found in every ocean, mostly at depths of 300\u2013600 m, but sometimes as deep as 4,000 m", "behavior": "Occasionally caught nearer the surface at night and are stranded on the shore during storms", "larvalHabitats": "Larval snipe eels occupy shallow regions of 60\u201370 m before descending to metamorphose into adult form"}, "reproduction": {"spawningSeason": "Mainly in the spring to early summer", "juvenileForm": "Leptocephali, flat, transparent, and remain near the surface for several months before metamorphosing"}}, "bobtailSnipeEels": {"taxonomy": {"family": "Cyematidae", "genera": [{"name": "Cyema", "species": ["C. atrum", "C. erythrosoma"]}]}, "characteristics": {"size": "Grow up to 16 centimeters long", "habitats": "Bathypelagic, found in all oceans, down to 5,000 meters"}}, "sawtoothEels": {"taxonomy": {"family": "Serrivomeridae", "genera": [{"name": "Serrivomer", "species": ["S. lanceolatus", "S. schmidti"]}, {"name": "Serrivomerina", "species": ["S. beanii", "S. greenei"]}]}, "characteristics": {"teeth": "Arrangement of inward-slanting teeth attached to the vomer bone in the roof of the mouth"}, "habitats": "Found in temperate and tropical seas worldwide"}}

Ophichthidae: {"Ophichthidae": {"scientificName": "Ophichthidae", "commonName": "Snake eels", "description": "Ophichthidae is a family of fish in the order Anguilliformes, commonly known as the snake eels. They have long, cylindrical, snake-like bodies and are burrowing eels. They are found worldwide in tropical to warm temperate waters and inhabit a wide range of habitats, from coastal shallows to depths below 800 m. Most species are bottom dwellers, hiding in mud or sand to capture their prey of crustaceans and small fish. The family comprises species ranging in total length from 5 cm to 2.3 m or more. Many species lack fins altogether, improving their ability to burrow into the substrate like worms. They are often spotted or striped in color, mimicking the appearance of venomous sea snakes to deter predators.", "genera": {"Myrophinae": ["Ahlia", "Asarcenchelys", "Benthenchelys", "Glenoglossa", "Mixomyrophis", "Muraenichthys", "Myrophis", "Neenchelys", "Pseudomyrophis", "Pylorobranchus", "Schismorhynchus", "Schultzidia", "Scolecenchelys", "Skythrenchelys", "Sympenchelys"], "Ophichthinae": ["Allips", "Aplatophis", "Aprognathodon", "Apterichtus", "Bascanichthys", "Brachysomophis", "Caecula", "Callechelys", "Caralophia", "Chauligenion", "Cirrhimuraena", "Cirricaecula", "Dalophis", "Echelus", "Echiophis", "Ethadophis", "Evips", "Gordiichthys", "Hemerorhinus", "Herpetoichthys", "Hyphalophis", "Ichthyapus", "Kertomichthys", "Lamnostoma", "Leiuranus", "Leptenchelys", "Letharchus", "Lethogoleos", "Leuropharus", "Luthulenchelys", "Malvoliophis", "Myrichthys", "Mystriophis", "Ophichthus", "Ophisurus", "Paraletharchus", "Phaenomonas", "Phyllophichthus", "Pisodonophis", "Quassiremus", "Rhinophichthus", "Scytalichthys", "Stictorhinus", "Suculentophichthus", "Xestochilus", "Xyrias", "Yirrkala"]}}}

Ophidiidae: {"Cusk-eel": {"scientificName": "Ophidiidae", "order": "Ophidiiformes", "etymology": "The scientific name is from the Greek ophis meaning 'snake', and refers to their eel-like appearance.", "divergence": "True eels diverged from other ray-finned fish during the Jurassic, while cusk-eels are part of the Percomorpha clade.", "fossil": {"genus": "Ampheristus", "period": "Late Cretaceous (Maastrichtian) to the early Oligocene"}, "distribution": "Cusk-eels live in temperate and tropical oceans throughout the world, from shallow water to the hadal zone.", "record": {"deepestFish": {"species": "Abyssobrotula galatheae", "depth": "8,370 m (27,460 ft)"}}, "ecology": {"behavior": "Solitary in nature", "habitat": "Close to the sea bottom, often hiding in muddy bottoms, sinkholes, caves, coral crevices, or living inside invertebrate hosts", "feeding": "Nocturnal, preying on invertebrates, crustaceans, and small bottom-dwelling fishes"}, "characteristics": {"body": "Long, slender body about 12\u201313 times as long as it is deep", "size": {"largestSpecies": "Lamprogrammus shcherbachevi (up to 2 m or 6.6 ft)", "typicalLength": "Shorter than 1 m (3.3 ft)"}, "fins": {"dorsalAnalCaudal": "Typically continuous, forming a long, ribbon-like fin", "ventral": "Developed into a forked barbel-like organ below the mouth"}, "mouth": "Large relative to head, upper jaw reaching beyond the eye, paired nostrils on either side of the head", "scales": "Potentially absent; when present, they are small"}, "reproduction": {"type": "Oviparous", "eggs": "Believed to be spawned as individual, free-floating eggs or placed in a mucilaginous raft for several days until they hatch into cusk-eel larvae", "larvae": "Live amongst the plankton relatively close to the water's surface and control their metamorphoses into adult cusk-eels"}, "conservationStatus": "Not enough information has been gathered about Ophidiidae as a whole to determine their conservation status. Some species are vulnerable and a few are fished commercially.", "genera": {"count": "About 240 species in 50 genera", "subfamilies": ["Brotulinae", "Brotulotaenilinae", "Neobythitinae", "Ophidiinae"]}}}
Ophidiiformes: {"Ophidiiformes": {"description": "Ophidiiformes is an order of ray-finned fish that includes cusk-eels, pearlfishes, viviparous brotulas, and others. They have small heads, long slender bodies, and can be found in tropic, subtropic, freshwater, and marine habitats. Some species are known for living in abyssal depths and have adapted a range of feeding methods and lifestyles, including parasitism.", "characteristics": {"body": "Slender with small heads, smooth scales, or no scales", "fins": "Long dorsal fin and an anal fin that typically runs into the caudal fin", "reproduction": "Majority are egg-laying, but some are viviparous"}, "distribution": {"habitats": "Tropical, subtropical, freshwater, marine, including abyssal depths", "extremes": "Some species found as far north as the coast of Greenland and as far south as the Weddell Sea"}, "notable_species": [{"name": "Abyssobrotula galatheae", "depth": "8,370 metres (27,460 ft) in the Puerto Rico Trench"}], "classification": {"suborders": {"Ophidioidei": {"families": ["Carapidae", "Ophidiidae"]}, "Bythitoidei": {"families": ["Bythitidae", "Aphyonidae", "Parabrotulidae"]}}}, "fossil_records": {"earliest_members": "Known from the Maastrichtian, including the basal ophidiiform Pastorius"}, "sources": ["FishBase", "Integrated Taxonomic Information System", "Bulletins of American Paleontology"]}}
Ophiodon elongatus: {"lingcod": {"scientificName": "Ophiodon elongatus", "otherNames": ["buffalo cod", "cultus cod"], "description": "The lingcod is a fish of the greenling family Hexagrammidae. It is a popular eating fish, prized by anglers for its taste.", "size": {"length": "up to 152 centimetres (60 in)", "weight": "up to 59 kilograms (130 lb)"}, "color": "Spotted in various shades of gray, with around 20% having blue-green to turquoise flesh, a color that is destroyed by cooking.", "distribution": "Endemic to the west coast of North America, with the center of abundance off the coast of British Columbia. They inhabit various habitats before eventually settling in similar relief and substrate as older lingcod."}, "diet": "Voracious predators, feeding on invertebrates, various fish species such as herring, salmon, Pacific hake, smaller octopuses, and large rockfish.", "age": {"maximum": "about 36 years", "age determination": {"method": "Cross sections of the fourth to eighth fin rays from the second dorsal fin provide a method for estimating the age of lingcod. Ophiuridae: {"Ophiuridae": {"description": "Ophiuridae are a large family of brittle stars of the suborder Ophiurina. The arms are simple and unbranched, projecting from and well-fused to the edge of the disc. The arm spines are short and movable, lying flat against the arms when stimulated, but held erect when the brittle star is at rest. Disc and arms are covered in naked, distinct scales, situated at both sides of the disc. The jaw is surrounded by a continuous series of mouth papillae. The base of the arm contains a single arm comb or an inner and outer arm comb.", "systematicsAndPhylogeny": {"fossils": "The fossils of Ophiuridae date back to Carboniferous (Aganaster\u2020).", "livingGenera": "The family includes various living genera, including those sometimes placed in the family Ophioleucidae, here included in Ophiuridae as the subfamily Ophioleucinae."}, "sources": ["Hansson, H.G. Ostracoda: {"name": "Ostracods", "scientificName": "Ostracoda", "class": "Crustacea", "commonName": "Seed Shrimp", "description": "Ostracods are a class of small crustaceans, typically around 1mm in size, with a diverse range of diets and a wide distribution in marine and freshwater environments. They are encased in a bivalve-like shell made of chitin and usually calcium carbonate and have a unique reproductive system, which includes large coiled sperm in males and brood care in some species.", "etymology": {"origin": "Greek", "meaning": "shell or tile"}, "fossils": {"record": "Ostracods are the most common arthropods in the fossil record, with fossils dating back to the early Ordovician period. They are valuable for biozonation of marine strata and as indicators of paleoenvironments.", "notableFindings": [{"location": "Queensland, Australia", "discoveryDate": "2013", "significance": "Guinness World Record for the oldest penis and largest sperm recorded in an animal"}]}, "anatomy": {"body": "The body is encased by a bivalve carapace and consists of a head and thorax, with various appendages serving different functions. Ostracods have a pair of 'ventilatory appendages' for creating a water current and exhibit diverse sensory organs and respiratory systems.", "development": {"carapaceOrigin": "The carapace develops from two independent buds of the carapace valves that meet in the middle during growth.", "segmentation": "Most species have lost trunk segmentation, and the head is the largest part of the body, bearing four pairs of appendages."}}, "palaeoclimaticReconstruction": {"method": "Mutual ostracod temperature range (MOTR)", "use": "Inferring palaeotemperatures based on oxygen isotope and calcium-magnesium ratio analysis of ostracod valves"}, "distribution": {"ecologicalNiche": "Ostracods can be part of the zooplankton or benthos in marine environments and are found in marine, freshwater, and terrestrial habitats, including extreme environments such as sulfidic caves, deep groundwaters, and hot springs.", "diversity": "Around 2000 species and 200 genera of non-marine ostracods have been documented, with a large portion of diversity still undescribed."}, "ecology": {"lifecycle": "Ostracods exhibit diverse reproductive strategies, including large coiled sperm, swarming, parthenogenesis, and brood care, and have a unique lifecycle with direct development and variable instar counts.", "predators": "They are preyed upon by a variety of fauna in aquatic and terrestrial environments, including amphibians and certain clams.", "bioluminescence": "Some ostracods exhibit bioluminescence, using it for predation defense and in courtship displays, with bioluminescent courtship displays associated with higher speciation rates."}, "classification": {"livingClades": {"subclass": ["Myodocopa", "Podocopa"], "orders": ["Myodocopida", "Halocyprida", "Palaeocopida", "Platycopida", "Podocopida"]}}, "relatedLinks": ["Kempf Database Ostracoda", "Ostracoda fact sheet, Guide to the Marine Zooplankton of South-eastern Australia", "International Research Group on Ostracoda", "Ostracoda Fact Sheet", "Huge sperm of ancient crustaceans", "World Ostracoda Database"]}

Paguroidea: {"name": "Hermit Crab", "scientificName": "Paguroidea", "description": "Hermit crabs are decapod crustaceans of the superfamily Paguroidea that have adapted to occupy empty scavenged mollusc shells to protect their fragile exoskeletons.", "taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Arthropoda", "class": "Malacostraca", "order": "Decapoda", "superfamily": "Paguroidea"}, "habitat": "Hermit crabs are found in almost all marine environments, ranging from shallow reefs and shorelines to deep sea bottoms. Some species are also terrestrial and require access to both freshwater and saltwater to survive.", "species": {"count": 800, "groups": [{"name": "Aquatic hermit crabs", "description": "Mostly marine, living in depths of saltwater. They breathe through gills and can survive briefly out of water if their gills are damp."}, {"name": "Land hermit crabs", "description": "Terrestrial species found in tropical areas, requiring access to both freshwater and saltwater to keep their gills damp or wet to survive and reproduce."}]}, "fossilRecord": {"description": "The fossil record of in situ hermit crabs using gastropod shells stretches back to the Late Cretaceous. The earliest record of the superfamily extends back to the earliest part of the Jurassic."}, "physicalCharacteristics": {"abdomen": {"description": "Long, spirally curved and soft, unlike the hard, calcified abdomens seen in related crustaceans. The vulnerable abdomen is protected by a salvaged empty seashell."}, "size": "Ranges from a few millimetres to the size of a coconut."}, "reproduction": {"description": "Hermit crabs undergo development involving metamorphosis from larvae to benthic-dwelling, shell-seeking crabs. The sexual behavior inhibited by hermit crabs varies from species to species."}, "behavior": {"shellFighting": "A behavior observed in all hermit crabs where the attacker attempts to steal the shell of the victim.", "shellRemodeling": "As hermit crabs grow, they require larger shells. They may fight or kill a competitor to gain access to the shell they favor.", "groupBehavior": "Some hermit crab species exhibit unique group behaviors, such as congregating during the day and moving in groups."}, "associations": {"description": "Hermit crabs have multiple 'associates' living in or on their shells, including nereid worms, amphipods, barnacles, and sea anemones."}, "petCare": {"description": "Several species of hermit crabs are kept as pets, with some species having a lifespan of up to 20 years if properly cared for."}, "sources": [{"name": "Wikispecies", "url": "https://species.wikimedia.org/wiki/Paguroidea"}, {"name": "Wikimedia Commons", "url": "https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Paguroidea"}, {"name": "Wikibooks", "url": "https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Animal_Care/Land_hermit_crab"}]}
Pandalidae: {"taxonomy": {"family": "Pandalidae", "order": "Caridea", "class": "Malacostraca", "phylum": "Arthropoda", "kingdom": "Animalia"}, "characteristics": {"description": "The family Pandalidae is a taxon of caridean shrimp characterized by the subdivided carpus of the second pereiopod and the lack of chelae on the first pereiopod. Paralepididae: {"Barracudinas": {"scientificName": "Paralepididae", "commonName": "Barracudinas", "description": "Barracudinas are elongated, slender fish with large eyes, and a pointed snout containing fang-like teeth. They are found almost worldwide in deep waters and are related to lizardfish. They lack swim bladders and are simultaneous hermaphrodites, a reproductive mode which is rare among vertebrates. Barracudinas have unique adaptations for camouflage in the deep pelagic, including a subdermal layer of guanine and transparent skin among some species. They are known to inhabit mesopelagic depths throughout the world's oceans, and are predators of fish, shrimps, and squids. While they are rarely caught by fisheries, they are frequently documented in the guts of pelagic predators such as tuna, swordfish, lancetfish, Cuvier's beaked whales, and blue sharks.", "habitat": "Mesopelagic depths throughout the world's oceans", "diet": "Predators of fish, shrimps, and squids", "size": "Up to 100 cm (3.3 ft) in length", "specialAdaptations": {"GuanineLayer": "Subdermal layer of guanine that imparts a kaleidoscopic color to their appearance", "TransparentSkin": "Smaller, more derived species possess very few scales and their skin is almost completely transparent", "DarklyPigmentedGutLinings": "Thought to help conceal bioluminescent prey", "BioluminescentOrgans": "Some species have bioluminescent organs for camouflage against downwelling light"}, "spawningHabits": "Very little is known of the spawning habits of these fish. While both sperm and eggs are present in gonads, spawning has never been observed. Planktonic disposition and transmission of their early larva indicate that the eggs are fertilized and dispersed in the plankton.", "source": "Integrated Taxonomic Information System, FishBase"}}

Paranthias colonus: {"Paranthias colonus": {"commonName": "Pacific creolefish", "description": "Paranthias colonus, also known as the Pacific creolefish, is a species of grouper found in the Eastern Pacific Ocean. They are known to form small aggregations above reefs and retreat to the reef when in danger. They feed on plankton and can be found at depths of up to 100m. The body is elongate and fusiform with a small head and convex profiles. They have specific fin and ray counts and can grow up to approximately 36 cm. The coloration varies between young and adult individuals, with young ones being bright yellow with dark spots and adults being greenish brown dorsally and reddish below, with five white or blue-white spots on the back. The fins are reddish.", "distribution": "The Pacific creolefish is found in the Eastern Pacific from the Gulf of California to Peru, including the Revillagigedo, Galapagos, Clipperton, Cocos Island, and Malpelo islands.", "parasites": ["Prodistomum orientalis", "Brachyphallus sp.", "Lecithochirium sp.", "Anisakis sp.", "Spinitectus sp.", "Caligus sp.", "Hatschekia sp.", "Pseudorhabdosynochus jeanloui"], "references": ["Encyclopedia of Life. Parapaguridae: {"Parapaguridae": {"description": "The Parapaguridae are a family of marine hermit crabs from deep waters. Instead of carrying empty gastropod shells like other hermit crabs, they carry colonies of dozen or more sea anemones or zoanthids. Phaeodaria: {"Phaeodarea": {"description": "Phaeodarea, also known as Phaeodaria, is a group of amoeboid cercozoan organisms that are traditionally considered radiolarians but molecular trees have placed them among the Cercozoa. They are distinguished by the structure of their central capsule and the presence of a phaeodium, an aggregate of waste particles within the cell.", "characteristics": {"cell_structure": {"description": "Phaeodarea are unicellular protists that grow a capsule with a thick, double-layered wall containing astropylum or oral pores and parapylae or lateral pores. They have a large, often darkly pigmented mass of granular cytoplasm called phaeodium external to the capsule. Their mitochondrial cristae are tubular."}, "nutrition": {"description": "Phaeodarea are heterotrophic plankton (zooplankton) that chiefly live in pelagic open oceans. They have a continuous strand of cytoplasm in the astropyle that carries digested prey matter into the endoplasm. Limited evidence suggests they feed on microflagellates, metazoans, copepods, and salps."}, "reproduction": {"description": "Sexual reproduction of Phaeodaria has not been confirmed, but the release of motile swarmers that are likely gametes is widely documented. Some species disperse by producing multinucleated amoebae that eventually form swarmers with two undulipodia (flagella)."}}, "ecology": {"description": "Phaeodarea are exclusively marine, holoplanktonic unicellular protists that play an important role in marine ecosystems, living in pelagic open oceans from the surface to the deep sea. They are heterotrophic plankton and are present in all oceans."}, "systematics": {"history": {"description": "Phaeodaria were historically regarded as Radiolaria, along with Polycystinea and Acantharea, due to their elaborate siliceous skeletons and central capsule with pores from which axopodia emerge. Through molecular phylogenetics, Phaeodaria are now classified as a subclass of the phylum Cercozoa, within the higher Rhizaria supergroup."}, "phylogeny": {"description": "Phaeodarea is a monophyletic clade consisting of 11 subclades. The current taxonomy by Cavalier-Smith divides Phaeodarea into two orders: Eodarida and Opaloconchida, each containing suborders, families, and genera."}, "modern_classification": {"description": "The modern classification of Phaeodarea consists of the subclass containing 2 orders (Eodarida and Opaloconchida), 7 suborders, 16 families, and 39 genera, as proposed by Cavalier-Smith in 2012."}}}}
Phidolopora: {"Phidolopora": {"type": "Genus", "scientificName": "Phidolopora", "family": "Phidoloporidae", "distribution": "Almost cosmopolitan", "species": [{"name": "Phidolopora avicularis", "authority": "MacGillivray, 1883"}, {"name": "Phidolopora bartrumi", "authority": "Brown, 1952"}, {"name": "Phidolopora chakra", "authority": "Boonzaaier-Davids, Florence & Gibbons, 2020"}, {"name": "Phidolopora cyclops", "authority": "Boonzaaier-Davids, Florence & Gibbons, 2020"}, {"name": "Phidolopora elongata", "authority": "Smitt, 1866"}, {"name": "Phidolopora labiata", "authority": "Gabb & Horn, 1862"}, {"name": "Phidolopora pacifica", "authority": "Robertson, 1908"}, {"name": "Phidolopora pacificoidea", "authority": "Liu, 2001"}, {"name": "Phidolopora robusta", "authority": "Canu & Bassler, 1927"}, {"name": "Phidolopora trisinuata", "authority": "Liu, 2001"}]}}
Phoronida: {"Phoronids": {"scientificName": "Phoronida", "commonName": "Horseshow worms", "description": "Phoronids are marine animals that filter-feed with a lophophore and build upright tubes of chitin to support and protect their soft bodies. They are found in most oceans and seas, excluding the Antarctic Ocean.", "habitat": "Phoronids inhabit the intertidal zone and can be found at depths of up to 400 meters. They live in vertical tubes embedded in soft sediment or form tangled masses buried in rocks and shells.", "anatomy": {"size": "Most adult phoronids are 2 cm long and about 1.5 mm wide, although the largest can grow up to 50 cm long.", "bodyStructure": {"ampulla": "A flask-like swelling at the bottom end of the body that anchors the animal in the tube and enables it to retract its body when threatened.", "lophophore": "A crown of tentacles at the top of the body, which is used for filter-feeding and respiration.", "tubes": "Phoronids secrete rigid tubes of chitin to protect their soft bodies. These tubes can be reinforced with sediment particles and other debris."}}, "feedingAndCirculation": {"feeding": "Phoronids filter-feed using their lophophores, with cilia on the sides of the tentacles drawing in water and food particles.", "respiration": "They rely on respiration through the lophophore and do not ventilate their trunks with oxygenated water. The blood contains hemoglobin to adapt to anoxic and hypoxic environments.", "excretion": "Solid wastes are moved up the intestine and out through the anus."}, "reproductionAndLifecycle": {"reproduction": "Phoronids reproduce sexually from spring to autumn. Some species are hermaphroditic and cross-fertilize, while others have separate sexes.", "larvae": "Most species form free-swimming actinotroch larvae, which feed on plankton and undergo metamorphosis to become adult phoronids."}, "ecology": {"populationDensity": "In some habitats, populations of phoronids can reach tens of thousands of individuals per square meter.", "predators": "Predators of phoronids include fish, gastropods, and nematodes. Some species have effective defenses against predators."}, "evolutionaryHistory": {"fossilRecord": "There are no indisputable body fossils of phoronids, but there is evidence of trace fossils attributed to Phoronis in various periods from the Silurian to the Cretaceous.", "familyTree": "Phoronids, brachiopods, and bryozoans are collectively called lophophorates, although their exact relationship and evolutionary history is still subject to debate."}}}
Phronima: {"Phronima": {"description": "Phronima is a genus of small, deep sea hyperiid amphipods of the family Phronimidae. It is found throughout the world's oceans, except in polar regions. Phronima species live in the pelagic zone of the deep ocean. Their bodies are semitransparent.", "habitat": "Phronima species live in the pelagic zone of the deep ocean, found throughout the world's oceans, except in polar regions.", "feeding behavior": "Instead of constantly feeding on a live host, females attack salps, using their mouths and claws to eat the animal and hollow out its gelatinous shell. Phronima females then enter the barrel and lay their eggs inside, then propel the barrel through the water as the larvae develop, providing them with fresh food and water.", "classification": {"species": ["Phronima atlantica", "Phronima bowmani", "Phronima bucephala", "Phronima colletti Bovallius, 1887", "Phronima curvipes Vosseler, 1901", "Phronima dunbari", "Phronima pacifica Streets, 1887", "Phronima sedentaria (Forssk\u00e5l, 1775) (type species)", "Phronima solitaria Gu\u00e9rin-M\u00e9neville, 1836", "Phronima stebbingi Vosseler, 1901"]}}}
Phronima sedentaria: {"Phronima sedentaria": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Arthropoda", "subphylum": "Crustacea", "class": "Malacostraca", "order": "Amphipoda", "family": "Phronimidae", "genus": "Phronima", "species": "sedentaria"}, "description": "Phronima sedentaria is a species of amphipod crustaceans known for their large size relative to other members of the family Phronimidae. The species is usually found in midwater pelagic habitats but can be found migrating all the way to the surface.", "ecology": {"symbioticRelationship": "Exhibits a symbiotic relationship with tunicates of the genera Pyrosoma spp., Doliolum spp., and Salpa spp., displaying behaviors that suggest commensalism, parasitism, and predation. They are also known to be carnivorous on zooplankton, krill, arrowworms, and other crustaceans.", "feedingStrategies": "Uses different feeding techniques depending on the food source, primarily using the leading sets of pereiopods (front legs) for feeding. Physonectae: {"Physonectae": {"type": "suborder", "name": "Physonectae", "inJapanese": "\u80de\u6cf3 (h\u014dei)", "description": "Physonectae is a suborder of siphonophores, composed of pelagic organisms forming colonies of specialized zooids originating from the same fertilized egg.", "distribution": "The majority of physonect siphonophores are pelagic, with the exception of Rhodallidae, which are a family of benthic physonects. Physonects are known to be widely distributed globally, although their exact global distributions are unclear due to being understudied and often misidentified.", "morphology": {"pneumatophore": "All physonect siphonophores have an aboral, apical pneumatophore filled with gas, formed by invagination of the superficial cell layers of the larva. The pneumatophore plays a role in controlling gas volume and pressure for buoyancy control.", "nectosome": "The nectosome is composed of asexual nectophores, or swimming bells, specialized for swimming.", "siphosome": "The siphophore includes the gastrozooids (feeding polyps) and sexual medusoids."}, "reproduction": {"budding": "Each physonect colony is composed of individual organisms originating from the same fertilized egg, with specialized functions including locomotion, feeding, and reproduction. The ventral budding zone of the nectophores produces new buds asexually.", "sexualReproduction": "Sexual reproduction occurs to give rise to a new colony of zooids. Many physonect siphonophores are monoecious, some are protandrous, and few are dioecious. Fertilization happens externally."}, "lifeStages": "The life cycle of physonects involves external fertilization, formation of planula, development into siphonula, and maturation into a young colony, eventually becoming a mature colony. Most physonectae are pelagic throughout their entire life cycles.", "diet": "Physonectae are carnivorous predators and primarily consume large copepods, smaller copepods, arthropods, chaetognaths, fish larvae, and other large, non-copepod prey."}}
Planctoteuthis: {"Planctoteuthis": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Mollusca", "class": "Cephalopoda", "order": "Teuthida", "family": "Chiroteuthidae", "genus": "Planctoteuthis"}, "description": "Planctoteuthis is a genus of chiroteuthid squid comprising five species, occurring worldwide in lower mesopelagic to bathypelagic depths in tropical to temperate waters. It has been suggested that members of Planctoteuthis are neotenic, retaining characteristics of the doratopsis developmental stage. This is marked in the retention of the paralarval tentacular club, unique among subadult chiroteuthids. Members lack both photophores and a funnel valve.", "characteristics": {"neotenic": true, "retention_of_paralarval_tentacular_club": true, "lack_of_photophores": true, "lack_of_funnel_valve": true}, "species": ["Planctoteuthis danae", "Planctoteuthis exopthalmica", "Planctoteuthis levimana", "Planctoteuthis lippula", "Planctoteuthis oligobessa"], "references": {"Tree of Life web project": "https://treeoflife.org/planctoteuthis"}}}

Platyhelminthes: {"Platyhelminthes": {"alsoKnownAs": ["flatworms", "flat worms", "platyhelminths"], "description": "Platyhelminthes are a phylum of relatively simple bilaterian, unsegmented, soft-bodied invertebrates. Unlike other bilaterians, they are acoelomates and have no specialized circulatory and respiratory organs. They are divided into free-living flatworms and parasitic groups like Cestoda, Trematoda, and Monogenea.", "characteristics": [{"name": "Bilaterally symmetrical", "description": "Their left and right sides are mirror images of each other, with distinct top and bottom surfaces."}, {"name": "Acoelomates", "description": "They have no body cavity, unlike most other bilaterians."}, {"name": "Simple anatomy", "description": "They lack specialized circulatory and respiratory organs and have soft, unsegmented bodies."}], "majorSubgroups": {"Turbellaria": {"description": "Mostly free-living, ranging from 1 mm to 600 mm in length, and mainly predators or scavengers. Some are symbiotes or parasites. Many have pigment-cup ocelli and some are hermaphrodites."}, "Trematoda": {"description": "Parasitic flatworms known as flukes, with often complex life cycles and different stages infesting multiple hosts. Includes Digenea and Aspidogastrea groups."}, "Cercomeromorpha": {"description": "Parasitic flatworms with Monogenea and Cestoda groupings. Monogeneans are mainly external parasites, while Cestodes are internal parasites known as tapeworms."}}, "evolutionaryRelationships": {"relatedTo": "Bilateria", "internalRelationships": {"Acoelomorpha": "basal bilaterians", "Platyzoa": "part of Lophotrochozoa, closely related to Gastrotricha"}}, "interactionWithHumans": {"parasitism": {"impact": "Can cause diseases in humans and livestock, with some species causing tropical diseases like schistosomiasis. Infection with tapeworms and flukes can lead to serious health problems.", "risks": {"spread": "Rising threat in developed countries due to social trends, and spreads in less-developed countries due to poor sanitation and water supply."}}, "benefits": {"control": "Some planarian species have been used to control pests like the giant African snail, and have shown potential to reduce populations of mosquito species."}, "conservationConcerns": "Some flatworm species pose a threat to native snails and earthworms and are of concern in certain regions."}, "fossils": {"oldestIdentified": "Cestode eggs found in a Permian shark coprolite, with possible older fossils from the Devonian and Early Cambrian"}}}

Pleuroncodes planipes: {"Grimothea planipes": {"also known as": ["pelagic red crab", "red crab", "tuna crab"], "description": "Grimothea planipes is a bright red animal, up to 13 centimetres (5.1 in) long. It resembles a true lobster, but has a shorter abdomen.", "distribution": "Grimothea planipes lives on the continental shelf west of Mexico. It is usually found only south-west of San Diego, but in warmer years, its range may extend northwards into California. The southern limit of the species' range is in Chile.", "life cycle": "The life cycle of Grimothea planipes includes planktonic larvae being swept by the California Current thousands of miles out to sea. A solution was proposed whereby the larvae use an opposing undercurrent at a lower depth to return to the continental shelf.", "ecology": "Grimothea planipes usually feeds on protists and zooplankton, but will feed by filtering blooms of diatoms. It is an important food item for many species of birds, marine mammals, and fish. It is favored by tuna and is also known to be consumed by billfishes, yellowtail amberjack, sharks, Epinephelus analogus, gray whales, Bryde's whales, blue whales, sea otters, the Mexican endemic bat Myotis vivesi, loggerhead sea turtles, and seabirds like the herring gull (Larus argentuatus). Large numbers of Grimothea planipes washed ashore can be a valuable addition to the diets of seabirds, especially in El Ni\u00f1o years."}}
Pleuronectidae: {"Pleuronectidae": {"alternativeName": "Righteye flounders", "description": "Pleuronectidae, also known as righteye flounders, are a family of flounders characterized by their positioning on the sea bottom on their left sides with both eyes on their right sides.", "characteristics": {"dorsalFins": "Long and continuous", "reproductiveMethod": "Females lay eggs that float in mid-water until the larvae develop, and then they sink to the bottom", "habitat": "Found on the bottoms of oceans around the world, with some species found at depths down to 2,000 m (6,600 ft)", "diet": "Small species eat sea-floor invertebrates such as polychaetes and crustaceans, while larger species feed on other fishes and cephalopods"}, "commerciallyFishedSpecies": ["Various fish called flounders", "European plaice", "Halibuts", "Lemon sole", "Common dab", "Pacific Dover sole", "Flukes"]}, "Classification": {"subfamilies": {"Pleuronectinae": {"genera": 27, "species": "About 60 species in the Northern Hemisphere"}, "Paralichthodinae": {"description": "One species off southern Africa"}, "Poecilopsettinae": {"genera": 3, "species": "About 20 species in tropical and subtropical oceans"}, "Rhombosoleinae": {"genera": 9, "species": "About 20 species in the Southern Hemisphere"}}}, "Derived from": "The Greek words \u03c0\u03bb\u03b5\u03c5\u03c1\u03ac (pleura), meaning \"rib\" or \"side\", and \u03bd\u03b7\u03ba\u03c4\u03cc\u03bd (nekton), meaning \"swimming\"", "Related": ["Bothidae, the lefteye family of flounders"]}

Poeobius: {"Poeobius": {"type": "Genus", "taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Annelida", "class": "Polychaeta", "order": "Phyllodocida", "family": "Tomopteridae", "genus": "Poeobius", "species": "Poeobius meseres"}, "description": "Poeobius is a genus of marine polychaete worm, containing the single species Poeobius meseres, also known as balloon worm. Polychaeta: {"name": "Polychaeta", "description": "Polychaeta is a paraphyletic class of generally marine annelid worms, commonly called bristle worms or polychaetes.", "characteristics": {"size": "Less than 10 cm in length, although ranging from 1 mm to 3 m", "body features": "Each segment has a pair of fleshy protrusions called parapodia that bear many bristles, called chaetae, which are made of chitin. The head includes two to four pairs of eyes, antennae, tentacle-like palps, and pits lined with cilia known as nuchal organs.", "respiration": "Primarily through the parapodia, some species may have external gills", "circulatory system": "Usually presents a simple but well-developed circulatory system with main blood vessels and smaller vessels supplying the parapodia and gut", "nervous system": "Consists of a ventral nerve cord, ganglia, and sensory organs on the head", "reproductive strategies": "Most have separate sexes, shed immature gametes into the body cavity, and fertilize their eggs externally. Some reproduce by epitoky, where the worm undergoes a remarkable transformation as new, specialized segments grow from its rear end until it can be clearly divided into two halves.", "ecological niche": "Polychaetes are found in marine, freshwater, and terrestrial environments. Their lifestyle varies widely, including burrowing, swimming, pelagic life, tube-dwelling, boring, commensalism, and parasitism."}, "ecology": {"habitats": "Predominantly marine, but many species also live in freshwater, and a few in terrestrial environments. Some species swim among the plankton or above the abyssal plain, while most burrow or build tubes in the sediment and some live as commensals. A few species are parasitic.", "notable species": ["Pompeii worm (Alvinella pompejana) - Endemic to hydrothermal vents, heat-tolerant", "Bone-eating snot flower (genus: Osedax) - Known for consuming bones", "Hesiocaeca methanicola - Lives on methane clathrate deposits", "Lamellibrachia luymesi - Cold seep tube worm, over 250 years old", "Bobbit worm (Eunice aphroditois) - Predatory species reaching up to 3 m in length", "Dimorphilus gyrociliatus - Has the smallest known genome of any annelid, extreme sexual dimorphism"]}, "reproduction": {"modes": "Most have separate sexes, shed immature gametes into the body cavity, and fertilize their eggs externally. Some reproduce by epitoky, undergoing a remarkable transformation as new, specialized segments begin to grow from its rear end, dividing the worm into two halves.", "larval stages": "Fertilized eggs typically hatch into trochophore larvae, which float among the plankton, and eventually metamorphose into the adult form by adding segments."}, "fossil record": {"known fossils": ["Stem-group polychaete fossils known from the Sirius Passet Lagerst\u00e4tte in Greenland, dated to the early Cambrian", "Phragmochaeta canicularis - The oldest known stem-group polychaete fossil", "Cloudina - An early polychaete fossil from the terminal Ediacaran period"]}, "taxonomy": {"classification": ["Basal or incertae sedis", "Subclass Palpata", "Family Protodrilidae", "Family Polygordiidae", "Order Amphinomida", "Order Eunicida", "Order Phyllodocida", "Suborder Aphroditiformia", "Suborder Glyceriformia", "Suborder Nereidiformia", "Suborder Phyllodociformia", "Subclass Sedentaria", "Infraclass Canalipalpata", "Order Sabellida", "Order Spionida", "Suborder Spioniformia", "Suborder Terebellida", "Infraclass Scolecida", "Order Capitellida", "Order Cossurida", "Order Opheliida", "Order Orbiniida", "Order Questida", "Order Scolecidaformia", "Subclass Echiura"]}}

Psychrolutes phrictus: {"name": "Blob Sculpin", "scientificName": "Psychrolutes phrictus", "family": "Psychrolutidae", "habitat": {"location": "North Pacific Ocean", "depth": "500 to 2,800 m"}, "description": {"maximumLength": "70 cm (28 in)", "physicalCharacteristics": {"head": "broad and flattened", "eyes": "large and widely separated", "mouth": "curved with fleshy lips", "operculum": "poorly ossified and covered by a gelatinous layer", "cirri": "many small fleshy threads scattered over the head and body", "dorsalFin": "eight spines and nineteen to twenty soft rays", "analFin": "twelve to fourteen soft rays", "pectoralFins": "broad with fleshy pads near their tips", "coloration": "grey or black on the upper parts, pale on the underparts with some indistinct mottling"}}, "distribution": {"nativeTo": "northeastern Pacific Ocean"}, "ecology": {"diet": {"mainlyConsumes": ["crustaceans", "molluscs", "sea pens"], "otherItemsConsumed": ["cephalopods", "crinoids", "sea cucumbers", "fish"], "hostTo": ["Chondracanthus yanezi", "Neobrachiella amphipacifica"]}, "behavior": {"reproductiveBehavior": "the adult fish guard the nest, known example of parental care in egg-laying deep sea fishes", "spawning": "adhesive eggs onto limestone-like rocks in the deep sea", "interactionsWithOtherSpecies": {"octopuses": "scattered around and among the sculpins, also brooding their eggs"}}}}
Psychrolutidae: {"Blobfish": {"scientificName": "Psychrolutes", "commonNames": ["blobfish", "toadfish", "flathead sculpin", "tadpole sculpin"], "description": "The fish family Psychrolutidae contains over 35 recognized species in 8 genera. Their skin is loosely attached and movable, and the layer underneath it is gelatinous.", "habitat": "They are found in depths ranging from 300\u20131,700 meters in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, inhabiting colder waters and sometimes venturing into warm-temperate seas.", "diet": "They are ambush/opportunistic/foraging predators that feed on small crustaceans, sea pens, sea worms, and other small organisms.", "reproduction": "They exhibit complex nesting behaviors complete with egg guarding and have been observed gathering in large numbers to lay their pinkish eggs in a single surrounding nesting area. Psychropotes longicauda: {"Psychropotes longicauda": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Echinodermata", "class": "Holothuroidea", "order": "Elasipodida", "family": "Psychropotidae", "genus": "Psychropotes", "species": "longicauda"}, "description": {"adult": {"feeding_tentacles": 18, "body_length_cm": {"min": 14, "max": 32}, "body_shape": "cylindrical, broadest and somewhat flattened near the anterior end", "appendage": {"length_cm": {"max": 12}, "features": "dorsal, tail-like, pointed or with a pair of unequal-length tips"}, "tube_feet": {"ventral_surface": "double row of small tube feet", "body_sides": "single row of larger tube feet"}, "skin": "soft and pliable, violet in colour", "other_name": "gummy squirrel"}, "larva": {"tentacles": 10, "length_mm": {"min": 23}, "features": "transparent with a reddish hue at the anterior end, unpaired gelatinous dorsal appendage"}}, "distribution": {"habitat": "cosmopolitan abyssal species of sea cucumber found on the seabed in the world's deep oceans", "larvae": {"habit": "pelagic", "depth": "more than 500 m above the ocean floor in the abyssal zone"}}, "behaviour": {"feeding": "sifting through soft sediments with feeding tentacles", "reproduction": {"egg_diameter_mm": 4.4, "larval_nutrition": "yolk nourishment for an extended time, allowing wide dispersion"}}}}
Psychropotes: {"Psychropotes": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Echinodermata", "class": "Holothuroidea", "order": "Elasipodida", "family": "Psychropotidae", "genus": "Psychropotes"}, "description": "Psychropotes is a genus of sea cucumbers known for their ability to swim, although this is only facultative. Larvae are benthopelagic and transparent, growing to around 2 cm long.", "species": ["Psychropotes belyaevi", "Psychropotes depressa", "Psychropotes dubiosa", "Psychropotes dyscrita", "Psychropotes fuscopurpurea", "Psychropotes hyalinus", "Psychropotes longicauda", "Psychropotes loveni", "Psychropotes minuta", "Psychropotes mirabilis", "Psychropotes monstrosa", "Psychropotes moskalevi", "Psychropotes pawsoni", "Psychropotes raripes", "Psychropotes scotiae", "Psychropotes semperiana", "Psychropotes verrucicaudatus", "Psychropotes verrucosa", "Psychropotes xenochromata"]}}
Psychropotidae: {"Psychropotidae": {"description": "Psychropotidae is a family of deep-sea swimming sea cucumbers characterized by their elongate shape, depressed anterior dorsal surface, large posterior appendage, 10-20 tentacles and ventrolateral radii with small tube feet. They have calcareous deposits and a low degree of calcification, mainly consisting of connective tissue. The calcareous ring is incomplete with 5 independent parts, and they have unique sclerites in papillae. Some species may also exhibit swimming behavior and use dorsal appendages for movement.", "behavior": "Psychropotidae can swim short distances, with certain species spending much of their juvenile phase in the pelagic zone. Some species can use a large dorsal appendage as a 'sail' to move with the prevailing current. The ventral coloration may serve as camouflage from predators above and below.", "taxonomy": "Traditionally, Psychropotidae have been placed in the same taxon as the family Deimatidae, but recent molecular phylogenetic data suggests that the taxon is polyphyletic, with Deimatidae separated from all other Elasipoda families.", "reproduction": "The ovary in psychropotid species is a large thick-walled nodular structure containing oocytes, with an interspecific maximum size of 1.2 mm to 3 mm. The testes are well-developed structures packed with spermatozoa, except in specimens infested with protozoan parasites. Some species have notably large eggs, with Psychropotes longicauda having the largest known egg size in holothurians at 4.4 mm."}}
Pterasteridae: {"Pterasteridae": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Echinodermata", "class": "Asteroidea", "order": "Velatida", "family": "Pterasteridae"}, "description": "Pterasteridae is a family of sea stars primarily found in deep waters. They have an inflated aboral surface and a hole in the middle of the central disc called \"osculum\" for expelling mucus to defend against predators. Some species brood their young in internal chambers flushed with seawater. Fossil pterasterids have been found as early as the upper Campanian of the Cretaceous period.", "characteristics": {"habitat": "Deep-water", "aboral_surface": "Inflated", "defense_mechanism": "Expelling mucus through the \"osculum\"", "reproduction": "Some species brood their young in internal chambers flushed with seawater"}, "genera": {"Amembranaster": {"author": "Golotsvan, 1998", "species_count": 1}, "Benthaster": {"author": "Sladen, 1882", "species_count": 3}, "Calyptraster": {"author": "Sladen, 1882", "species_count": 5}, "Diplopteraster": {"author": "Verrill, 1880", "species_count": 7}, "Euretaster": {"author": "Fisher, 1940", "species_count": 3}, "Hymenaster": {"author": "Thomson, 1873", "species_count": 51}, "Hymenasterides": {"author": "Fisher, 1911", "species_count": 2}, "Pteraster": {"author": "M\u00fcller & Troschel, 1842", "species_count": 46}}}}
Pteropoda: {"Pteropoda": {"commonName": "pteropods", "description": "Specialized free-swimming pelagic sea snails and sea slugs, marine opisthobranch gastropods, most live in the top 10 m of the ocean and are less than 1 cm long.", "taxonomy": {"establishment": "Established by Cuvier in 1804 as \"pt\u00e9ropodes\". Fran\u00e7ois P\u00e9ron and Charles Alexandre Lesueur expanded the group to include opisthobranch and heteropoda taxa, and even ctenophora. In 1824, H.M.D. de Blainville named the two groups Gymnosomata and Thecosomata.", "clades": [{"name": "Thecosomata", "description": "Sea butterflies with a shell"}, {"name": "Gymnosomata", "description": "Sea angels without a shell"}]}, "evolutionaryHistory": {"originated": "During the Early Cretaceous, around 133 million years ago.", "diversification": "Occurring during the mid-late Cretaceous."}, "distribution": {"habitats": "Found in all major oceans, usually 0\u201310 metres (0\u201333 ft) below the ocean surface and in all levels of latitude. Few live lower than 500 meters below sea level. Commonly found on continental shelves."}, "threats": {"oceanAcidification": {"impactOnSpecies": "Pteropods, such as Limacina helicina, are potentially vulnerable to the corrosive waters associated with ocean acidification due to their calcium carbonate shell."}}}}

Pycnogonida: {"SeaSpider": {"scientificName": "Pycnogonida", "order": "Pantopoda", "class": "Pycnogonida", "description": "Marine arthropods with long legs and cosmopolitan distribution. They have a small body size and leg spans ranging from 1 mm to over 70 cm. Most species are found in relatively shallow depths but can also be found in Antarctic and deep waters.", "characteristics": {"walkingLegs": 8, "polymerousSpecies": 9, "respiratorySystem": "Gasses are absorbed by the legs and transferred through the body by diffusion. Proboscis allows them to suck nutrients from soft-bodied invertebrates. Digestive tract has diverticula extending into the legs.", "morphology": "Long, thin body with cephalothorax and a much smaller unsegmented abdomen. Oxygen is absorbed by the legs and transported via the hemolymph to the rest of the body. The heart beats vigorously at 90 to 180 beats per minute, creating substantial blood pressure.", "nervousSystem": "Consists of a brain connected to two ventral nerve cords, which in turn connect to specific nerves."}, "reproductionAndDevelopment": {"sexes": "Most species have separate sexes, with one known hermaphroditic species. Females possess a pair of ovaries, while males possess a pair of testes. Only males care for laid eggs and young.", "larva": "Blind gut and the body consists of a head and its three pairs of cephalic appendages only. At least four types of larvae have been described."}, "distributionAndEcology": {"habitat": "Found in oceans around the world, from shallow waters to depths of 7,000 meters. Live in marine and estuarine habitats, well camouflaged beneath rocks and algae.", "feedingHabits": "Carnivorous predators or scavengers that feed on cnidarians, sponges, polychaetes, and bryozoans. Can be parasitic on sea anemones."}, "taxonomy": {"species": "Over 1,300 species classified into eighty-six genera. Debate exists on whether they belong to the Chelicerata or have their own distinct lineage."}, "fossilRecord": {"earliestFossil": "Known from the Cambrian 'Orsten' of Sweden, with unambiguous sea spider body fossils from the Silurian and Devonian periods. Pycnopodia helianthoides: {"Pycnopodia helianthoides": {"commonName": "Sunflower sea star", "scientificName": "Pycnopodia helianthoides", "description": "The sunflower sea star, Pycnopodia helianthoides, is a large sea star found in the northeastern Pacific Ocean. It is the only species of its genus and is among the largest sea stars in the world, with a maximum arm span of 1 m (3.3 ft). Adult sunflower sea stars usually have 16 to 24 limbs and vary in color. They are carnivorous animals, feeding mostly on sea urchins, clams, sea snails, and other small invertebrates. The species is classified as Critically Endangered on the IUCN Red List.", "size": {"armSpan": "1 m (3.3 ft)", "weight": "approximately 5 kg"}, "color": "Bright orange, yellow-red, brown, and sometimes purple", "distribution": "Northeastern Pacific Ocean from Alaska to southern California, particularly dominant in Puget Sound, British Columbia, northern California, and southern Alaska", "habitat": "Low subtidal and intertidal areas up to 435m deep that are rich in seaweed, kelp, sand, mud, shells, gravel, or rocky bottoms", "diet": "Sea urchins, clams, snails, abalone, sea cucumbers, other sea stars, and dead or dying squid", "behavior": "Efficient hunters with a speed of 1 m/min (3.3 ft/min) and a tendency to shed arms to escape predators. They are preyed upon by king crabs.", "reproduction": "Reproduce sexually through broadcast spawning from May through June. Juveniles grow arms as they mature, with a lifespan of three to five years.", "conservationStatus": "Critically Endangered", "conservationEfforts": "Initiation of captive breeding programs and proposals for protection under the Endangered Species Act"}}

Pyrosoma atlanticum: {"Pyrosoma atlanticum": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Chordata", "class": "Thaliacea", "order": "Salpida", "family": "Pyrosomatidae", "genus": "Pyrosoma", "species": "Pyrosoma atlanticum"}, "description": "Pyrosoma atlanticum is a cylindrical, pelagic marine colonial tunicate that can grow up to 60 cm long and 4\u20136 cm wide.
