Radiolaria: {"entity": "Radiolaria", "description": "The Radiolaria, also called Radiozoa, are protozoa with intricate mineral skeletons, typically made of silica. They are found as zooplankton throughout the global ocean and are primarily heterotrophic, but many have photosynthetic endosymbionts and are considered mixotrophs.", "taxonomy": {"super_group": "Rhizaria", "major_lineages": ["Polycystina (Spumellaria + Nassellaria)", "Spasmaria (Acantharia + Taxopodida)"], "higher_order_groups": {"detected": ["Acantharia", "Spumellaria"], "unknown": "likely to be much higher than what is currently known"}}, "fossil_record": {"age": "Cambrian period", "significance": "used in geological dating, including for oil exploration and determination of ancient climates", "common_fossils": ["Actinomma", "Heliosphaera", "Hexadoridium"]}, "biogeography": {"habitat": "occupy habitats at multiple latitudes and depths throughout the world oceans", "potential_expansion": "tropical endemic species may expand their ranges toward midlatitudes", "impacts_of_global_warming": "modern Southern Ocean species will face environmental stressors due to disappearing cold-water habitats"}, "shells": {"composition": "usually made of silica", "function": "used for catching prey and can sink to the ocean floor when radiolarians die"}, "diversity_and_morphogenesis": {"spine_variations_discovered_by": "HMS Challenger", "drawings_by": "Ernst Haeckel in 1887", "related_works": ["Turing, Alan (1952). 'The Chemical Basis of Morphogenesis'", "Richards, Bernard (2005-2006) 'Turing, Richards and Morphogenesis'"]}, "related_topics": ["Radiolarite", "Biology", "Evolution", "Oceanography"]}
Radiozoa: {"entity": {"name": "Radiolaria", "description": "The Radiolaria, also called Radiozoa, are protozoa of diameter 0.1\u20130.2 mm that produce intricate mineral skeletons, typically with a central capsule dividing the cell into the inner and outer portions of endoplasm and ectoplasm. They are found as zooplankton throughout the global ocean and are primarily heterotrophic but many have photosynthetic endosymbionts, making them mixotrophs.", "taxonomy": {"super_group": "Rhizaria", "groups": {"traditional": ["Acantharea", "Nassellaria", "Spumellaria", "Phaeodarea"], "current": ["Polycystina", "Spasmaria"]}, "related_groups": {"molecular_analyses": ["Acantharia", "Spumellaria"], "relationships": "The relationship between the Foraminifera and Radiolaria is debated. Molecular trees support their close relationship\u2014a grouping termed Retaria."}}, "biogeography": {"habitat": "occupy habitats at multiple latitudes and depths throughout the world oceans", "sediments": "Sediments from the tropics reflect a composite of vertically stacked faunal assemblages, some of which are contiguous with higher latitude surface assemblages."}, "shells": {"description": "Radiolarians are encased in elaborate globular shells usually made of silica and pierced with holes, allowing them to catch prey by extending parts of their body through the holes.", "fossil_record": "The skeletons of ancient radiolarians are used in geological dating, including for oil exploration and determination of ancient climates."}, "fossil_record": {"oldest_known": "The earliest known radiolaria date to the very start of the Cambrian period, appearing in the same beds as the first small shelly fauna.", "extinct_species": "About ninety percent of known radiolarian species are extinct."}, "related_topics": ["Rhizaria", "Protozoa", "Zooplankton", "Endosymbiosis", "Mixotrophs", "Foraminifera"]}}
Rajiformes: {"Rajiformes": {"superorder": "Batoidea", "description": "Rajiformes is one of the four orders in the superorder Batoidea, consisting of flattened cartilaginous fishes related to sharks. They are distinguished by greatly enlarged pectoral fins, a generally flattened body, and exhibit rajiform locomotion.", "characteristics": {"body": "Rajoids typically have a dorsoventrally flattened body, a slender and pointed snout, wide mouth, well-developed spiracles, and gill slits located on the ventral surface just behind the head. They also have enlarged pectoral fins, two dorsal fins, and a whip-like tail with no caudal fin.", "skin": "Most species have thorn-like dermal denticles on their skin, often with a row of large denticles along the spine. The eyes and spiracles are located on the upper surface of the head.", "reproduction": "Most species give birth to live young, although some lay eggs enclosed in a horny capsule known as 'mermaid's purse'."}, "distribution": {"habitat": "Species of the order Rajiformes are found throughout the world's oceans, from Arctic to Antarctic waters, and from shallow coastal shelves to open seas and abyssal regions. Some are found in rivers and estuaries, but most are marine and live near the sea bed at depths down to 3,000 m (9,800 ft) or more."}, "families": {"extant": ["Anacanthobatidae", "Arhynchobatidae", "Gurgesiellidae", "Rajidae"], "extinct": ["Sclerorhynchoidei", "Ischyrhizidae", "Sclerorhynchidae", "Onchopristidae", "Ptychotrygonidae", "Schizorhizidae"]}, "biology": {"feeding": "Most species are carnivorous, feeding on molluscs, invertebrates, and small fish. The manta ray, however, feeds on plankton sieved out of the water. Some species swim by undulating their enlarged pectoral fins, while others propel themselves through the water with sideways movements of their tail and caudal fin.", "reproduction": "Most species are viviparous or ovoviviparous, whereas skates lay eggs enclosed in horny cases known as mermaid's purses. Most species are benthic, resting on the sea bed or pelagic, continually cruising the ocean."}}}

ratfish: {"name": "Chimaeras", "scientific_name": "Chimaeriformes", "informal_names": ["ghost sharks", "rat fish", "spookfish", "rabbit fish"], "closest_relatives": ["sharks", "rays"], "habitat": "deep water", "anatomy": {"description": "Chimaeras are soft-bodied, shark-like fish with bulky heads and long, tapered tails. Rathbunaster californicus: {"genus": "Rathbunaster", "species": "Rathbunaster californicus", "family": "Asteriidae", "common_name": "California sun star", "description": "Rathbunaster is a monospecific genus of sea stars in the family Asteriidae. The genus name was given by Walter Kenrick Fisher to honor the starfish biologist Richard Rathbun of the Smithsonian Institution. It is also involved in the decomposition of whale carcasses.", "reproduction": {"modes": ["asexual", "sexual"], "sexual_reproduction": "releases gametes into the water column for external fertilization"}, "ecological_impact": "Rathbunaster californicus is important in its ecosystems, being one of the most abundant sea stars along the west coast of the United States. rubber: {"subject": "Rubber", "aliases": ["India rubber", "latex", "Amazonian rubber", "caucho", "caoutchouc"], "description": "Rubber, also known as India rubber or latex, is a natural polymer of isoprene, prized for its high stretch ratio, resilience, and water-proof properties. Rubyspira: {"Rubyspira": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Mollusca", "class": "Gastropoda"}, "description": "Rubyspira is a genus of deep water sea snails within the superfamily Abyssochrysoidea.", "distribution": "Rubyspira is known to be from Monterey Bay, California.", "species": [{"name": "Rubyspira goffrediae", "discoveredYear": 2010}, {"name": "Rubyspira osteovora", "discoveredYear": 2010, "typeSpecies": true}, {"name": "Rubyspira from S\u00e3o Paulo Ridge", "status": "undescribed"}], "ecology": {"habitat": "Rubyspira are specialized bone-eating snails found on whale falls.", "foodSource": "Their main food source is the bones of whales."}}}
Ruvettus pretiosus: {"name": "Oilfish", "scientificName": "Ruvettus pretiosus", "distribution": "Oilfish have a cosmopolitan distribution in tropical and temperate oceans and are found at depths from 100 to 800 metres (330 to 2,620 ft), but most often between 200 and 400 metres (660 and 1,310 ft). They are distributed throughout tropical and temperate waters across the world, being recorded in the Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific oceans, including the Mediterranean Sea.", "description": "Oilfish are large, fusiform fish which often grow to 1.5 metres (4.9 ft) and a maximum of 3 metres (9.8 ft). They have large fangs, rough scales, two pairs of finlets, and a uniformly brown coloration. The meat of Oilfish is extremely oily, containing high lipid concentrations. Although edible, the oil mainly consists of wax esters, which makes the meat act as a laxative if consumed in large quantities.", "habitat": "Oilfish are found in the deep water benthic environments of continental slopes and seamounts, where they group in pairs or remain solitary. If food is scarce on the seafloor, at night Oilfish will rise to the surface to prey on other fish, cephalopods, and crustaceans.", "importanceToHumans": "Fisheries targeting Oilfish are rare, occurring in small regions of the Atlantic and Pacific through the use of handlines. However, Oilfish are common bycatch for fisheries targeting Tuna and Swordfish, which employ longlines. Despite their laxative-inducing flesh, Oilfish meat is popular in Japanese restaurants and can be substantially cheaper than that of other fish species, leading to some vendors intentionally mislabelling it as Butterfish or Cod, resulting in consumer health issues.", "incidents": [{"name": "ParknShop Oilfish Incident", "description": "In January 2007, ParknShop, a supermarket chain in Hong Kong, admitted to selling mislabeled Oilfish in their stores. Over 600 people became sick as a result, suffering from stomach pain and diarrhea. A total of 14 complaints were filed against the supermarket chain, leading to an investigation by the Centre for Food Safety. The fish were originally mislabeled in Indonesia, leading to an investigation and allegations of corruption. ParknShop stopped selling the fish, but argued in court that there was no law against the sale of Oilfish. The supermarket would later plead guilty to 9 charges of inappropriate labeling and was fined HK$45,000. As a result of the incident, the Centre for Food Safety in Hong Kong published new guidelines on the proper labeling of Oilfish and Escolar to consumers, preventing mislabeling. The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation in 2007 reported several cases in Canada where mislabelled Oilfish was sold at Chinese supermarkets."}], "relatedSpecies": [{"name": "Escolar", "description": "Escolar is an Oilfish relative, also with high concentrations of wax esters and can be similarly mislabeled."}]}
Sabellida: {"Sabellida": {"type": "Order", "taxonomy": {"Kingdom": "Animalia", "Phylum": "Annelida", "Class": "Polychaeta", "Order": "Sabellida"}, "characteristics": {"Feeding mode": "Filter feeder", "Buccal organ": "Absent", "Prostomium": "Fused with peristomium and bears feathery feeding tentacles", "Habitat": "Live in parchment-like tubes made of particles from the environment"}, "suborders": {"Feather duster worms": "Sabellidae", "Serpulid worms": "Serpulidae"}, "notable species": ["Giant feather duster worm (Eudistylia polymorpha)", "Peacock worm (Sabella pavonina)", "European fan worm (Sabella spallanzanii)", "Christmas tree worm (Spirobranchus giganteus)"], "related_links": {"Media": "https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Sabellida", "Data": "https://species.wikimedia.org/wiki/Sabellida"}}}
Sabellidae: {"Sabellidae": {"commonName": "Feather duster worms", "description": "Sabellidae is a family of marine polychaete tube worms known for their protruding feathery branchiae. They build tubes out of a tough, parchment-like exudate, strengthened with sand and bits of shell, with the genus Glomerula secreting a tube of calcium carbonate instead. They can be found in subtidal habitats around the world, and their oldest fossils are known from the Early Jurassic.", "characteristics": {"feedingAppendages": "Feather-duster worms have a crown of feeding appendages or radioles in two fan-shaped clusters projecting from their tubes when under water. Each radiole has paired side branches making a two-edged comb for filter feeding.", "anatomy": {"thoracicSegments": {"features": "The usually eight thoracic segments bear capillaries dorsally and hooked chaetae (bristles) ventrally."}, "abdominalSegments": {"features": "The abdominal segments are similar to the thoracic segments, but with the position of the capillaries and chaetae reversed. The posterior few abdominal segments may form a spoon-shaped hollow on the ventral side."}, "size": "Size varies between tiny and over 10 cm (4 in) long. Some small species can bend over and extend their tentacles to the sea floor to collect detritus."}}, "genera": ["Potamilla", "Glomerula"]}}

Salpidae: {"Salp": {"scientificName": "Salpidae", "commonName": "Salp", "description": "A barrel-shaped, planktonic tunicate in the family Salpidae known for its efficient jet propulsion and its ability to filter and feed on phytoplankton.", "distribution": "Salps are common in equatorial, temperate, and cold seas, including the Southern Ocean near Antarctica. Scalicus engyceros: {"name": "Scalicus engyceros", "taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Chordata", "class": "Actinopterygii", "order": "Scorpaeniformes", "family": "Peristediidae", "genus": "Scalicus", "species": "engyceros"}, "description": "Scalicus engyceros is a species of marine ray-finned fish belonging to the family Peristediidae, the armoured gurnards or armored sea robins. It is found in the northwestern Pacific Ocean, from southern Japan to Hawaii.", "distribution": {"habitat": "Benthic species found in rocky and sandy substrates at depths between 200 and 662 m (656 and 2,172 ft). Prefers tropical to warm, temperate seas and can often be found in marine waters on the lower continental shelf and upper continental slope at depths of 230m-545m."}, "physical_description": {"features": ["Filamentous barbels with 13-18 branches", "Narrow preorbital processes", "Short, rigid, parallel projections on the rostrum", "Small spines on the crown of the head", "Short pelvic fin"], "size": "Reaches a maximum published total length of 32 cm (13 in)", "color_variation": "Comes in various colors such as yellow, orange, red, or white with intraspecific color variation"}, "reproduction": {"reproductive_strategy": "Egg bearer", "embryonic_period": "2-3 days", "larval_period": "Few months", "recruitment_season": "Occurs over a few months from summer to winter"}, "behavior": {"feeding_habits": "Predator of benthic fish and crustaceans", "social_structure": "Solitary but may associate with other members during peak breeding season", "sensory_projections": "Used to hunt for food in weak light environments"}, "conservation_status": "Advocated for conservation of sea mounts due to the species' association with these areas and the importance of seamounts in the deep sea ecosystem", "economic_importance": "Caught as by-catch in bottom trawling fisheries"}
Scaphopoda: {"tuskShells": {"scientificName": "Scaphopoda", "commonNames": ["tusk shells", "tooth shells"], "description": "Tusk shells are a class of shelled marine mollusks with a worldwide distribution. They are the only class of exclusively infaunal marine mollusks, living in soft substrates offshore. The shells of species within this class range in length from 0.5 to 18 cm and are not as easily visible in beach drift as the shells of sea snails and clams. Molecular data suggest they are a sister group to cephalopods.", "orientation": {"description": "The morphological shape of the scaphopod body makes it difficult to orient satisfactorily, leading to disagreements among researchers. The apex of the shell and mantle are anatomically dorsal, and the large aperture is ventral and anterior. Functionally, the large aperture with the foot is anterior, the apical area posterior, the concave side dorsal, and the convex side ventral."}, "anatomy": {"shells": {"description": "Members of the order Dentaliida have glassy-smooth and narrow shells, while the Dentalids tend to have strongly ribbed and rough shells. Their shell structures allow them to move with surprising speed through loose sediment.", "defense": "When Dentalids sense vibrations, their defensive response is to freeze, making them harder to detect by predators."}, "mantle": {"description": "The mantle of a scaphopod is entirely within the shell. The foot extends from the larger end of the shell and is used to burrow through the substrate. Most adult scaphopods live entirely buried within the substrate, with water entering the mantle cavity through the apical aperture."}, "feedingAndDigestion": {"description": "Scaphopods have minute tentacles around the foot, called captacula, which sift through sediment and convey food to the mouth. The mouth has a grinding radula for digestion, and the digestive system includes a digestive diverticulum, esophagus, stomach, and intestine. They lack gills and have a unique feeding mechanism."}, "vascularSystem": {"description": "The scaphopod vascular system is rudimentary, lacking a heart and ctenidia. Metabolic waste is excreted through a pair of nephridia close to the anus. They have unique openings that may serve to relieve internal pressure by ejecting body fluid."}, "nervousSystem": {"description": "The nervous system is generally similar to that of cephalopods, with cerebral and pleural ganglia. Scaphopods have no eyes, osphradia, or distinct sensory organs, but possess genes involved in photoreceptor formation and function."}}, "reproductionAndDevelopment": {"description": "Scaphopods have separate sexes and external fertilization. Once fertilized, the eggs hatch into a free-living trochophore larva, which develops into a veliger larva that closely resembles the adult. They remain univalved throughout their morphogenesis."}, "ecology": {"habitat": "Tusk shells live in seafloor sediment, feeding primarily on foraminiferans and sometimes supplementing this with vegetable matter."}, "classification": {"description": "The group is composed of two subtaxa, Dentaliida and Gadilida, each consisting of several families and genera. The differences between the two orders hinge on size and details of their anatomy."}, "evolution": {"fossilRecord": "There is a good fossil record of scaphopods from the Mississippian onwards, making them the youngest molluscan class. Their evolutionary relationships and phylogeny with other molluscan groups remain contentious."}, "humanUse": {"description": "The shells of some tusk shell species were used as shell money by native populations in the Pacific Northwest and for crafting belts and headdresses by the Natufian culture of the Middle East."}, "references": ["Reynolds, P. D. (2002). \"The scaphopoda\". Molluscan Radiation - Lesser-known Branches. Advances in Marine Biology.", "Scarabino V. (1995). Scaphopoda of the tropical Pacific and Indian Oceans, with description of 3 new genera and 42 new species", "Steiner, G.; Kabat, A. R. (2001). Catalogue of supraspecific taxa of Scaphopoda (Mollusca). Zoosystema."]}}
Scleractinia: {"name": "Scleractinia", "commonName": "Stony corals", "phylum": "Cnidaria", "habitat": "Marine", "diet": "Zooplankton, invertebrates, small fish, and photosynthesis products from zooxanthellae", "reproduction": "Both sexual and asexual", "conservationStatus": "Listed under Appendix II of CITES", "anatomy": {"description": "Individual animals known as polyps have a cylindrical body crowned by an oral disc surrounded by a ring of tentacles. The base of the polyp secretes the stony material from which the coral skeleton is formed.", "skeletalStructure": "Secreted by the epidermis of the lower part of the body, the skeleton initially forms a cup surrounding the polyp. It contains radially aligned plates called septa."}, "ecology": {"groups": {"Reef-forming corals (hermatypic)": {"preferredHabitat": "Clear, oligotrophic, shallow tropical waters", "symbioticDinoflagellates": "Replete with the symbiotic unicellular dinoflagellates known as zooxanthellae"}, "Non-reef-forming corals (ahermatypic)": {"habitat": "Found in all regions of the ocean, including deep and polar waters"}}, "feeding": "Tentacles extend to feed on zooplankton; some corals also produce mucus films to trap small organic particles", "relationshipWithZooxanthellae": "Corals with zooxanthellae grow at a faster rate due to energy derived from photosynthesis products"}, "families": ["Mussidae", "Faviidae"], "evolution": {"origin": "First appeared in the Middle Triassic; their relationship to earlier corals is currently unresolved"}}
Sclerasterias: {"genus": "Sclerasterias", "scientificFamily": "Asteriidae", "description": "Sclerasterias is a genus of starfish in the family Asteriidae. Adult individuals have five arms but small, immature individuals have six. Young individuals, called Hydrasterias, often undergo fissiparity where the disc splits into two parts, each bearing three arms, and new arms develop on each part to complete the complement of arms. Scorpaenidae: {"Scorpaenidae": {"alsoKnownAs": "Scorpionfish", "description": "Scorpaenidae is a family of mostly marine fish known for their venomous species and characterized by sharp spines coated with venomous mucus. It includes hundreds of members and is widespread in tropical and temperate seas, primarily found in the Indo-Pacific. The family was described by the French naturalist Antoine Risso in 1826.", "taxonomy": {"scientificName": "Scorpaenidae", "suborder": "Scorpaenoidei", "order": "Scorpaeniformes", "subfamilies": ["Sebastinae", "Setarchinae", "Neosebastinae", "Scorpaeninae", "Caracanthinae", "Apistinae", "Tetraroginae", "Synanceiinae", "Plectrogeniinae"]}, "characteristics": {"body": "Compressed with ridges and spines on the head", "fins": {"dorsalFin": "Single with 11-17 spines and 8-17 soft rays", "analFin": "Single with 1-3 spines and 3-9 soft rays", "pelvicFin": "Single spine and 2-5 soft rays", "pectoralFin": "Large with 11-25 soft rays"}, "reproduction": "Mostly utilize internal fertilization and exhibit varied reproductive strategies including ovoviviparity and egg laying", "size": {"largestSpecies": "Shortraker rockfish (Sebastes borealis) - max length of 108 cm (43 in)", "typicalLength": "Many species have max total lengths of 5 cm (2.0 in)"}}, "distributionAndHabitat": {"oceans": "Mainly in the Pacific and Indian Oceans, with some species found in the Atlantic Ocean", "habitat": "Marine and brackish habitats including reefs, estuaries, bays, and lagoons"}}}
Scorpaeniformes: {"Scorpaeniformes": {"description": "The Scorpaeniformes is a diverse order of ray-finned fish, including the lionfishes and sculpins. It is one of the five largest orders of bony fishes by number of species, with over 1,320. They are known as 'mail-cheeked' fishes due to their distinguishing characteristic, the suborbital stay: a backwards extension of the third circumorbital bone across the cheek to the preoperculum. Scorpaeniform fishes are carnivorous, mostly feeding on crustaceans and smaller fish. They typically have spiny heads, and rounded pectoral and caudal fins.", "suborders": [{"name": "Scorpaenoidei", "description": "The suborder Scorpaenoidei is usually found in the benthic zone and includes the groups sea robins and scorpionfishes. The sea robins are further classified into two families: sea robins and armored sea robins. The scorpionfishes have twelve families and are very dynamic in size."}, {"name": "Platycephaloidei", "description": "This suborder includes families such as Bembridae, Platycephalidae, and Hoplichthyidae, and is associated with the superfamily Platycephaloidea."}, {"name": "Normanichthyiodei", "description": "This suborder includes the family Normanichthyidae and is associated with the superfamily Normanichthyoidea."}, {"name": "Zoarcoidei", "description": "This suborder includes various families such as Anarhichadidae, Cryptacanthodidae, and Stichaeidae, and is associated with the superfamily Zoarcoidea."}, {"name": "Gasterosteoidei", "description": "This suborder includes families such as Hypoptychidae, Aulorhynchidae, and Gasterosteidae, and is associated with the superfamily Gasterosteoidea."}, {"name": "Cottoidei", "description": "This suborder includes families such as Anoplopomatidae, Zaniolepididae, and Hexagrammidae, and is associated with various superfamilies such as Hexagrammoidea and Cyclopteroidea."}], "families": ["Aploactinidae", "Congiopodidae", "Pataecidae", "Gnathanacanthidae", "Eschmeyeridae", "Scorpaenidae", "Bembridae", "Platycephalidae", "Hoplichthyidae", "Triglidae", "Peristediidae", "Normanichthyidae", "Anarhichadidae", "Cryptacanthodidae", "Stichaeidae", "Pholidae", "Bathymasteridae", "Ptilichthyidae", "Eulophiidae", "Zoarcidae", "Scytalinidae", "Zaproridae", "Hypoptychidae", "Aulorhynchidae", "Gasterosteidae", "Anoplopomatidae", "Zaniolepididae", "Hexagrammidae", "Trichodontidae", "Jordaniidae", "Rhamphocottidae", "Scorpaenichthyidae", "Agonidae", "Cottidae", "Psychrolutidae", "Bathylutichthyidae", "Cyclopteridae", "Liparidae"], "references": ["Sepkoski, Jack (2002). 'A compendium of fossil marine animal genera'. Bulletins of American Paleontology. 364: 560."]}}
Scotoplanes: {"name": "Scotoplanes", "genus": "Scotoplanes", "family": "Elpidiidae", "commonName": "Sea pigs", "taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Echinodermata", "class": "Holothuroidea", "order": "Elasipodida"}, "description": "Scotoplanes is a genus of deep-sea sea cucumbers belonging to the family Elpidiidae. Its species are commonly known as sea pigs. These creatures inhabit the deep ocean bottoms, particularly on the abyssal plains in the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian Oceans, as well as in the Antarctic.", "locomotion": {"description": "Scotoplanes move through the top layer of seafloor sediment using their enlarged tube feet. They also have the ability to swim when disturbed. Some species are benthopelagic and spend time in the water column. Their frontal lobe as well as two anal lobes help propel them through the water, and their tentacles aid in detecting their surroundings while moving."}, "ecology": {"habitat": "Deep ocean bottoms, specifically on the abyssal plain, at depths of over 1,200 to 5,000 meters.", "feeding": "Scotoplanes are deposit feeders, obtaining food by extracting organic particles from deep-sea mud. They demonstrate strong preferences for rich, organic food that has freshly fallen from the ocean's surface, such as whale corpses.", "behavior": "They exhibit behavioral patterns of aggregation, where large numbers will aggregate either to feed or mate. They also host parasitic and commensal organisms, providing shelter to juvenile crabs and other organisms."}, "size": {"length": "4 to 6 inches", "anatomy": "Bilaterally symmetrical with six pairs of tube feet, ten buccal tentacles lining the oral cavity"}, "physiology": {"defenseMechanism": "Their skin contains a toxic chemical called holothurin, and they have external appendages including tube feet, dorsal papillae, and buccal tentacles.", "respiratorySystem": "They breathe from their anus, lacking a respiratory tree, and their bodies are not suited for the surface.", "reproductiveSystem": "They have a unique reproductive system with one gonad in both females and males, and active gametogenesis has been observed in both sexes.", "nervousSystem": "Consists of a network of nerves without ganglia.", "waterVascularSystem": "Similar to other echinoderms, Scotoplanes have a water vascular system which is responsible for the efficacy of their vascular system."}, "species": [{"name": "Scotoplanes angelicus"}, {"name": "Scotoplanes globosa"}, {"name": "Scotoplanes mutabilis"}], "references": [{"title": "Science Magazine: Sign In", "url": "https://www.sciencemag.org/"}, {"title": "Neptune Canada 'Sea Pig Slow Dance'", "url": "https://neptunecanada.ca/"}, {"title": "Echinoblog", "url": "https://echinoblog.blogspot.com/"}, {"title": "Sea pigs? Gross or cool? on Animal Planet website", "url": "https://www.animalplanet.com/"}]}
Scyliorhinidae: {"Catsharks": {"family": "Scyliorhinidae", "largestFamilyOfSharks": true, "numberofSpecies": 160, "genera": ["Akheilos", "Apristurus", "Asymbolus", "Atelomycterus", "Aulohalaelurus", "Bythaelurus", "Cephaloscyllium", "Cephalurus", "Figaro", "Galeus", "Halaelurus", "Haploblepharus", "Holohalaelurus", "Parmaturus", "Pentanchus", "Poroderma", "Schroederichthys", "Scyliorhinus"], "cladogram": ["Scyliorhininae", "Galeinae", "Pentanchini", "Galeini", "Galeina", "Halelaelurina", "Atelomycterininae", "Schroedericthyinae"], "anatomyAndAppearance": {"features": "elongated cat-like eyes, small dorsal fins, patterned appearance", "size": "up to 80 cm, with exceptions up to 1.6 m", "genusSpecificCharacteristics": {"Apristurus": "mostly dark bodies, long anal fin, flat snouts; bilateral symmetrical pattern in sonic hedgehog dentition expression"}, "Cephaloscyllium": "ability to fill stomachs with water or air when threatened"}, "distribution": "found around seabeds in temperate and tropical seas worldwide, from shallow intertidal waters to depths of 2,000 m", "behavior": {"nocturnal": true, "habitatSegregation": "males and females live in separate areas"}, "reproduction": {"oviparousSpecies": true, "ovoviviparousSpecies": true, "matingBehavior": "mate by biting and holding the female\u2019s pectoral fins"}, "aquaria": {"popularSpecies": ["Atelomycterus macleayi", "coral catshark"]}}}
Scyphozoa: {"Class": {"name": "Scyphozoa", "phylum": "Cnidaria", "commonName": "True jellyfish"}, "Description": "The Scyphozoa are an exclusively marine class of the phylum Cnidaria, referred to as the true jellyfish. They have existed from the earliest Cambrian to the present.", "Etymology": {"origin": "The class name Scyphozoa comes from the Greek word skyphos (\u03c3\u03ba\u03cd\u03c6\u03bf\u03c2), denoting a kind of drinking cup and alluding to the cup shape of the organism."}, "Biology": {"LifeHistoryPhases": "Most species of Scyphozoa have two life-history phases, including the planktonic medusa or polyp form, and an inconspicuous, but longer-lived, bottom-dwelling polyp.", "Size": "They typically range from 2 to 40 cm in diameter, with the largest species reaching 2 metres across.", "Habitat": "Scyphomedusae are found throughout the world's oceans, from the surface to great depths; no Scyphozoa occur in freshwater or on land.", "Feeding": "As medusae, they eat a variety of crustaceans and fish, which they capture using stinging cells called nematocysts."}, "Anatomy": {"Symmetry": "Scyphozoans usually display a four-part symmetry and have an internal gelatinous material called mesoglea, which provides structural integrity.", "PhysicalFeatures": "Scyphozoans have no durable hard parts, including no head, no skeleton, and no specialized organs for respiration or excretion.", "Movement": "The jellyfish swims by alternately contracting and relaxing muscle fibres within the mesoglea.", "DigestiveSystem": "The mouth opens into a central stomach, from which interconnected diverticula radiate outwards, and some species have additional, smaller mouths in the oral arms."}, "Reproduction": {"SexualDimorphism": "Most species appear to be gonochorists, with separate male and female individuals.", "Development": "The fertilized egg produces a planular larva which quickly attaches itself to the sea bottom, and then develops into the hydroid stage of the lifecycle."}, "CommercialImportance": "Scyphozoa include jellyfish fished commercially for food, such as the moon jelly Aurelia aurita and the enormous Nemopilema nomurai, which in some years causes major fisheries disruptions.", "Taxonomy": {"Orders": 3, "ExtantSpecies": "About 200 extant species are recognized at present, but the true diversity is likely to be at least 400 species.", "Subclasses": ["Coronamedusae", "Discomedusae"], "OrdersInDiscomedusae": 2, "SubclassDetails": {"OrderCoronatae": {"Families": ["Atollidae", "Atorellidae", "Linuchidae", "Nausithoidae", "Paraphyllinidae", "Periphyllidae"]}, "OrderRhizostomeae": {"Suborders": ["Daktyliophorae", "Kolpophorae"], "Families": ["Catostylidae", "Lobonematidae", "Lychnorhizidae", "Rhizostomatidae", "Stomolophidae", "Cassiopeidae", "Cepheidae", "Mastigiidae", "Thysanostomatidae", "Versurigidae"]}, "OrderSemaeostomeae": {"Families": ["Cyaneidae", "Drymonematidae", "Pelagiidae", "Phacellophoridae", "Ulmaridae"]}}, "Encyclopedia": "The Classification and Distribution of the Class Scyphozoa 'Scyphomedusae'. Encyclop\u00e6dia Britannica (11th ed.). 1911."}}
sea star: {"starfish": {"name": "Starfish", "scientific_name": "Asteroidea", "class": "Asteroidea", "description": "Starfish, also known as sea stars, are marine invertebrates with a star-shaped body and multiple arms radiating from a central disc. They are part of the class Asteroidea and belong to the phylum Echinodermata. There are over 1,900 species of starfish found in all the world's oceans, inhabiting a wide range of habitats from tropical zones to polar regions and depths of up to 6,000 meters.", "anatomy": {"general": "Most starfish have five arms, although the number can vary. Some species have a larger number of arms, up to 15. The body wall consists of a thin cuticle, an epidermis, a thick dermis, and a coelomic myoepithelial layer. The dermis contains an endoskeleton of calcium carbonate components known as ossicles. Starfish have a hydraulic water vascular system that helps in locomotion, adhesion, food manipulation, and gas exchange.", "water_vascular_system": "The water vascular system is a hydraulic system made up of fluid-filled canals and is concerned with functions like locomotion, adhesion, food manipulation, and gas exchange. Water enters the system through the madreporite, a porous sieve-like ossicle, and is linked through a stone canal to a ring canal around the mouth opening. Radial canals lead off from this, and tube feet extend from these canals to assist in movement and feeding."}, "diet": "Starfish are mostly generalist predators, feeding on microalgae, sponges, bivalves, snails, and other small animals. Some species are detritivores or suspension feeders, and a few are able to absorb organic nutrients from the surrounding water. Some starfish species are known to eat coral polyps or are capable of hunting prey much larger than their mouths by using specialized feeding behaviors.", "reproduction": {"sexual_reproduction": "Most starfish are gonochorous, having separate male and female individuals. Some species are simultaneous hermaphrodites, producing eggs and sperm at the same time. Starfish have distinctive reproductive strategies that include free spawning of buoyant eggs and sperm into the water, brooding of eggs, internal fertilization, and asexual reproduction through fission or autotomy of limbs. Larvae of some species can also reproduce asexually."}, "ecology": {"distribution_and_habitat": "Starfish species are found in all of the world's oceans, inhabiting a wide range of marine environments from tropical coral reefs, rocky shores, and tidal pools to kelp forests, seagrass meadows, and the deep-sea floor. The greatest diversity of species occurs in coastal areas.", "impact": "Starfish play important ecological roles as keystone species in marine communities. Their feeding activities can regulate the diversity, distribution, and abundance of microorganisms, and they also have the ability to control populations of certain prey species. However, some starfish outbreaks have caused damage to coral reefs, threatening biodiversity and reef-feeding fish. Invasive starfish species can also negatively impact marine ecosystems by threatening commercially important populations of other marine organisms."}, "evolution": {"fossil_record": "The fossil record for starfish dates back to the Paleozoic, and there are Lagerst\u00e4tten, known as 'starfish beds' where accumulations of complete skeletal structures occur. Starfish rapidly diversified during the Early Jurassic period, and phylogenetic data suggests that they may have undergone significant speciation over the past 6,000 years. The order and phylogeny of the Asteroidea has been challenging to resolve, with molecular evidence leading to ongoing debates about the taxonomic classification of the group."}, "in_human_relations": {"research": "Starfish are used in reproductive and developmental studies, as well as regenerative and cloning research due to their unique ability to regenerate lost body parts and expel foreign objects from their bodies. Their large oocytes make them well suited for laboratory studies.", "legend_and_culture": "Starfish have been featured in various legends, fables, and cultural references, appearing in myths and fables from different cultures including an aboriginal Australian fable and ancient Hawaiian prayers. Starfish have also been used as titles for novels, non-fiction books, and business management concepts. In popular culture, starfish have been portrayed in TV series and popular animation."}, "in_industry_and_military_history": {"food": "While occasionally used as food in some cultures, starfish are not commonly consumed due to the presence of unpleasant-tasting compounds, toxins, and the risk of transmitting paralytic shellfish poisoning. They are sometimes taken from their habitat and sold as souvenirs, curios, or for display in aquariums.", "military_history": "Starfish has been chosen as a name for military vessels, night-time decoy sites during World War II, and high-altitude nuclear tests. The name is also used for computer networks, software tools, and a seabed imaging system and company."}}}
Sebastes: {"name": "Sebastes", "scientificName": "Sebastes", "kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Chordata", "class": "Actinopterygii", "order": "Scorpaeniformes", "family": "Scorpaenidae", "genus": "Sebastes", "subfamily": "Sebastinae", "habitat": "Atlantic and Pacific Oceans", "description": "Sebastes is a genus of marine ray-finned fish belonging to the subfamily Sebastinae part of the family Scorpaenidae. Sebastes caurinus: {"name": "Copper Rockfish", "scientificName": "Sebastes caurinus", "commonNames": ["Copper rockfish", "Copper seaperch"], "taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Chordata", "class": "Actinopterygii", "order": "Scorpaeniformes", "family": "Scorpaenidae", "subfamily": "Sebastinae", "genus": "Sebastes", "subgenus": "Pteropodus"}, "description": "The copper rockfish, Sebastes caurinus, is a highly variable marine ray-finned fish with coloration ranging from dark reddish brown to lighter pinkish brown. It is a demersal fish found in the eastern Pacific, creating and communicating with sound for agonistic behaviors.", "habitat": "The copper rockfish is widespread and found in rocky areas with high relief in the Pacific coast from the Gulf of Alaska to the Pacific side of the Baja California peninsula. It occurs at depths of about 10 to 183 metres (33 to 600 ft).", "distribution": "The copper rockfish has a wide distribution from the northern reaches of the Gulf of Alaska to north of Guerrero Negro, Baja California, and is found at a wide range of depths in the Pacific.", "biology": {"reproduction": "Copper rockfish are viviparous, reaching sexual maturity between three and eight years. Females bear more young when they are larger. They have a gestation period of around 10 months and can live over forty years.", "diet": "Juveniles feed primarily on planktonic crustaceans and as they grow, they feed on larger crustaceans, squid, octopus, and smaller fish. They are preyed on by lingcod, cabezone, salmon, sea birds, sea mammals, and humans.", "behavior": "Copper rockfish are faithful to their chosen home, traveling no more than a mile from their location. Sebastes pinniger: {"name": "Canary Rockfish", "scientificName": "Sebastes pinniger", "commonName": "Orange Rockfish", "taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Chordata", "class": "Actinopterygii", "order": "Scorpaeniformes", "family": "Scorpaenidae", "subfamily": "Sebastinae", "genus": "Sebastes", "species": "pinniger"}, "description": "The canary rockfish is a marine ray-finned fish native to the waters of the Pacific Ocean off western North America. It is notable for its orange-yellow appearance with a blotchy orange pattern over a whitish or light gray background. It has three stripes on the head angling downwards and back, and its fins are orange, with the pectoral, pelvic, and anal fins somewhat pointed and larger. Some individuals have dark blotches on the body or dorsal fin.", "habitat": "Young canaries live in relatively shallow water, moving to deeper water as they mature. Adults are mostly found at depths of 80\u2013200 meters, tending to collect in groups around pinnacles and similar high-relief rock formations, especially where the current is strong.", "diet": "Juveniles feed on small crustacea such as krill larvae, copepods, and amphipods, while adults eat krill and small fishes.", "conservationStatus": "The population of canary rockfish on the U.S. West Coast was declared overfished in 2000, leading to a recovery plan being implemented in 2001. This stock was declared rebuilt in 2015. While a distinct population segment (DPS) of canary rockfish in Puget Sound was proposed for listing as threatened under the Endangered Species Act, it was later removed from the Federal List of Threatened and Endangered Species due to new genetic information indicating lack of discreteness."}

Sebastolobus alascanus: {"shortspineThornyhead": {"scientificName": "Sebastolobus alascanus", "commonNames": ["shortspine thornyhead", "channel rockcod", "shortspine channel rockfish", "spinycheek rockfish"], "taxonomy": {"phylum": "Chordata", "class": "Actinopterygii", "order": "Scorpaeniformes", "family": "Scorpaenidae", "subfamily": "Sebastinae"}, "description": {"physicalCharacteristics": "Large head with a strong spiny ridge, elongate tapering body, dorsal fin with 15 to 17 spines and 8 to 9 soft rays, anal fin with 3 spines and 4 to 5 soft rays, bright red color with varying black on fins and pale gill chamber", "size": "Up to 80 cm (31 in) in length"}, "distribution": "Northern and northeastern Pacific Ocean, from the Sea of Okhotsk to Cedros Island in Baja California, depths between 17 and 1,600 m", "biology": {"feedingHabits": "Predator of shrimp, crabs, zooplankton, amphipods, and other benthic invertebrates", "reproduction": "Females grow larger and reach sexual maturity at approximately 18 cm or 8-10 years old, internally fertilized eggs extruded in pelagic, gelatinous masses, spawning occurs between December and May along the Pacific coasts of contiguous United States and between April and May in the Gulf of Alaska", "adaptations": "Predominantly living in the oxygen minimum zone with specific adaptations/exaptations for low oxygen levels"}, "status": {"stockAssessments": "Healthy stock in the waters off Alaska, British Columbia, and the West Coast of the United States, with overfishing not occurring", "IUCNStatus": "Endangered (based on 2000 assessment)"}}}

Siboglinidae: {"Siboglinidae": {"description": "Siboglinidae is a family of polychaete annelid worms, formerly composed of the phyla Pogonophora and Vestimentifera, with around 100 species living in thin tubes buried in sediment or attached to hard substratum at ocean depths ranging from 100 to 10,000 m. They are found in association with hydrothermal vents, methane seeps, sunken plant material, and whale carcasses.", "discovery": {"location": "Indonesia", "year": 1900, "zoologist": "Maurice Caullery"}, "anatomy": {"size": "less than 1 millimetre in diameter, but 10\u201375 centimetres in length", "body_parts": ["cephalic lobe", "glandular forepart", "trunk", "opisthosoma"], "characteristics": ["branchial ciliated tentacles", "papillae", "ciliary tracts", "chaetae"]}, "evolution": {"origins": "Mesozoic (250 \u2013 66 Mya) or Cenozoic (66 Mya \u2013 recent)", "clades": ["Vestimentifera", "Sclerolinum", "Frenulata", "Osedax"]}, "vestimentiferans": {"description": "Benthic marine creatures known from hydrothermal vent systems", "regions": ["obturaculum", "vestimentum", "trunk", "opisthosome"], "ecology": {"nutrition": "derived from sulfide-rich fluids", "symbiotic_relationship": "sulfide- or methane-oxidizing bacteria living in a trophosome"}}, "genera": {"clade_Frenulata": ["Birsteinia", "Bobmarleya", "Choanophorus", "Crassibrachia", "Cyclobrachia", "Diplobrachia", "Galathealinum", "Heptabrachia", "Lamellisabella", "Nereilinum", "Oligobrachia", "Paraescarpia", "Polybrachia", "Siboglinoides", "Siboglinum", "Siphonobrachia", "Spirobrachia", "Unibrachium", "Volvobrachia", "Zenkevitchiana"], "clade_Monilifera": ["Sclerolinum"], "clade_Vestimentifera": ["Alaysia", "Arcovesia", "Escarpia", "Lamellibrachia", "Oasisia", "Ridgeia", "Riftia", "Tevnia"]}}}
Simenchelys parasitica: {"snubnosedEel": {"scientificName": "Simenchelys parasitica", "commonNames": ["pug-nosed eel", "slime eel", "snub-nose parasitic eel"], "description": "The snubnosed eel, Simenchelys parasitica, is a deep-sea eel and the only member of its genus. Sternoptyx: {"Sternoptyx": {"scientificName": "Sternoptyx", "commonName": "Hatchetfish", "genus": "Sternoptyx", "family": "Sternoptychidae", "description": "Sternoptyx is an oceanic ray-finned fish genus belonging to the family Sternoptychidae. It is the type genus of the Sternoptychidae and the marine hatchetfish subfamily Sternoptychinae. The fish have silvery, high, and laterally compressed bodies and large, non-telescopic eyes. Despite being relatively small, even the largest species do not exceed 60 millimetres (2.4 in) in standard length.", "species": [{"name": "Sternoptyx diaphana", "commonName": "Diaphanous hatchetfish", "scientificName": "Sternoptyx diaphana", "description": "Also known as the Diaphanous hatchetfish."}, {"name": "Sternoptyx obscura", "commonName": "Obscure hatchetfish", "scientificName": "Sternoptyx obscura", "description": "Also known as the Obscure hatchetfish."}, {"name": "Sternoptyx pseudobscura", "commonName": "Highlight hatchetfish", "scientificName": "Sternoptyx pseudobscura", "description": "Also known as the Highlight hatchetfish."}, {"name": "Sternoptyx pseudodiaphana", "commonName": "False oblique hatchetfish", "scientificName": "Sternoptyx pseudodiaphana", "description": "Also known as the False oblique hatchetfish."}], "fossilRecord": {"existence": "Fossils of this genus show that they have existed at least since the Early Oligocene, about 30 million years ago."}}}
Sternoptyx diaphana: {"Sternoptyx diaphana": {"scientificName": "Sternoptyx diaphana", "commonName": "Diaphanous hatchetfish", "family": "Sternoptychidae", "description": "Sternoptyx diaphana is a short, deep-bodied fish with a laterally compressed body and a maximum length of about 45 mm (1.8 in). The mouth is nearly vertical, the snout is short and the eyes are large. The body slopes steeply up from the head and levels off at the caudal peduncle. In front of the dorsal fin is a toothed, pear-shaped translucent plate supported by a single spine. The dorsal fin has 9 to 12 soft rays and the anal fin 13 to 14. There is a translucent fold of skin just below the short tail, and another below the ventral region of the body. There are photophores behind and below the eye, on the gill cover, and rows of photophores on the underside of the fish. The dorsal region is dark, the flanks are silvery and the fins transparent.", "distribution": "Sternoptyx diaphana has a wide distribution in temperate and tropical waters of all the world's oceans, although occurring with less frequency in equatorial seas. Its depth range is 300 and 1,500 metres (1,000 and 5,000 ft), but it is most often found between about 600 and 900 metres (2,000 and 3,000 ft), where the water temperature is between 4 and 11 \u00b0C (39 and 52 \u00b0F). It appears not to make the daily vertical migrations made by some related species.", "ecology": "The diet consists of small fish, euphausiids, decapods, copepods and amphipods. Larger fish generally consume larger food items; the diet varies with location with the fish appearing to be opportunistic predators of whatever prey species they encounter.", "status": "Sternoptyx diaphana has a very wide distribution, is a common species and faces no particular threats. The International Union for Conservation of Nature has assessed its conservation status as being of \"least concern\"."}}

Stylasterias forreri: {"Stylasterias": {"scientific_name": "Stylasterias", "genus": "Starfish", "family": "Asteriidae", "description": "Stylasterias is a genus of starfish in the family Asteriidae. Stylasterias forreri, the velcro star, is the only species in the genus. It is found on the Pacific coast of Canada and the United States.", "species": [{"common_name": "Velcro Star", "scientific_name": "Stylasterias forreri", "description": "The velcro star is a large starfish, growing to a maximum diameter of 100 cm (39 in), but is usually considerably smaller. The central disc is small and the five (occasionally six) arms are long and tapering. Rows of large spines run down the arms, each one surrounded by a ring of 30-40 pedicellariae, tiny pincer-like structures. Between the spines are tufts of pale gills. The colour of the velcro star is some shade of grey or black, or occasionally beige.", "distribution": "The velcro star occurs on the Pacific coast of North America, from Kodiak Island, Alaska, to Southern California. It is found at depths to about 530 m (1,740 ft). It is generally uncommon and mostly occurs in deep water at the head of fiords.", "biology": "The velcro star feeds on invertebrates such as gastropod molluscs and chitons. If anything touches its aboral (upper) surface, the starfish reacts by snapping shut the pedicellariae in the vicinity of the stimulus. The velcro star can also defend itself against attack by predators such as the morning sun star (Solaster dawsoni) by inflicting thousands of nips with its pedicellariae."}]}}

Symphurus thermophilus: {"Symphurus thermophilus": {"scientificName": "Symphurus thermophilus", "commonName": "Thermal tonguefish", "description": "Symphurus thermophilus is a species of tonguefish notable for being the only flatfish known to be an obligate inhabitant of hydrothermal vents. It is known from several widely dispersed locations in the western Pacific Ocean and occurs in great numbers. They are tolerant of harsh conditions and are often found in close association with elemental sulfur, including molten sulfur pools that exceed 180 \u00b0C in temperature. As they are not significantly different in appearance and feeding habits from other tonguefishes, they are thought to be relatively recent colonizers of vent ecosystems. These fish were first observed in nature in 1988 and were provisionally assigned to the species Symphurus orientalis before being recognized as a new species. The species name thermophilus is from the Greek thermos meaning \"heat\" and philos meaning \"lover,\" referring to its association with hydrothermal vents.", "distributionAndHabitat": {"distribution": "widely dispersed locations in the western Pacific Ocean", "habitat": "shallow active hydrothermal vent sites at a depth of 239\u2013733 m, with most found between 300\u2013400 m"}, "physicalDescription": {"bodyShape": "laterally flattened body", "size": "8.7 cm for male, 11.2 cm for female", "color": "dark chocolate brown with blotches and speckles on the eyed side; white with scattered dark melanophores on the blind side"}, "biologyAndEcology": {"behavior": "spend most of their time on the sea floor, moving forwards or backwards by undulating their bodies and sometimes burying themselves completely in the substrate", "feeding": "varies from seamount to seamount, with diet including polychaete worms, crustaceans, snails, sponge spicules, and chemosynthetic bacteria filaments", "reproduction": "oviparous, slow-growing, and long-lived, with females releasing buoyant eggs"}}}

Thetys: {"name": "Thetis", "pronunciation": "THEEH-tiss", "greekName": "\u0398\u03ad\u03c4\u03b9\u03c2", "roles": ["Sea nymph", "Goddess of water"], "parents": {"father": "Nereus", "mother": "Doris"}, "grandparent": "Tethys", "sibling": "50 Nereids", "otherIdentities": ["Metis (possibly)"], "mythologicalRoles": {"trojanWar": {"significance": "Marriage with Peleus led to the birth of Achilles, a key figure in the Trojan War", "precipitatingEvent": "Wedding of Thetis and Peleus"}, "protectionAndNurturing": {"unsuccessfulRole": "Protecting and nurturing a hero"}, "cosmicRelations": {"distinctiveAspects": "Alternative structure of cosmic relations"}}, "epithet": "Halosydne", "weddingWithPeleus": {"adviceFromProteus": "Peleus was advised to bind Thetis tightly while she was asleep to prevent her from escaping by changing forms", "outcome": "Thetis consented to marry Peleus and gave birth to Achilles"}, "children": ["Achilles"], "mythologicalEvents": {"burningOfAchillesMortality": "Attempt to make Achilles immortal by burning away his mortality in fire", "dippingInRiverStyx": "Attempt to make Achilles invulnerable by dipping him in the River Styx"}, "worship": {"historicalRecords": "Persisted in some regions", "significantCult": "Not venerated as a goddess by cult in most regions; an exception in Laconia"}, "associations": {"associatedDeities": ["Zeus", "Poseidon", "Hephaestus"], "connectionWithMetis": "Close connection has been argued between Thetis and Metis, another shape-shifting sea-power later beloved by Zeus"}, "literaryReferences": {"works": ["Homer's Iliad", "Euripides's Andromache", "Apollonius Rhodius's Argonautica", "The Shield of Achilles by WH Auden"]}, "modernPortrayals": {"films": ["Clash of the Titans (1981)", "Troy (2004)"], "literature": ["The Song of Achilles by Madeline Miller", "The Silence of the Girls by Pat Baker"], "otherMedia": ["Lore: Olympus by Rachel Smythe (2019)"]}}
Thetys vagina: {"topic": "Thetys vagina", "description": "Thetys vagina, or the twin sailed salp, is the largest known solitary species of salp and the only valid species of the genus Thetys. It was first described by W.G Tilesius in 1802. The species is transparent and gelatinous, making it difficult to be seen in water, which is helpful in avoiding predators. It has a fossil range that is very recent. Other animals often mistaken for T. vagina are Salpa fusiformis, Aurelia aurita, and Pegea confoederata. There is no known status of conservation for this species. T. vagina DNA was sequenced as part of a larger project in 2014, where spiny lobster larvae were found attached to T. vagina and consuming it.", "physical_description": {"size": "Up to 333 mm (13 in) long", "development_forms": {"aggregate_generation": {"size": "Up to 250 mm", "muscle_bands": 5}, "solitary_generation": {"size": "Up to 300 mm", "muscle_bands": 20, "tentacles": 2}, "tests": "Covered in ridges and grooves", "digestive_system": "Colored, seen as a dark or colorful lump", "embryos_size": "Between 10-15 mm"}}, "distribution": {"habitats": "Pelagic marine environments in tropical and temperate waters of the Pacific, Atlantic, and Indian Ocean", "occasional_occurrence": "In colder waters in the northern Atlantic, likely following warm water currents", "notable_occurrences": ["Central coast of British Columbia", "West Coast of the U.S.", "Off the coast of northern Honshu and southern Hokkaido, Japan", "Recorded biomass of 852 g WW m\u22123 in the Tasman Sea"]}, "diet": {"feeding_behavior": "Consumes plankton nutrient water and filters it via an internal net made of mucus", "diet_contents": ["Marine plankton including single-celled organisms such as dinoflagellates, silicoflagellates, diatoms, and tintinnids", "Copepods and other small particles"], "preyed_upon_by": ["Medusae", "Siphonophores", "Ctenophores", "Heteropods", "Sea turtles", "Late stage larvae of the spiny lobster", "Marine birds", "Various species of fish"], "energy_content": "11.00 kJ g\u22121 DW"}, "ecology": {"carbon_exchange": "Efficient carbon sinks and contribute to organic carbon flux", "benthic_consumption": "Benthic communities consume T. vagina carcasses, providing nutrients and carbon input"}, "etymology": {"generic_name": "Refers to Tethys or Thetis, Greek mythological figures", "species_epithet": "Latin for 'sheath' or 'scabbard'"}, "media": {"photograph": "Link to photograph", "video": "Link to video of swimming behavior on YouTube"}}
Thliptodon: {"seaAngels": {"scientificName": "Clionidae", "commonName": "Sea angels", "description": "The Clionidae are a family of sea angels, which are a group of pelagic marine gastropods. They resemble angels, complete with flapping 'wings', hence their common name. They are gelatinous, mostly transparent pteropods, and they only have shells in their embryonic stage. They are mostly very small, with the largest species (Clione limacina) reaching 5 cm (2 in).", "externalAnatomy": {"description": "The Clionidae use winglike flaps for rhythmical locomotion, as if flying in the sea. These 'wings' are attached to the anterior part of the body. The posterior part is gelatinous and mostly transparent. Tiburonia granrojo: {"Tiburonia": {"genus": "jellyfish", "family": "Ulmaridae", "discoveryYear": 2003, "species": "Tiburonia granrojo", "discoverer": "George Matsumoto and MBARI crew", "morphologicalAnalysis": "Pieces of the medusae (bell margin and arms) were collected for morphological analysis", "taxonomicIdentification": "Led to sequencing and taxonomic identification", "subfamily": "Tiburoniinae", "genusEtymology": "Named after the ROV 'Tiburon', meaning 'shark' in Spanish", "speciesEtymology": "Originally intended to be called 'big ugly', renamed 'granrojo', meaning 'big red' in Spanish", "habitat": "Ocean depths of 600 to 1,500 metres", "distribution": "Found in the Pacific Ocean, including the Gulf of California, Monterey Bay, Hawaii, and Japan", "size": "Up to 76 centimetres in diameter", "physicalCharacteristics": {"oralArms": "Thick fleshy 4-7 oral arms", "radialCanals": "Do not narrow", "color": "Deep red"}, "environmentalConditions": {"temperature": "2.7\u20134.9C", "salinity": "34.1-34.5 PSU", "oxygenContent": "0.15-1.22 ml of O2 1^-1"}, "population": "Only 23 members of the species found to date", "retrievalForStudy": "Only one small specimen retrieved for further study", "videosTakenBy": "Remote controlled submarines", "publication": "Announced in Marine Biology in 2003", "specimenLocation": "National Science Museum in Tokyo", "furtherReading": [{"title": "Article in the California Academic of Sciences' Science Now", "content": "Several high quality images"}, {"title": "Article for National Geographic Today"}, {"title": "Report in Innovations Report"}, {"title": "Release in MBARI News"}, {"title": "Big Red Jellyfish | Smithsonian Ocean Portal"}]}}
Tomopteridae: {"Tomopteridae": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Annelida", "class": "Polychaeta", "order": "Phyllodocida", "family": "Tomopteridae"}, "description": "Tomopteridae is a family of holopelagic polychaetes known for being very active swimmers with a high metabolic rate. They have a unique body structure with a large coelom that serves as a buoyancy aid and fluid circulation system.", "characteristics": {"length": "1-2 cm to 30 cm", "metabolic rate": "high", "buoyancy aid": "large coelom filled with body fluid of similar density to seawater", "circulatory system": "lost, coelomic fluid functions in transport", "reproductive method": "females produce gelatinous egg cases that float in water column"}, "behavior": {"swimming": "active swimmers", "bioluminescence": "some species are bioluminescent, producing yellow light", "propulsion": "metachronal paddling, sequential movement of multiple appendages"}, "unique features": {"muscular system": "reduced to a mesh just below the epidermis", "sperm": "have two tails", "parapodia": "able to change surface area by spreading and contracting, creating differences in drag"}, "genera": ["Tomopteris", "Briaraea", "Enapteris", "Escholtzia"]}}
Torquaratoridae: {"Torquaratoridae": {"scientificName": "Torquaratoridae", "commonName": "Neck Plow", "description": "Torquaratoridae is a family of acorn worms (Hemichordata) that lives in deep waters between 350 and 4000 meters. They have semitransparent gelatinous bodies, often brightly colored, and can grow up to three feet in length. They use cilia to glide over the ocean floor and feed on detritus, leaving behind a trail of feces.", "habitat": "Deep waters between 350 and 4000 meters", "feeding": "Feeds on detritus by gliding over the ocean floor at a rate of about three inches per hour", "reproduction": {"embryos": "One species (Coleodesmium karaensis) has been shown to care for the offspring by bearing about a dozen embryos surrounded by a thin membrane in shallow depressions on the surface of the mother's pharyngeal region.", "eggSize": "The large eggs measure almost 2 millimeters across", "development": "Direct development without larvae"}, "anatomy": {"proboscisSkeleton": "Reduced or absent in different species", "stomochord": "Reduced in adults, extending through the entire length of the collar in some species", "reproductiveOrgans": "Unusual by being located outside the body; numerous ovaries and testicles bulge outwards in an epidermal pouch attached to the rest of the body by a slender stalk"}, "adaptations": "Adaptations to life in deep-sea habitats, such as unusual reproductive organs and reduced body musculature"}, "genera": {"Allapasus": "Holland, Kuhnz & Osborn, 2012", "Coleodesmium": "Osborn, Gebruk, Rogacheva & Holland, 2013", "Tergivelum": "Holland, Jones, Ellena, Ruhl & Smith, 2009", "Torquarator": "Holland, Clague, Gordon, Gebruk, Pawson & Vecchione, 2005", "Yoda": "Priede, Osborn, Gebruk, Jones, Shale, Rogacheva & Holland, 2012"}}
Trachipterus altivelis: {"King-of-the-salmon": {"scientificName": "Trachipterus altivelis", "family": "Trachipteridae", "distribution": "Eastern Pacific Ocean from Alaska to Chile", "habitat": "Open ocean, depth of up to 900 meters (3,000 feet)", "description": "Elongated, ribbon-shaped body with a long dorsal fin, silver body with crimson-colored fins and blackish area above the eye", "size": {"length": "Up to 1.83 meters (6.0 feet)", "largerSpecimens": "Reported to be larger than 1.83 meters"}, "reproduction": {"type": "Oviparous", "spawning": "Year-round, with no specific peak", "eggSize": "2.6\u20133.7 mm (0.10\u20130.15 in) in diameter"}, "juveniles": {"features": "Longer fins than adults, silvery with red fins and 3\u20135 dark blotches on the sides above the lateral line", "diet": "Copepods, polychaete worms, fish larvae, amphipods, copepods, and fish scales"}, "diet": "Copepods, krill, small pelagic fishes, young rockfishes, squid, octopus", "predators": ["Bigeye thresher shark (Alopias superciliosus)", "Longnose lancetfish (Alepisaurus ferox)"], "encounters": {"fishingEncounters": "Encountered while trolling for salmon, in nets", "beachEncounters": "Occasionally washed up on the shore"}}, "Folklore": {"origin": "Legends of the Makah people", "myth": "Belief that king-of-the-salmon leads the salmon annually to their spawning grounds, with killing one feared to stop the salmon run", "specificEpithet": "Formerly referred to as rex-salmonorum, with 'rex' meaning 'king' in Latin"}}
Trichiuridae: {"cutlassfishes": {"description": "Cutlassfishes are predatory fish in the family Trichiuridae of the order Scombriformes found in seas throughout the world. They are long, slender, and generally steely blue or silver in colour, with reduced or absent pelvic and caudal fins, giving them an eel-like appearance, and large fang-like teeth. Some species are known as scabbardfishes, hairtails, or frostfishes.", "species": 45, "habitat": "Seas worldwide", "classification": {"subfamilies": [{"name": "Aphanopidinae", "genera": ["Aphanopus", "Benthodesmus"]}, {"name": "Lepidopodinae", "genera": ["Assurger", "Eupleurogrammus", "Evoxymetopon", "Lepidopus"]}, {"name": "Trichiurinae", "genera": ["Demissolinea", "Lepturacanthus", "Tentoriceps", "Trichiurus"]}]}, "timeline": {"source": "Sepkoski, Jack. Tubulariidae: {"Tubulariidae": {"definition": "Tubulariidae is a family of hydroid cnidarians. They are close relatives of the Hydridae and are now united with these and a number of relatives in a newly recognized suborder Aplanulata. Most species in this family grow on stalks and resemble small flowers.", "superfamily": "Presumed superfamily or infraorder Tubulariida of suborder Capitata", "suborder": "Aplanulata", "genera": ["Bouillonia Petersen, 1990", "Ectopleura", "Hybocodon L.Agassiz, 1860", "Lobataria Watson, 2008", "Ralpharia Watson, 1980", "Tubularia", "Zyzzyzus"]}}
Tunicata: {"tunicate": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Chordata", "subphylum": "Tunicata", "classes": ["Ascidiacea", "Thaliacea", "Appendicularia"]}, "characteristics": {"body_structure": "Sessile or pelagic, filter feeders, with sac-like body structure and two tubular openings (siphons)", "unique_feature": "Possess an outer covering or 'tunic' made of proteins and carbohydrates"}, "species": {"number_of_species": 3000, "common_names": ["sea squirts", "sea pork", "sea livers", "sea tulips"]}, "fossil_record": {"early_occurrence": "Early Cambrian period"}, "feeding": {"feeding_method": "Suspension feeders - capture planktonic particles by filtering sea water through their bodies", "feeding_process": "Draw in water through buccal siphon, trap planktonic particles with mucous net in the pharynx, then move to the stomach for digestion"}, "life_cycle": {"reproduction": "Mostly hermaphrodites, release sperm and eggs into the water for external fertilization; larvae may have notochords and tadpole-like appearance"}, "medical_uses": {"compounds": ["Plitidepsin", "Trabectedin"], "potential_medical_applications": "Treatment of cancer and potentially for regenerative processes in humans"}, "uses_by_humans": {"food": {"consumption": "Variety of species consumed as food in different cultures e.g., piure in Chile, sea pineapple in Japan and Korea"}, "other_uses": {"biofuel_research": "Being researched as a potential source of biofuel due to cellulose and protein content", "model_organisms": "Used in scientific research as model organisms for developmental and genetic studies"}}}}
Turridae: {"entity": {"name": "Turridae", "description": "Turridae is a taxonomic family name for predatory sea snails, marine gastropod mollusks in the superfamily Conoidea. The family is a major component of the Indo-Pacific molluscan fauna, and its species are found worldwide, mostly in the neritic zone. The family was originally thought to consist of several thousand closely related sea snail species, but it was later discovered to be polyphyletic. As a result, the family has been greatly reduced in size, and a number of other families were created to contain monophyletic lineages previously thought to be part of Turridae.", "distribution": "Species in the family Turridae are found worldwide, with most of them located in the neritic zone. The family is a major component of the Indo-Pacific molluscan fauna.", "shellDescription": "The shells of Turridae species are narrow with a more or less fusiform shape. The whorls are elongate to broadly spindle-shaped and conical. They are generally small, usually less than 15 mm in length, with strong ribs and spiral ridges. The aperture is long and narrow, with a siphonal canal and an anal sinus. The shells show variable sculpture and are generally carnivorous, predatory gastropods with a poison gland and toxoglossan radula used for predation and self-defense.", "taxonomyHistory": "The family Turridae was initially considered one of the most difficult groups to study due to a large number of supra-specific described taxa, species diversity, and rarity. The taxonomy of Turridae has undergone several revisions over the years, resulting in the creation of new subfamilies and the resolution of the polyphyletic family into 13 monophyletic families based on anatomical and molecular phylogeny.", "currentGenera": ["Coronia", "Coroniopsis", "Cryptogemma", "Daphnobela", "Decollidrillia", "Eopleurotoma", "Epalxis", "Epidirella", "Gemmula", "Gemmuloborsonia", "Gemmulopsis", "Ingaunoturricula", "Iotyrris", "Kuroshioturris", "Lophiotoma", "Lucerapex", "Optoturris", "Oxyacrum", "Pleuroliria", "Polystira", "Purpuraturris", "Turridrupa", "Turris", "Unedogemmula", "Xenuroturris"], "furtherReading": ["Grant, U. S. & H. R. Gale, 1931", "Powell, A. W. B., 1942", "Powell A. W. B. (1964)", "Morrison, J. P. E., 1966", "Oyama, K., 1966", "Powell, A. W. B., 1966", "Powell, A. W. B., 1969", "Sabelli, B. & G. Spada, 1977", "Kilburn R. N., 1983", "McLean J., 1971", "Vera Pel\u00e1ez, J. L., J. Martinell & M. C. Lozano-Francisco, 1999", "Vera pel\u00e1ez, J. Uria aalge: {"name": "Common Murre", "scientificName": "Uria aalge", "taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Chordata", "class": "Aves", "order": "Charadriiformes", "family": "Alcidae", "genus": "Uria", "species": "U. aalge"}, "description": "The common murre is a large auk with a circumpolar distribution, occurring in low-Arctic and boreal waters in the North Atlantic and North Pacific. It spends most of its time at sea, only coming to land to breed on rocky cliff shores or islands.", "habitat": "Breeding habitat includes islands, rocky shores, cliffs, and sea stacks. The population is large, with possibly 7.3 million breeding pairs or 18 million individuals.", "distribution": "The common murre has a circumpolar distribution, occurring in low-Arctic and boreal waters in the North Atlantic and North Pacific. Some populations have short migration distances, instead remaining close to the breeding site year-round.", "behavior": {"flight": {"characteristics": "Flies with fast wing beats at a speed of 80 km/h (50 mph). Groups of birds are often seen flying together in a line just above the sea surface."}, "diving": {"method": "Pursuit-diver that forages for food by swimming underwater using its wings for propulsion. Dives usually last less than one minute, but the bird can swim underwater for distances of over 30 m (100 ft) and has been recorded diving to depths of up to 180 m (590 ft)."}, "feeding": {"diet": "Eats small schooling forage fish, marine worms, squid, and crustaceans such as amphipods. Consumes 20\u201332 g of food in a day on average.", "foraging range": "Can venture far from its breeding grounds to forage; distances of 100 km (60 mi) and more are often observed."}, "reproduction": {"reproductiveSystem": "Nests in densely packed colonies in areas such as islands, rocky shores, cliffs, and sea stacks. Does not make nests and lays its eggs on bare rock ledges or the ground.", "incubation": "Both parents incubate the egg for 28 to 34 days in shifts of 1\u201338 hours.", "growthOfChick": "Chicks leave the nest after 16 to 30 days (average 20\u201322 days), and glide down into the sea, slowing their fall by fluttering as they are not yet able to fly. The male cares for the chick at sea until it is able to fly."}}, "relationshipWithHumans": {"pollution": "Major oil spills double the winter mortality of breeding adults but appear to have little effect on birds less than three years old. This loss of breeding birds can be compensated by increased recruitment of 4\u20136 year olds to breeding colonies.", "foodSource": "In areas such as Newfoundland and Labrador, the birds, along with the related thick-billed murre, are consumed."}}
Urticina: {"Urticina": {"description": "Urticina is a genus of relatively large and often colorful sea anemones in the family Actiniidae from the North Pacific, North Atlantic, and Arctic Oceans.", "species": [{"name": "Urticina asiatica", "author": "Averincev", "year": 1967}, {"name": "Urticina clandestina", "authors": ["Sanamyan N.", "Sanamyan K.", "McDaniel"], "year": 2013}, {"name": "Urticina coccinea", "author": "Verrill", "year": 1866}, {"name": "Urticina columbiana", "author": "Verrill", "year": 1922, "commonNames": ["crusty red anemone", "columbia sand anemone", "sand anemone", "sand-rose anemone"]}, {"name": "Urticina coriacea", "author": "Cuvier", "year": 1798, "commonName": "red beaded anemone"}, {"name": "Urticina crassicornis", "author": "M\u00fcller", "year": 1776, "commonName": "Christmas anemone"}, {"name": "Urticina eques", "author": "Gosse", "year": 1858, "commonNames": ["white-spotted rose anemone", "strawberry anemone"]}, {"name": "Urticina felina", "author": "Linnaeus", "year": 1761, "commonName": "northern red anemone"}, {"name": "Urticina grebelnyi", "authors": ["Sanamyan, N.P.", "Sanamyan, K.E."], "year": 2006}, {"name": "Urticina macloviana", "author": "Lesson", "year": 1830}, {"name": "Urticina mcpeaki", "authors": ["Hauswaldt", "Pearson"], "year": 1999}, {"name": "Urticina piscivora", "authors": ["Sebens", "Laakso"], "year": 1978, "commonNames": ["fish-eating anemone", "fish-eating urticina"]}, {"name": "Urticina tuberculata", "author": "Cocks", "year": 1850}]}}
Valvatida: {"Valvatida": {"taxonomy": {"order": "Valvatida", "class": "Asteroidea", "phylum": "Echinodermata"}, "description": "The Valvatida is an order of starfish in the class Asteroidea, containing 695 species in 172 genera in 17 families. Xenophyophore: {"Xenophyophorea": {"description": "Xenophyophorea is a clade of multinucleate unicellular organisms found on the ocean floor, belonging to the group of foraminiferans. nuclei", "test": {"composition": "Agglutinated tests made of calcium carbonate and other foreign mineral particles glued together with organic cements, ranging from a few millimetres to 20 centimetres in diameter", "variation": "Delicate and elaborate shapes, including compartmentalized tests consisting of multiple chambers"}, "unique_terms": {"stercomata": "Individual waste pellets", "stercomares": "Pellets bundled together in long strings", "xanthosomes": "Small, yellow-red spherical bodies", "granellae": "Crystals of barite found within their cytoplasm", "linellae": "Threadlike structures found outside of the granellare in some xenophyophores", "xenophyae": "Agglutinated particles from which the test is constructed, containing sediment particles, sponge spicules, radiolarian tests, and the tests of smaller foraminifera"}, "mineral_selection": "Select certain minerals and elements from their environment that are included in their tests and cytoplasm or concentrated in excretions"}, "growth_and_reproduction": {"reproduction": "Assumed to involve an alternation of generations", "gametes": "Form in a specialized part of the granellare, with subsequent stages resembling amoeba-like structures"}, "habitat_and_range": {"depth": "Found between depths of 500 and 10,600 metres, with most being epifaunal living atop the seabed, while one species is known to be infaunal burying itself up to 6 centimetres deep into the sediment", "distribution": "Found in all four major ocean basins and in areas of enhanced organic carbon flux such as beneath productive surface waters, sub-marine canyons, seamounts, abyssal hills, and continental slopes"}, "feeding": {"diet": "Actively uptake food from surrounding sediments using pseudopodia and use the test to trap particles", "feeding_ecology": "Play a major role in ocean-floor biogeochemical cycling, supplement their feeding with bacteria growing on their waste products, and may utilize diatoms and dissolved organic matter"}, "fossil_record": {"fossils": "No positively-identified xenophyophore fossils have been discovered yet", "possible_links": "Some ediacaran fossils have been suggested to represent Decapoda: {"Decapoda": {"description": "Decapoda is an order of crustaceans within the class Malacostraca, and includes crabs, lobsters, crayfish, shrimp, and prawns. It is estimated to contain nearly 15,000 extant species in around 2,700 genera, with around 3,300 fossil species. Decapods are characterized by having ten legs and a variety of appendages for feeding and movement.", "anatomy": {"appendages": 38, "legs": 10, "specialized appendages": {"pereiopods": "found on the last five thoracic segments", "chelipeds": "one pair of pereiopods with enlarged pincers", "maxillipeds": "three pairs of feeding appendages in front of the pereiopods", "pleopods": "five pairs of appendages on the abdomen", "uropods": "one pair on the telson, forming the tail fan"}}, "evolution": {"origin": "Late Ordovician around 455 million years ago", "divergence": {"Dendrobranchiata": "prawns, as the first group to diverge", "Pleocyemata": "diverged into swimming shrimp groupings and crawling/walking group called Reptantia"}, "key events": "High species diversification coincided with the rise and spread of modern coral reefs in the Jurassic and Cretaceous periods"}, "classification": {"suborders": {"Dendrobranchiata": {"included groups": ["Penaeoidea", "Sergestoidea"]}, "Pleocyemata": {"included groups": ["Infraorder Stenopodidea", "Infraorder Caridea", "Infraorder Astacidea", "Infraorder Anomura", "Infraorder Brachyura"]}}, "superfamilies": {"Stenopodidea": ["Procaridoidea", "Oplophoroidea"], "Caridea": ["Galatheacaridoidea", "Palaemonoidea"], "Astacidea": ["Enoplometopoidea", "Nephropoidea", "Parastacoidea"], "Anomura": ["Galatheoidea", "Hippoidea", "Lithodoidea", "Paguroidea"]}}}, "references": {"1": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decapoda"}}

Munididae: {"Munididae": {"type": "Family of squat lobsters", "description": "The family Munididae is taxonomically separated from the family Galatheidae. It includes squat lobsters, which can be distinguished by the presence of a trispinose frontal edge to the carapace, a central rostrum, and two spines extending forward from above the eyes. Most species are deep-water taxa.", "ecology": "Some species enter shallow water, but the majority are deep-water taxa, in contrast to the mostly shallow-water Galatheidae.", "taxonomy": {"separation_date": "2010", "previous_inclusion": "Many genera included in the family Munididae were previously part of the wider circumscription of the family Galatheidae.", "recognized_genera": ["Data related to Munididae at Wikispecies", "Media related to Munididae at Wikimedia Commons"]}}}
Mytilidae: {"Mytilidae": {"description": "Mytilidae is a family of small to large marine and brackish-water bivalve molluscs found worldwide, with some species inhabiting freshwater environments.
