Opisthoteuthis californiana: {"Opisthoteuthis californiana": {"alsoKnownAs": ["Flapjack Octopus", "Flapjack Devilfish"], "description": "Opisthoteuthis californiana, also known as the flapjack octopus, or flapjack devilfish, is a species of umbrella octopus. It usually appears pinkish with fins above its eyes and has a maximum size of 20 cm mantle length. Unlike other octopus species, it is unable to camouflage by changing skin color and texture due to its gelatinous body.", "distribution": {"habitat": "Muddy seafloor off the coast of the northern Pacific Ocean", "range": "Northern and northeastern Pacific Ocean, from central Honsh\u016b (Japan) and the Sea of Okhotsk to the Bering Sea and the western coast of North America including Eureka Bar, California"}, "reproduction": {"spawning": "Continuous spawning over several years with one or two large eggs at a time", "eggCharacteristics": "Hard, protective outer shell, not brooded or protected by the mother, hatched young undergo direct development, mature females carry about 1400\u20132380 eggs in their ovary"}, "classification": {"genus": "Opisthoteuthis", "relatedSpecies": ["Opisthoteuthis albatrossi"]}, "diet": "Mainly small benthic/epibenthic crustaceans including copepods, isopods, mysids, and small shrimp", "popularCulture": {"films": ["Finding Nemo"], "books": ["The Adventures of a Flapjack Octopus"], "videoGames": ["ABZU"]}, "recentResearch": "Research is ongoing in Monterey Canyon with specimens resembling O. californiana, and some eggs from the octopus have been incubating for a year as of 2015"}}
Paragorgia arborea: {"name": "Paragorgia arborea", "scientificName": "Paragorgia arborea", "commonName": "Bubblegum coral", "description": "Paragorgia arborea is a species of coral in the family Paragorgiidae, commonly known as the bubblegum coral because of its bulbous branch tips. It mainly grows in depths between 200 and 1,300 metres at temperatures between 3 and 8 \u00b0C. It is found widespread in the Northern Atlantic Ocean and Northern Pacific Ocean on seamounts and knolls, and was first described by the Swedish naturalist Carl Linnaeus in 1758. P. arborea is a foundation species, providing a habitat for other species in deep sea coral ecosystems.", "characteristics": {"height": "Up to 6 metres", "color": "White, red, or salmon", "structure": "Branching, fan-shaped structure with a tough central trunk and many branches", "reproductivePolyps": "Siphonozoids", "feedingPolyps": "Autozoids"}, "reproductiveStrategy": "P. arborea is hypothesized to be a brooder, where fertilization takes place on or inside the female colony. Corals reproduce sexually by either spawning or brooding, but then once settled, corals reproduce asexually to grow into a many branched colony.", "feedingStrategy": "P. arborea is a filter feeder that optimizes nutrient uptake by adjusting its behavior to the tidal cycle. It extends its polyps to actively feed when tidal currents bring in organic matter and retract them to digest the food or be inactive afterward.", "microbiome": {"composition": ["Alphaproteobacteria", "Mycoplasmatota", "Spirochaetota"], "features": "Host-specific microbiome and an external surface mucopolysaccharide layer (SML) acting as a defense against water-borne pathogens and helping the coral filter feed"}, "distributionAndHabitat": {"latitude": "Between 30\u00b0 and 70\u00b0 in both hemispheres", "depth": "200 to 1,300 metres", "temperature": "3 to 8 \u00b0C", "location": "North Atlantic Ocean, Northern Pacific Ocean, along the entire Norwegian coast, Western Atlantic, Mid-Atlantic Ridge south of Iceland", "preference": "Exposed locations with strong currents, marine canyons, and on the continental slope with a preference for hard substrate"}, "ecology": {"associations": ["Gorgonocephalus caputmedusae", "Primnoa resedaeformis", "Paramuricea grandis", "Keratoisis ornata", "Pennatula borealis"], "role": "Foundation species, serving as a breeding ground, shelter, and feeding space for a wide variety of species and increasing the species richness of the entire ecosystem"}, "conservationThreats": {"threats": ["Trawling by commercial fisheries", "Offshore oil extraction", "Deep sea mining", "Cable laying"], "vulnerability": "Slow growth rate and fragile skeleton", "impact": "Destruction of P. arborea due to human disturbance will have effects that reverberate throughout multiple trophic levels in the deep-sea coral ecosystem and affect species richness because it is a foundation species."}}

Pectinidae: {"scallops": {"taxonomy": {"kingdom": "Animalia", "phylum": "Mollusca", "class": "Bivalvia", "order": "Pectinoida", "family": "Pectinidae"}, "diet": "filter feeders, eat plankton", "habitat": "live in all of the world's oceans, in relatively shallow waters from the low tide line to 100 m, and prefer living within, upon, or under rocks, coral, rubble, sea grass, kelp, sand, or mud", "digestive_system": {"lack": "siphons", "digestion": "food trapped in mucus and then moved toward the mouth by cilia on the structure"}, "nervous_system": {"features": "controlled by three paired ganglia located at various points throughout their anatomy"}, "vision": {"eyes": "large number (up to 200) of small eyes arranged along the edge of their mantles"}, "reproduction": "dioecious (males and females are separate), simultaneous hermaphrodites (both sexes in the same individual), and a few are protoandrous hermaphrodites (males when young then switching to female)"}, "shell": {"shape": "consists of two similarly shaped valves with a straight hinge line along the top, devoid of teeth, and producing a pair of flat wings or \"ears\" on either side of its midpoint", "decorative_use": "symbol of St James, fertility symbol, emblem of pilgrimage"}, "seafood_industry": {"usage": "highly prized as a food source, and some are farmed as aquaculture", "largest_fishery": "Atlantic sea scallop (Placopecten magellanicus) found off the northeastern United States and eastern Canada"}, "pearls": {"production": "occasionally produce pearls, though usually lack lustre and iridescence"}, "symbolism_and_culture": {"associated_figures": ["St. James the Great", "Venus (Roman goddess of love and fertility)"], "heraldry": "badge of pilgrimage, coat of arms"}, "contemporary_art": {"sculpture": "Maggi Hambling's steel sculpture, The Scallop, erected in 2003 as a memorial to the composer Benjamin Britten"}}
